PETITION.PRESENTERS: COATES; COLSTON; DEVEREUX; FAULKNER; GILES; HERRON; JONES; KERNOT; LEWIS; PANIZZA; REID; WALSH

PETITION.TITLE: Tobacco Advertising
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled: the humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That we the undersigned call for urgent action by our Federal Parliament and all government agencies concerned with Health and Sport to impose an immediate ban on the incidental advertising of tobacco products on television and provide for alternative funding to replace tobacco sponsorship. That tobacco sponsorship of sporting events and participants openly flouts the 1976 Federal law prohibiting tobacco advertising on TV and radio. That our Parliament immediately end this association between healthy sports and the deaths of 18,300 people in Australia each year from tobacco-related diseases.
And your petitioners in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Coates (from 20 citizens), Senator Colston (from 25 citizens), Senator Devereux (from 60 citizens), Senator Faulkner (from 25 citizens), Senator Giles (from 25 citizens), Senator Herron (from 25 citizens), Senator Jones (from 81 citizens), Senator Kernot (from 50 citizens), Senator Lewis (from 52 citizens), Senator Panizza (from 27 citizens), Senator Reid (from 99 citizens) and Senator Walsh (from 25 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare: Abortions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and the Senators in Parliament assembled:
The humble Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
* That every abortion kills an unborn human baby.
* That the right to life to all humans is the most fundamental and essential of all human rights.
* That the Government's first duty is to protect this right to life.
* That the most defenceless and threatened lives are those of unborn babies for whom the Government is duty bound to take extra steps to protect.
* That in 1987/88 taxpayers funds through Medicare provided Medical Benefits for 61,879 abortions totalling $6.4 million.
* That in the same year Commonwealth grants to the States indirectly financed the deliberate killing of thousands of other unborn babies in State Public Hospitals.

Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Parliament carry out its duty to protect the right to life of Australian babies by ceasing to fund abortions through Medicare, restricting grants to the States and by all other means at its disposal.
And your Petitioners as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Michael Baume (from 45 citizens), Senator Bishop (from 220 citizens), Senator Brownhill (from 178 citizens), Senator Faulkner (from 197 citizens) and Senator Jones (from 181 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Aidex Exhibition
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and senators in the Senate assembled.

The petition of the undersigned shows the very deep concern of people in the community against the proposed AIDEX exhibition of weapons of war in our country. We firmly believe that it is not in Australia's interest to become dealers in death and destruction. Particularly at this time when our planet's environment is in a parlous condition and demands statesmanlike leadership to the world on its rehabilitation. We therefore ask that:-

The Exhibition to take place be one which shows instead the ways in which we aim to overcome the dangers to our world from poisoned soil, air and water by high-lighting the need for tree-planting, solar-powered homes, electric cars, etc. as a means of attacking the global warming and other hazards to our fragile environment.
And we, your humble petitioners will as in duty bound, ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Archer (from 20 citizens), Senator Jones (from 11 citizens) and Senator Zakharov (from 30 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Electoral Advertising
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled; the petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That we call upon the Senate to reject legislation denying Australians the right to advertise electoral material on radio and television, believing such bans amount to a denial of free speech, an unfair advantage to an incumbent government, and denial of information to print-handicapped and other Australians.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Bishop (from 18 citizens), Senator Jones (from nine citizens) and Senator Reid (from 69 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare: Abortions
PETITION.PARA: The Honourable President and members of the Senate assembled in Parliament. This petition of the below citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the Senate that we support the continued cover for all abortions on the Medicare schedule. We oppose any attempt to restrict access to the rebate under Medicare.

Medicare cannot pretend to be a Universal health care system without providing a rebate for a termination of pregnancy. Those who will be hardest hit by proposals to restrict access to items 6469, 274 and 275 on the Medicare schedule are poorer and disadvantaged women who will not be able to meet the cost of a non-subsidised abortion.
Your petitioners humbly pray and request that the Senate will vote against any attempt to restrict access to abortion or any abortion-related items on the Medicare schedule.

PETITION.TITLE: Reduction of Armaments
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and Members of the Senate assembled:
The Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia humbly showeth:
That currently Australia's military expenditure is $8,970 million a year, i.e. over $24 million a day:
That the 1989 Environmental Land Package allowed $320 million to be spent on the environment over the next ten years, but that this
- is less than the cost of one Anzac frigate (initially $416 million)
- or less than half the cost of one submarine ($644 million);
That Project Kangaroo 1989 military exercise cost $230 million in three months, more than two-thirds the sum allotted to the environment for ten years;
That, in the meantime we urgently need more money for
- housing for the homeless,
- safer and more efficient public transport,
- more hospital staff and beds,
- better health services, education, child care, etc.;

That while we recognise the need for legitimate spending on defence, we consider that current expenditure and projected development of Australian military capacity far exceeds that required to maintain Australian security;
That we believe a reduction in our military build up would, in fact, contribute to peace and security in our region.
That we therefore appeal to the Government to reduce expenditure on armaments and use the money thus saved for the needs of the community and the environment.
And we, your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Broadcasting Corporation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The Petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
That the Australian Broadcasting Corporation is increasingly unable to fulfil its responsibilities to provide independence, integrity, quality entertainment and commercial-free services.
The Australian Broadcasting Corporation must be funded in such a way for these responsibilities and obligations to be maintained.
Your Petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should:
1) Increase the annual funding base of the ABC by a minimum of $32 million;
2) Guarantee adequate and properly indexed funding to the ABC for the next three years on an agreed basis with the ABC;
3) Maintain the legislative prohibition on corporate sponsorship and advertising on the ABC.
And your Petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Assets Test: Family Farm
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
This petition of concerned citizens of Australia respectfully shows:
That family farming and small business assets are unsuitable for inclusion in the assets test for Austudy, Assistance for Isolated Children and other education allowances.

Your Petitioners ask that the Senate in Parliament assembled should request the Australian Government to exempt the family farm of registered primary producers who are living and working on their own farm and the assets of other small businesses from inclusion in the assets tests for Austudy, Assistance for Isolated Children and other education allowances.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Telecom: 0055 Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
1. Telecom is selling 0055 telephone networks to private contractors who provide offensive and sexually explicit recorded messages to the public.

2. The providers of these services are advertising in the pages of Australian newspapers in a manner which is designed to titillate and attract calls from the whole community and thus play on the curiosity of children.
3. These services degrade and humiliate women and portray them as sex objects, and they destroy the innocence of children.

Your petitioners request that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, immediately call on Telecom to so regulate the conditions under which these services are made available, that women are no longer portrayed as sex objects, degraded or humiliated and that the innocence of children is protected.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Smokefree International Flights
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
We, the undersigned,
(i) are alarmed at the health and safety hazards that arise from the smoking of cigarettes and other tobacco products on international airlines, a dangerous practice banned within Australia;

(ii) call for the International Civil Aviation Organisation (ICAO) of which Australia is a member to set a standard for smokefree international flights; standards set by ICAO must be agreed to by its 162 member nations.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Uranium: Mining and Export
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That your petitioners request that the Australian Government take steps immediately to stop the mining and export of uranium
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Aidex Exhibition
PETITION.PARA: To the Hon. the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled, the Petition of the undersigned showeth:

That the Australian Government is making Australia an active participant in the international arms trade by its official support for the Australian International Defence Exhibition (Aidex 91) to be held in November 1991.
Your Petitioners ask that the Senate should-
* request the Government to withdraw all official support and participation from Aidex to regain our international standing as an advocate of disarmament and arms control.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Broadcasting Corporation: Country Hour
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

Having regard to the proposal of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation to alter the format of the Country Hour to a single national programme; the valuable community service provided by the Country Hour; the role of the Country Hour in extending agricultural research extension, market and weather information to farmers on a local basis and the need for local rather than national information.
Your petitioners therefore pray that your Honourable House will:
Call on the Federal Government to ensure that the Country Hour is retained in its present form with predominantly State and localised input to retain its relevance to the farming community.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Goods and Services Tax
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the President and members of the Senate assembled in Parliament:

The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the Senate proposals to introduce a goods and services tax and points out to the Senate that a 15% tax on funerals will cost a pensioner an extra $300 for a low budget funeral.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the Senate will not agree to such a tax.

PETITION.TITLE: Independence of Subjugated Countries, including Croatia and Slovenia

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HARRADINE

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I present to the Senate the following petition, from 369 citizens, which is not strictly in conformity with the Standing Orders as it is not in the correct form:

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned respectfully shows:

* That 92% of Croatians who voted in a referendum on 25 April 1991, supervised by the Constitutional Court of the Republic of Croatia, declared their support for Croatia as a sovereign and independent State and their opposition to Croatia remaining in the Yugoslav Federation;
* That 88% of Slovenians who voted in a referendum democratically expressed their support for Slovenia as an autonomous and independent State;
* That both Slovenia and Croatia have declared themselves to be independent Republics and that each Republic is prepared to defend its territorial integrity.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, should request the Australian Government to:

* Establish diplomatic relations with the legitimate representatives of each Republic and of any currently subjugated country whose residents by a democratically expressed popular vote have declared their wish to be independent; and
* Establish trade relations with the Croatian and Slovenian Republics, to take advantage of the very favourable attitude which exists between the people of these Republics and the Australian people.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

TALK.START.PARA: May I ask you a question, Mr President, again arising out of yesterday's business?
—Yes.

—We were anticipating, pursuant to what you said yesterday, that there would no longer be a picket this morning, the matter having been resolved by the Industrial Relations Commission. A picket is still in place, disrupting honourable senators in the course of their work. I therefore ask you: why is the picket still in place and what efforts are you making to have the picket removed?

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Firstly, the operations of the Senate are not being seriously disrupted. I have just come from a meeting where these questions were asked. There is no backlog of mail. Deliveries are being made. There are now no delays with the provision of newspapers. No-one is stopping senators from getting into the parliamentary building. At 10.10 last night I made arrangements whereby people could get a Commonwealth car at the Melbourne Avenue entrance of Parliament House or senators could avail themselves of Cabcharge vouchers-as many did last night. Senators would know that I am not in charge of Commonwealth cars, and I was certainly not in a position to do anything at 10 o'clock last night.

INTERJECT.PARA: Later today, at 12 noon exactly, the Speaker and I will be meeting with the people who are installing the picket line around Parliament House. I do not want to forecast what will happen at that meeting, but I can assure Senator Hill that I will keep the Senate informed of any developments following that meeting. I am doing everything possible to resolve this dispute.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, could I ask you a question following on the question asked by Senator Hill? As a result of the meeting that you and the Speaker will hold with the people who are conducting the illegal picket, if the picket continues will you continue to make available to senators Cabcharge vouchers and will those Cabcharge vouchers also be available to staff?
—That is a matter that I will report back on. I think that would be the situation, but I will let Senator Parer know after the meeting this afternoon. I do not see any difficulties with that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, you were in the chair last evening when I drew your attention to the fact that the Minister for Administrative Services (Senator Bolkus), who is responsible for Comcar, told the Senate yesterday that Comcar had not intervened with any instructions to the drivers about crossing the picket lines. Last night I told you and the Senate that my driver was instructed over the Comcar radio network that he was not to cross the picket lines.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. I do not want to interrupt Senator Newman, but there are forms of this chamber that should be observed. I have listened to what has been said. I think that I am reading what Senator Newman is saying clearly, but that is going to the merits of the issue. The point is that the forms of this chamber should be observed and we are all out of order at present.
—I can assure Senator Newman that the Minister responsible will be at the meeting to which I am referring.
—I thank you, Mr President. Just before I was interrupted by Senator Harradine-I understand his concerns-I only wished to--
—Order! Senator Newman, you will have to seek leave to make a statement or ask a question.
—Mr President, I seek leave to do so.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I appreciate the information which you have given us that the Minister responsible for Comcar will be present at the meeting, but my purpose in raising again what I told the Senate last night is that, as a result of the Minister misleading the Senate yesterday and the continuing problems which you are facing as the President of the Senate and that we are facing as senators, we have no confidence in the Minister's ability to provide us with the implementation of the agreement which he has with you as the Presiding Officer. Therefore, the assurance that the Minister will be at the meeting and your explanation that you have no responsibility for Comcar fills us with extreme concern and foreboding. My colleagues are not prepared to accept assurances that the matter can be left safely in the hands of the Minister for Administrative Services.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate-
(a) notes:

(i) the latest view of the former Treasurer (Mr Keating) that the notion that interest rates should be set in a medium-term context and target inflation is an echo of an old conservative incantation that did not work in the past and should be dismissed by any government worth its salt-especially a Labor government, and

(ii) reports that the recent change to the Labor Party's economic platform, to the effect that monetary policy must take a medium-term focus to attempt to reduce inflationary expectations and improve price stability, was drafted by Mr Keating;
(b) calls on Mr Keating to explain this seemingly inexplicable contradiction;
(c) notes:
(i) that the new Treasurer (Mr Kerin) believes monetary policy should be set in a medium-term context and therefore disagrees with Mr Keating's most recent statements, and
(ii) that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) supported Mr Keating on economic policy when Mr Keating was Treasurer, but now supports Mr Kerin;
(d) notes with dismay the confusion and disarray in the Government's ranks on fundamental economic policy;
(e) calls on the Government to end its continual leadership struggles, which are rendering coherent policy making impossible; and
(f) condemns Government leaders for allowing their massive egos and desires for power to override the interests of the Australian people.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate-
(a) notes that 18 August 1991 is the 25th Anniversary of the Battle of Long Tan;

(b) recalls that, on 18 August 1966, in the Long Tan rubber plantation in Phuc Tuy Province, 106 Australians of D Company 6RAR held off a force of 2500 Viet Cong and North Vietnamese soldiers for nearly three hours until support arrived;
(c) notes that 18 Australians were killed in this battle and many more wounded;
(d) recalls that D Company was awarded a Presidential Unit Citation for its courage in the face of overwhelming adversity; and
(e) honours the contribution of these and all Australians who served in Vietnam.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate notes that-

(a) in framing the capital gains provision of the Income Tax Assessment Act, the Government has ignored the plight of taxpayers who had lost their investment in shares when the companies concerned were placed in liquidation;

(b) consequently, these shares are in a state of limbo as they cannot be written off because the shareholders are no longer in a position to meet a valid and effective transfer to comply with the Act; and
(c) mechanisms for some deductibility of such losses exist in tax jurisdictions of other OECD countries.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate-
(a) notes that:

(i) the Alternative Budget promoted by the Australian Democrats on 10-11 August 1991 provides for the collection of an additional $6.4 billion in new and additional taxes from the workers of Australia,
(ii) included in those new and additional taxes are taxes which will directly impact on lower income earners, particularly taxes on tobacco, alcohol and fuel,
(iii) there are proposals to re-introduce death duties in the form of an inheritance tax and for a land tax,
(iv) small businessmen and farmers will be penalised by the proposal to tax trusts in the same way as corporations, and
(v) the proposal to recover road costs from trucking companies will impact enormously on people living in remote, rural and provincial Australia; and

(b) calls upon the Treasurer (Mr Kerin) to reject the additional taxes and Government spending proposed by the Democrats and, rather, bring in a budget which severely restricts Government spending and reduces the overall taxation collection from Australian workers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tierney Sen J.W.

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate-
(a) notes that Australia's unemployment rate soared to 9.8 per cent in July 1991 with a record number of 83 900 jobs disappearing during the month;
(b) notes with dismay the appalling rise in teenage unemployment which hit a new high of 28.5 per cent in July 1991, up from 20 per cent a year earlier;
(c) deplores the critical situation in Newcastle, where 30.8 per cent of all teenagers are unemployed, almost one in three, and 38 per cent are unable to find full-time work; and

(d) condemns the Hawke Government for eradicating 129 200 full-time jobs for teenagers over the last 12 months, with the result that more than 40 per cent of teenagers are seeking full-time employment in this country with little or no hope for their future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate-
(a) notes with dismay the reported sale of 25 000 tonnes of heavily subsidised wheat (at $US85-90 per tonne) by Saudi Arabia to our exclusive market of New Zealand;
(b) further notes that this is another ally in the Gulf War that has turned its back on Australia when it comes to trade; and

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp Sen R.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bourne Sen V.

(a) notes that:

(ii) cancellation of naval, army and air force operations would severely restrict the opportunities for training of Australia's armed forces,

(iii) the retirement of capital equipment and cancellation of capital equipment contracts would make the Australian Defence Force incapable of performing its function and that munitions reductions of some $10 million would further effectively reduce the Force's defence capabilities, and

Motion (by Senator Powell) agreed to:

Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-
On behalf of the Australian Democrats, I am introducing this Bill to make the full disclosure of political donations a legal requirement.

Since their inception, the Australian Democrats have had a clear policy in support of full disclosure and we have pursued that commitment with vigour. We believe that a requirement of full disclosure is not only correct in principle, but that the electorate is both entitled to know the source of donations to political parties and wants to have that information available to it.

The whole question of election funding has become a matter of concern in a range of countries recently because of three basic reasons. First, a number of studies, especially in the U.S.A., have shown that special interest contributions to political campaigns do influence legislative behaviour and results. Secondly, the rapidly escalating costs of political advertising, particularly on the electronic media, have placed enormous and growing pressure on participants in elections to raise very large sums of money. And thirdly, a number of scandals in several countries has shown that legislation giving favours to particular groups or businesses or even individuals can be traced back to donations made during election campaigns. We are seeing evidence of this here in Australia in a range of Royal Commissions and both the Report of the Fitzgerald Royal Commission in Queensland and the ICAC in NSW have expressed concern about the dangers of political corruption associated with the existing system of election fund raising and advertising. The Joint Standing Committee Report ``Who Pays the Piper Calls the Tune'' (1989) also focused on these concerns and the risks of distortion to our open democratic system. A specific recommendation of that Committee Report was that all political parties should be required to disclose all donations, gifts and income and that the Australian Electoral Commission should be given power to conduct spot audits of political parties.

As honourable Senators are aware, the Australian Government introduced legislation earlier this year dealing with both disclosure and political advertising. The history of events since then is well-known, but it does bear repeating briefly. The Government's proposed total ban on electronic media advertising was rejected by the Democrats and the Opposition even before the Bill came into the Parliament. However, the Democrats have consistently put the view that the disclosure provisions of the Government's Bill should be toughened and supported. Further, the Democrats have argued consistently that political advertisements should be regulated. We have been particularly vigorous in pushing for ``truth in advertising'' amendments-a matter we have pursued in the Parliament for many years.

Regrettably, for many months, the Government adopted a position of ``no ban, no Bill''. We persisted in our attempts to get support for amendments to toughen disclosure and require truth in advertising. Because we remained firm in our intention to keep the disclosure and ``truth'' issues alive the Government finally backed down from its position of a total ban. The Democrats were pleased to see an acknowledgment at last that the issues of disclosure and advertising could be split. We announced immediately that we would move to refer the advertising section of the Bill, (in its new form of an election-only ban), our proposed regulatory amendments including truth, and the recommendations of the Electoral Matters Committee Report to a Senate Committee for enquiry and report. Most importantly, we made it clear that there was no reason why the Parliament could not deal with the disclosure section of the Bill and pass it immediately.

That remains our view. All parties have stated a position of support for full disclosure. We could have had a law requiring disclosure of donations passed through the Parliament this week if the Government and the Opposition had stuck to their stated commitments on this issue.

The Democrats move to split the Bill has been thwarted by the combined actions of the Coalition and Labor parties in referring the entire Bill to a Committee. The whole concept of parties funding sources becoming a matter of public knowledge is still in jeopardy as a result.

The Opposition parties maintained support for separating the issues of advertising and disclosure until the day before their about-face, and it seems they were never genuine in their moves to split the Bill. When a point was reached that the Bill could be split, the old parties combined so that the disclosure provisions could be quietly shelved.

The Democrats will not stand by and let the issue lapse. Our unsuccessful attempt to save and pass the disclosure provisions this week is a matter of regret, but we will still persist,-as we have for many years,-in pushing for full information being available to the electorate about donations to political parties. This Bill embraces the disclosure provisions of the Government's Bill and includes our amendments to toughen those provisions. The objectives of the Bill's contents are to achieve full, contemporaneous disclosure of donations to political parties, and annual reporting of all their income and expenditure. We welcome constructive comments and any improvements to the Bill to ensure those objectives are met. Most importantly, the existence of this Bill will be a constant reminder to the other parties of their public commitments to disclosure provisions. The Democrats will continue to press for such provisions to become law at the earliest possible opportunity. I commend the Bill to the Senate.

That this Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-
The purpose of this Bill is to amend the Ombudsman Act 1976 in order to broaden the power of the Commonwealth Ombudsman with respect to the Australian Broadcasting Corporation.

Specifically, the Bill seeks to amend sub-paragraphs 1 (a) and (b) of section 5 of the Ombudsman Act 1976 which provide for the Ombudsman to investigate complaints relating to matters of administration by a department or prescribed authority.

This Bill will add sub-paragraph (c) to section 5, which will allow the Ombudsman to respond to, and investigate, complaints regarding programming decisions of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation.
This Amendment seeks to redress the present situation whereby complaints against the ABC are investigated by the ABC.

In May this year, in a belated response to increasing criticism of ABC programming decisions, particularly with regard to its reporting of the Gulf war, the ABC's Managing Director announced the establishment of an ``Independent Complaints Review Panel''.
According to the Managing Director, the panel was established to ``review written complaints of serious bias, lack of balance or unfair treatment arising from ABC broadcasts''.

While recognising the considerable media experience of the members of the panel, it is important to also note that the final determination for action on complaints rests with the ABC's Managing Director.
Despite his assertions, the ``Independent Complaints Review Panel'' is not truly independent.

By way of comparison, I draw your attention to the way in which complaints regarding other media organisations are handled. For example, public complaints against the print media can be addressed to the Press Council, while complaints against commercial television or radio can be made to the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal.
Now to the privileged position of the ABC. There are no independent review or adjudication procedures to deal with complaints about the ABC's programming decisions.
The responsibility for investigating such complaints should not be that of a panel hand-picked by ABC management. Rather, it should be the responsibility of the Ombudsman.
The Ombudsman provides a review mechanism which need not directly interfere with the ABC's independence.
The Ombudsman would be a truly independent adjudicator who is both highly regarded and respected by the public.
Furthermore, the Ombudsman is an established authority which does not require additional establishment costs.
Successive Ombudsmen are of the opinion that their act already gives them the power to investigate ABC programming decisions and they are willing to exercise that power.
The ABC argues that the Ombudsman does not have the power to investigate its programming decisions-that the Ombudsman's jurisdiction relates to administrative decisions only.
This argument denies the public an effective, independent review of their complaints against the ABC.
It is time that the ABC, was made answerable for its questionable programming decisions-decisions which have resulted in an unacceptable decrease in the quality of its programs.
In conclusion, the proposal contained in this Bill will-
* maintain the ABC's independence,
* subject it to a respected and publicly acceptable course or independent adjudication, and
* do so in a cost effective manner.
I encourage you to concur with the amendments proposed in this Bill and vote accordingly.

The Defence Force Superannuation Legislation Amendment Bill and the Military Superannuation and Benefits Bill were referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration. I think the main issue that came from the Senate Committee was one of representation on appeal boards-that was certainly the flavour of submissions-and the Committee agreed to that. That will not appear in terms of amendment to the legislation, but will be incorporated in the rules which will be put down immediately after royal assent. Of course, they are also subject to disallowance, but I understand that those organisations making submissions were quite happy with the way we are approaching that matter.

Additionally, we are proposing amendments to the Military Superannuation and Benefits Bill 1991 and the Defence Force Superannuation Legislation Amendment Bill 1991. These are of a very minor nature. In the case of the Military Superannuation and Benefits Bill, the amendments deal with membership of and transfer to the military superannuation scheme and either fill minor gaps or make more precise provision.

First, the amendments fill a gap in the provision regarding membership by reservists serving in operational areas; second, they make more specific provision regarding elections that may be made by members in certain circumstances; and, third, they make corrections to the provision for the suspension and cancellation of pensions of DFRDB pensioners who re-enter and elect to join the MSBS.

In the case of the Defence Force Superannuation Legislation Amendment Bill-I mention this now because the two things are related-the amendments clarify two matters dealt with in the Bill and otherwise correct references. First, the amendments make more specific provision regarding election of members of the DFRDB scheme who retire, re-enter and again retire. Second, they clarify the class of invalidity retirees to whom proposed amendments of section 57 of the DFRDB Act are to apply. I commend the amendments to the Committee, and I present the supplementary explanatory memoranda to these amendments.

As I said when I spoke in the second reading debate, this is an extremely complex pair of Bills, dealing with the superannuation scheme. It is not easy for members of parliament or, indeed, special interest groups to get a grip on the details that are affected by the drafting.

SPEECH.PARA: To give the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mr Bilney) his due, he was very helpful in providing to the Opposition the opportunity to take advice from superannuation experts on this Bill, and I do not think that I have acknowledged that publicly. I do appreciate the courtesy that was shown by him. Nevertheless, he did not take the well-meaning advice I offered him by way of correspondence earlier this year that this was a very appropriate Bill which should have been introduced and then left to lie on the table for some months so that all those who were interested in the matter could scrutinise it very carefully.

The Opposition did its best to scrutinise the legislation, as did the special interest groups. But exactly as I feared and predicted to the Minister, drafting problems have been found here and there, which are now being addressed by these Government introduced amendments. It is perhaps ironic that the Government is having to come and say, `We did not get it all right the first time'.

I do believe that this is not at all likely to be the last occasion on which amendments to this legislation will be introduced to remedy defects. As I said, it is almost impossible to get a Bill of such complexity all right the first time. That could have been avoided if we all had longer to study the legislation. Nevertheless, I do not wish to be mean-spirited; I simply wish to put that on the record and to say that I am informed that the Government has consulted widely with interest groups on these amendments, and for that I commend it.

Enabling interest groups to see the fine print of what the Government is proposing is a very positive step which is not followed often enough. It is one thing to hear or to read what the Government intends; it is another thing altogether to see what it has actually achieved by way of legislation. Those two things do not always coincide, as we all know. So the interest groups have had an opportunity to be briefed by the officers and have expressed themselves as satisfied with the amendments; the Opposition has had an opportunity to do the same, and it is of the same view.
I do not wish to delay the Committee any further. I simply am prepared, on behalf of the Opposition, to accept the amendments produced by the Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

The Committee is aware that under clause 37 there is provision for those who undertake to serve on to receive retention benefit payments in a lump sum. The argument advanced to us by some potential recipients is that by receiving the lump sum they will incur a higher taxation level. I understand the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray) has a response to that. We have put forward this amendment at the request of potential recipients. Perhaps if they are misinformed, and if we are misinformed, the Minister could correct that. However, I would like to proceed with the amendment on behalf of the people who have approached us.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government opposes the Australian Democrats amendments, basically on two grounds. Firstly, the actual level of the retention bonus was set with the understanding of what the taxation level would be; that is, we did not determine a retention bonus and then look at the taxation consequences later. In setting the bonus the taxation consequences were looked at, and that bonus was regarded as being at a sufficient level for retention purposes.

SPEECH.PARA: Secondly, the great difficulty with the alternative that Senator McLean is putting up is that if we take the tax out year by year there is no retention bonus any more. Someone can serve one or two years and then just go because there is no incentive to stay. With the retention bonus there is that incentive. Once the taxation arrangements are changed to make it year by year, it is a year by year decision as to whether people stay. We want people to stay through to the 20-year period. For those two reasons the Government opposes the Democrats amendment.

Opposition senators on the front bench carry the same burdens as the Democrat spokesmen. We have to address every piece of legislation, clause by clause, with the resources of backbenchers. Frankly, the argument which Senator Newman is advancing simply is a further distortion of the diatribe that we were subjected to in notices of motion this morning.

SPEECH.PARA: I hope that it will be accepted that it is not always possible for people to attend committees. This debate has the same standing as the debate on these amendments which would have occurred in another place. The fact that it is logistically possible only for me to do it here is something that only I can decide. Senator Newman's comments are irrelevant and misleading and, frankly, border on dishonest representation of the relative positions.

(3) That the committee may proceed to the dispatch of business notwithstanding that all members have not been duly nominated and appointed and notwithstanding any vacancy.
(4) That the committee elect a member nominated by the Leader of the Government as its chairman.

(5) That the Chairman of the Committee may, from time to time, appoint another member of the Committee, who is a non-Government Senator, to be the Deputy-Chairman of the Committee, and that the member so appointed act as Chairman of the Committee at any time when there is no Chairman or the Chairman is not present at a meeting of the Committee.
(6) That, in the event of the votes on any question before the Committee being equally divided, the Chairman, or the Deputy-Chairman when acting as Chairman, have a casting vote.
(7) That the quorum of the Committee be three members.

(8) That the committee have power to send for and examine persons and documents, to move from place to place, to sit in public or in private, notwithstanding any prorogation of the Parliament or dissolution of the House of Representatives, and have leave to report from time to time its proceedings and the evidence taken and such interim recommendations it may deem fit.

(9) That the committee be provided with all necessary staff, facilities and resources and be empowered to appoint persons with specialist knowledge for the purposes of the committee with the approval of the President.
(10) That the committee be empowered to print from day to day such documents and evidence as may be ordered by it, and a daily Hansard be published of such proceedings as take place in public.
upon which Senator Powell had moved by way of amendment:
Paragraph 1: After ``refers the Political Broadcast and Political Disclosures Bill 1991, as proposed to be amended by the Government,'' add ``with the exception of Part 3''.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner Sen J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thought that in the time available to me I would respond to some of the issues that have been raised in this debate by Opposition senators-issues such as free speech, the experience in the United States, certainly the question of the views of the Human Rights Commissioner, and the general issue of disclosure. As I was saying late last night, it is very easy to engender an emotional response from people when the terms `free speech' and `freedom of speech' are invoked. It is a pity this has happened because it is obvious to anyone with an interest in civil liberties that, despite the hypocritical cant and humbug which has been mouthed since the ban on political advertising was first mooted, this fundamental question of freedom of speech warrants very careful consideration in relation to the proposed ban.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not deny that there is a certain infringement on free expression in imposing this ban. However, to my mind, this is not a sufficient argument in itself. The real question is whether any denial of rights is a greater danger than those dangers it would supplant. I believe that the answer to that question is unequivocally no.

The seriousness of the situation that we face in the Australian political process means that we have to limit campaign expenditure and we have to fully disclose that campaign expenditure. I have been sickened by the stream of self-serving invocation of principles of free speech by various self-anointed experts in the media who, I believe, with very little reflection but a great deal of financial self-interest, have mouthed words of moral outrage and cynically used concepts of public interest to advance their own causes. Milton Cockburn, in the Sydney Morning Herald a couple of years ago, put it this way:

Before hearts begin to bleed for the television moguls, it is worth recalling that their main concern is being deprived of the windfall revenues that they have received every three (or fewer) years from election campaigns.
The classic example of this unbridled outrage comes from a so-called editorial by Mr Jeremy Cordeaux of radio station 2GB in Sydney. Mr Cordeaux said this:

Let me have my say before free speech is completely lost in this country, and that's what this gag on election advertising is-it is the most frightening erosion of free speech we have ever seen in Australia.
He asserts that. He does not have any arguments to back up his claim. Presumably we are expected to take it as self-evident that no rational or intellectually tenable argument even has to be put.

There is no suggestion-nor has there ever been any suggestion-that anyone would lose the right to express their political opinion. In fact, I think it is extraordinary that a talkback radio host could make such a claim because it is not unknown for the odd talkback host to cut off their listeners from time to time. I do not think that is unique to Sydney radio; I believe that happens all around this country. I really think the only problem Mr Cordeaux is likely to find is if his capacity to say what he wants is lost, and the only way that could possibly happen is if Mr Cordeaux's ratings become so bad that the management of 2GB decides that he ought not to be on air any longer.

The Opposition has also talked about the experience in the United States. I think it is a very valuable experience to examine, because there the whole system is out of control and there is a corrupting of the processes of government. I do not think anyone would want to see Australia go down that path. In the United States, the cost of electioneering-that is, overwhelmingly for political advertising-is the reason why the highly suspect political action committees were started for fund raising purposes. Campaign costs in the United States are positively frightening by Australian standards. This should give pause to my colleagues here in the Senate because US senators must raise, on average, $10,000 every week for the whole of their six-year term.

I think this insatiable need for money, when combined with the lack of party discipline in voting in both Houses, makes US politicians particularly susceptible to influence buying. Australia has a long way to go before we reach that state. The escalating costs of campaign advertising mean that we need to nip this problem in the bud before it goes any further. Of course, Electoral Commission figures show that television and radio advertising expenditure is by far the most important cost in campaigns; because of that, it clearly ought to be the main target.

I think the Government's objective in this legislation is to make our system more democratic by removing, as far as it is possible to do so, the influence of money. A fellow named Philip Stern wrote a book recently called The Best Congress Money can Buy. In it he wrote this:

Far too often money determines who shall run for office. All too often money determines what messages will be conveyed. Much too often money is a preoccupation or an obsession in the minds of the law makers.
Yet that prime determinant, money, is a poor tool of democracy, for money is indifferent to truth and to justice, since it is essentially unjustly distributed.

In equating electronic political advertising with free speech we are really talking about the notion that spending money equals free speech. As Philip Stern pointed out, that is a fallacy because there is an unequal and unjust distribution of money. To understand this, the best illustration of it is spending on advertising in the 1990 Federal election campaign, when over $15m was spent on broadcast advertising--

TALK.START.PARA: —By whom?

—I will get to that. That accounted for almost half the total expenditure of the party campaigns. The breakdown of the spending-and it is not just the spending of the major parties but also of the so-called third parties; that is, the little people, the groups that the Opposition and the Democrats are so fond of referring to when they talk about the denial of freedom of speech and those who would be most likely to suffer from a ban-is very illuminating. Of the $1.7m expended by third parties on broadcast advertising, $1.1m alone was spent by logging interests, with the Australian Conservation Foundation able to come up with only about $26,000.

SPEECH.PARA: Who else featured prominently in the breakdown? Luxury car dealers and pharmacists who, I suppose, are hardly examples of the poor and the dispossessed in our society. Let me say quite explicitly that it is impossible, given that this sort of money has to be raised, for any major party to avoid going cap-in-hand to the corporate sector in order to fund a modern political campaign. Any number of examples right across the political spectrum graphically demonstrate the dangers in that situation.

There is, in the broader sense, a lessening of the right to free speech. But that is free speech for the few. It is free speech for the wealthy; it is free speech for the powerful; and it is free speech only for the vested interests.

The Opposition has also raised the question of the attitude of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commissioner, Brian Burdekin, on whether this legislation complies with Articles 19(2) and 19(3) of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights to which Australia is a party. Article 19(2) requires parties to guarantee the right of freedom of expression. This right is not absolute, as Article 19(3) makes clear. It provides that the right may be limited in the interests of political order.

The Opposition scorns the advice that the Government has received from the Government's official legal advisers from the Attorney-General's Department that the legislation's aim of preventing political corruption falls within the meaning of Article 19(3), which means that the legislation does not breach the Covenant. All of a sudden it prefers to listen to the view of a man whose job it has vowed to scrap if it wins Government.

To fully understand the expedient and cynical nature of this view the Opposition is espousing, we need listen only to the words of the then shadow Attorney-General, Neil Brown, who was interviewed on the ABC's Law Report after he announced the Liberal Party hatchet job on the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission in October 1989. In reference to the monitoring of Australia's obligations under the international conventions-we have to bear in mind that he was saying this in the context of getting rid of the Commission-he said:

Well I'm quite satisfied that the lawyers of the Attorney-General's Department will exercise their function with true detachment and independence of mind. I think non-lawyers often think that it's impossible for lawyers to do that, but most lawyers realise that it can and is done on a daily basis by lawyers. So, I don't really have any concerns about that . . .
I would be quite happy myself, to have the Department itself and lawyers in the Department, look at our international obligations and whether they are being complied with under these conventions.

I think that Neil Brown himself has answered the case that the Opposition has put forward. Unfortunately, I do not have time today to canvass the nature of political advertisements, to examine what they add to the democratic process and whether they provide information. They distort and trivialise the political process. I believe that they conceal, rather than reveal, genuine information. I think that Phillip Adams said it all when he described them as `about as worth defending as graffiti slogans sprayed on the walls of public buildings or the obscenities scrawled on loos'.

In the short amount of time available to me I would like to turn to the second aspect of the Government's reforms, the full disclosure provisions. I think the hypocrisy of the Opposition really rises to new heights when we look at the disclosure provisions. Make no mistake about it, it does not want full disclosure. It asserts that it is prepared to support full disclosure but it manoeuvres and twists and turns to ensure that in the end it can vote against full disclosure while still maintaining it supports it. That is all to keep its party organisation happy. The Liberal Party secretariat has made it clear that it has always been opposed to disclosure and it always will be.

Why should disclosure be an issue? As we are all aware, the soaring costs of election campaigns have made all parties increasingly dependent on outside donations from corporations and various interest groups. Quite simply, the rationale for full disclosure is that it allows voters to determine for themselves whether an incumbent or a candidate is or will be at the beck and call of the interest groups, corporations or individuals who have helped finance and fund a political campaign. In other words, it protects it against influence peddling, which, in effect, is corruption. The right of the public to know about and to judge the significance of donations outweighs, in my opinion, the right of donors to confidentiality.

All major parties in this country have been guilty at times of exploiting glaring loopholes in the current Federal legislation. Now this Government has taken a stand to close those loopholes and to make disclosure meaningful. The first loophole to be closed is that which allows front organisations to be set up to launder donations and protect the identities of donors. Perhaps the most famous example of that is the National Free Enterprise Foundation which was established to filter about $300,000 to its National Party Queensland candidates, free of public reporting provisions. In the 1990 Federal election we saw Liberal Party sponsored vehicles, such as the Centurion Club and the 200 Club. They were used as similar fronts for private donors.

The other infamous loophole in the current legislation is that it allows donations to parties for non-election or administrative purposes to be exempt from all disclosure provisions. I do not believe that it is valid to make a distinction between election and non-election related activities for political parties. If any validity could be discovered it is outweighed by the opportunities that the current situation provides for manipulation.

The revelations of the Fitzgerald Commission of Inquiry into Possible Illegal Activities and Associated Police Misconduct in Queensland have shown what a joke political finance is and, in particular, the reporting provisions of donations. Judge Roden, Assistant Commissioner for the ICAC investigation into the north coast development in New South Wales, said:
It is beyond question that if politicians or political parties are paid money and then do favours, that is a form of corruption.
He also said:

The alternative to compulsory public disclosure, I believe, is an unacceptable risk that through financial necessity, influence with Government (of any political colour) will be a purchasable commodity.

I think the linkage between all these strands is quite clear. We do need to curtail ever rising campaign expenditure. Electronic advertising forms the major part of that expense. For this reason alone, it ought to be stopped. If we examine the worthless nature of electronic advertising then that certainly adds strength to this argument that there should be a ban on electronic advertising in election campaigns. It is clear that both disclosure and the electronic advertising ban are linked. It is a package that the Government has brought forward. It ought to be dealt with as a package. As the Government has claimed all along, these reforms deserve support. If they do survive the process of the select committee and the processes of the Senate, then I think this will be perhaps the most significant step ever taken in Australia to remove the sleaze factor in Australian politics.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to congratulate Senator Faulkner on an excellent speech. We have heard a truly objective and thorough analysis of what this issue is all about. It stands in marked contrast to the quality of the debate on this issue that we heard in the chamber last night. Indeed, I sought the call last night in order to speak to the people who might have been listening to the debate. We really were subjected to a diatribe of distortion from the Opposition which needed a response from the Australian Democrats. Senator Faulkner has responded on behalf of the Government. On behalf of the Australian Democrats I am responding to the diatribe that we were subjected to last night in anticipation of further diatribe from the Opposition in the debate on this issue this morning.

SPEECH.PARA: It is worth reminding ourselves precisely where we are in this debate. We are actually debating an amendment moved by Senator Powell to the proposition that the Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures Bill be referred to a committee. Senator Powell has suggested from the very beginning of this debate that the two fundamental issues which are rolled into one in this legislation-namely, political advertising and disclosure of political donations-should be separated. The first issue should go to a committee, because it is an issue about which there needs to be much deliberation and much public participation; the second issue, disclosure, should be addressed now. That is the essential thrust of Senator Powell's amendment.

In speaking to the proposed reference to a committee last night, a number of Opposition senators simply distorted the reality incredibly and, most of all, distorted the position taken by the Australian Democrats on this matter. In doing so, there was almost overwhelming evidence of the need for our attention to be drawn to the issue of how politicians present themselves to their constituents. Not only is there distortion through the mechanism of political advertising and failure to disclose the moneys which fund that process, but also there is gross distortion in the debate about whether there needs to be disclosure and whether we need to regulate political advertising. I commend Senator Faulkner for the objective evidence that he contributed to this debate a few minutes ago.

I am not too sure how young I was when I learned one of the most fundamental lessons in life. I know that I was very young when I learned that if people listen to somebody who is prejudiced, biased and bigoted, they find that out of the mouths of the prejudiced, biased and bigoted does not come the truth. On this issue enormous prejudice, bias and bigotry are being expressed by Opposition members. They pretend to be stating the Democrats position.

I put it to the listeners and to the readers of this debate that they would be better to trust their own judgments rather than to trust the judgment of Senator Kemp, Senator Vanstone and Senator Olsen on the Democrats attitude on this issue. I would like to state clearly the fundamental and simple position of the Democrats in relation to this legislation. Senator Parer, who is in the chamber, has vigorously distorted this very important issue over the months of this debate. He has correctly told the constituency that it is an important issue. He has correctly told the constituency that there is certainly a fundamental issue at stake; that is, freedom of speech. I admire that. Of course, it is true. It is self-evident that it is true; but it is also true and self-evident that Senator Parer has grossly distorted our position on this issue.

I would like to state very clearly where we have been on this issue all along. We have said from the very beginning that all is not well in relation to political advertising. If proof is needed that the Democrats have been saying that for some time, honourable senators should go back to the debates of our former leader, Senator Macklin, and they will see that he raised over and over again in this place the question of honesty in political advertising. He referred to the fact that politicians are exempt from the provisions and requirements of the Trade Practices Act which says that if ordinary people advertise any product that they want to promote on the market, they have to do it honestly; yet under the Trade Practices Act politicians are not obliged-there is no obligation in law-to be honest in their political advertising.

Michael Macklin, a former Senator and Democrat leader, has said over and over again in this place-he has brought it to our attention and it has been debated in this chamber-that honesty in political advertising is fundamental to the health of a democracy. We have said that for years. Therefore, when legislation came before us which focused partly on that issue, we embraced it as an opportunity to truly address it honestly, not to distort it.

TALK.START.PARA: —A total ban.

—From the beginning we have said that we blatantly reject the concept of a total ban on political advertising. That is what we have said, and I thank Senator Parer for acknowledging that. We have rejected a total ban on political advertising. Therefore, it follows logically to ask: how does one regulate political advertising that is permitted so that it is honest advertising?
—How dare you decide what should be advertised?

—I have just as much right to dare to make a contribution to this debate as has Senator Walters. Her contribution, as has been so frequently the case in contributions from members of the Opposition, is simply to distort our position. I have the right to clarify our position, and that is exactly what I am doing.

SPEECH.PARA: The clarification is that from the beginning we have rejected the concept of a total ban on political advertising. We have focused upon the issue of honesty in that advertising. We have said that the way to achieve that honesty is through regulation of that advertising. We will only come to grips with the whole problem associated with dishonesty in political advertising if we simultaneously come to grips with disclosure of where political parties get their money to do it. We have always acknowledged that the two issues of honesty in political advertising and disclosure of donations to that process are fundamental and vital. Therefore, in many respects, we welcome the opportunity that is provided by this legislation.

We have been accused of doing deals on this issue. I can tell honourable senators-I am the only one in this chamber who can tell you, Madam Acting Deputy President, having listened to every hour of the debate on this issue in our party room and having listened to most of the debate at the national executive level on this issue-that the Democrats in the party room, at the national executive level and also at the membership level, have taken this to be a serious issue as it is rightly presented. There has never been any deal done.

The Opposition cannot accept that, because we hold the balance of power in this place, we have to negotiate. We have to have an open door and an open mind and we have to listen. Opposition senators have closed doors and closed minds and are determined to maintain the status quo.

TALK.START.PARA: —We do on freedom of speech.

—No. They have closed minds about the status quo. We are the people who hold the balance of power in this place and who have to consider every paragraph and clause of every piece of legislation because of the responsibility we have by virtue of holding the balance of power. The fact that Opposition members have closed minds and closed doors does not give us the privilege of having closed minds and closed doors. We have to speak to Ministers. We have to negotiate amendments which will achieve honesty in political advertising. We have to negotiate amendments directed at disclosure of donations to political parties. We do not have a blind, closed mind approach. Nor can we ever afford to have that if we are to exercise the balance of power responsibly, as we have done for a decade in this place.

SPEECH.PARA: The distortions that we have heard from the Opposition in this debate, directed at our attitude towards the legislation-and we will hear more in the next hour or so-are proof positive that the whole question of political statement is riddled with distortion in this chamber, and absolutely riddled with distortion when projected as political advertising. There is no doubt that all is not well. There is no doubt at all that eventually this issue must be addressed. When it comes back from a committee, perhaps it will be addressed.

What is evident to me and to many who have watched this debate is that the Opposition is slowly but surely achieving its fundamental and primary objective of leaving things exactly as they are. That is because its constituency is the privileged. Its constituency is made up of those who have access to sufficient dollars, whether through political donation or otherwise.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about Bondy?

—What about Bondy? I am not denying that there may well be guilt in this matter in those quarters. I am saying that the Opposition is pursuing the interests of the status quo. It is emotionally drumming up a potential abuse of freedom of speech, which we would be equally concerned about. Along the line, the Opposition has grossly distorted our position on this matter, which has been quite simple: to reject any total ban on political advertising from the beginning; and to pursue two very clear objectives-truth in advertising and disclosure of public donations to political parties. They are two matters which must, in the best interests of our democracy, be addressed.

SPEECH.PARA: The best mechanism to do this is through the regulation of political advertising. We do not believe in the status quo because it does not deliver to the Australian people the processes that are in the best interests of a healthy democracy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate has before it a motion to refer the Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures Bill 1991 to a committee. The Opposition-the Liberal Party and the National Party-supports the reference of this Bill to a committee. I cannot recall a more draconian Bill coming before this chamber in my time. It is draconian for its attacks on democracy and on the foundations of a democratic society and for the consequent abridgment of human rights that comes from that attack on the democratic principles of this society.

SPEECH.PARA: It must go to a committee so that all those people who protested to the Liberal Party and the National Party about the iniquities of that Bill-and they are not party members; they represent the whole spectrum of human activity in Australia-have an opportunity to put their case before the public at large. The only wonderment I have about this Bill is that the public protest has been as muted as it has been. The only conclusion one can come to is that the Government has done a pretty good job on keeping it quiet and that word has not got out as to what is involved in the Bill.

I do not wish to spend time talking about the Democrats claim that the Liberal Party is pursuing the status quo. Nothing could be further from the truth. We are always interested in preserving democracy. We are not interested in preserving inequities or injustices in society. Our whole history in this country, ever since Federation, has shown that the parties on the Liberal side and the anti-Labor side have been at the forefront of the protection and the advancement of democratic principles. That is what we are on about in opposing this Bill.

This Bill has two parts to it: firstly, a ban on political advertising in the electronic media, both in radio and in television; and, secondly, a disclosure of donations- but a disclosure in a bizarre and perverted way. We have every objection to a ban on political advertising in the electronic media because it is grossly unfair. It is a debasement of the human rights of an individual in Australian society to put his views forward and to be heard, and it gives a great advantage to the government of the day.

There is not a Prime Minister who will not be guaranteed through an election campaign adequate time to express a point of view on a television or radio station. There is no way the ministry-people like Senator Richardson-will not get a run on the electronic media. People with a contrary point of view will be denied that opportunity.

With respect to the disclosure of political donations, we are happy to have full, free and equitable disclosure. We are not happy to have the bully boys from the labour movement come along to stand over some private individual because he gives $100,000 to the Liberal Party and bludgeon him with the intimidation tactics that have been so much a consequence of disclosure when the Australian Labor Party has known about it. We are not prepared to sit back and see tens of millions of dollars come out of union funds-and who knows what out of the superannuation funds that the unions will have in the future-and go into Labor Party slush funds. But I shall deal with that later.

Firstly, I want to deal with the comments that have been made by apolitical bodies within Australia. The first comment I refer to is that of the Law Council, a body of absolutely no political affiliation. It said that this Bill is so badly drafted that one cannot determine what is in it. There have been protests from the Australian Medical Association. The Media Council of Australia said that it is incredulous over the wide ranging applications and ramifications of this Bill and it cannot understand why people are not marching in the streets. APEA, the Automobile Association of Australia and the Real Estate Institute have protested against it. The Press Council considers the legislation to be unconstitutional.

Yesterday the Salvation Army wrote to me. One of the very interesting points that the Salvation Army raised is that, where literacy is a real factor in the Australian community, illiterate people gain a great deal of their information on society through what they hear. They hear and they see through the electronic medium, not through the print medium. Those people will be denied the opportunity of exposure to political viewpoints from people within the country.

Yesterday I received a letter from the Australian Parents Council. It made the point that our affairs will be at huge risk because the responsibility for the determination of what the public hears will be placed on current affairs programmers and reporters. We know how much most of those people love the Labor Party and fail to reflect the opinions in this place of people who are not members of the Labor Party.

So the list goes on: the Confederation of Australian Industry; the National Farmers Federation; the Mining Industry Council; the Forest Industries Association; ACROD; the Australian Chamber of Manufactures; the Brotherhood of St Laurence; the National Federation of Blind Citizens; the Council of Civil Liberties-even the Australian Conservation Foundation, which one could be forgiven for thinking at times is an arm of the Democrats or the Labor Party have all protested about the basic breach of democratic principles in this Bill.

Not only will political parties be denied the right to put their point of view in the form of paid advertisements before the Australian electorate through election campaigns, but anyone in the community who has an interest in projecting some viewpoint before the community will be denied the opportunity of doing so because it will be deemed that that point of view will be likely to influence the outcome of the election in one way or another. Any groups which are critical of the Government, the way that welfare groups are constantly asking for increased funding, will be unable to ask for more funds for the blind or for the disabled or any other welfare service in the community because it will be deemed that their claims are political advertising and they will be banned under the Act. Even the current affairs programs are suspect because the Labor Party will only have to claim that a current affairs program may have influenced the outcome of a future election for it to be banned.

The fundamental point is that the right of free speech, the very basis of the democratic system of the Government of Australia, is being eroded and severely curtailed by this denial of free speech. That is a characteristic, of course, of all totalitarian regimes. While this Government is not a totalitarian regime, it certainly exhibits some of the tendencies of one. The Government is obviously desperately trying to retain power. Under its guidance we have seen the collapse of the Australian economy and Australian society.

We are involved in the second great depression of this century. Let me remind the Senate that the first Great Depression of this century occurred under the Scullin Labor Government of the early 1930s. Today in Australia we have 700,000 unemployed, plus hundreds of thousands who have given up putting their names on unemployment lists out of total despair that they will ever get a job. We have 28.5 per cent of teenagers unemployed-an absolutely staggering figure. It is the highest total we have had since the Great Depression. Of the people who should be entering the work force to be trained and contributing to the future growth of this country, 28.5 per cent are unemployed.

I spend a fair bit of my time talking to university graduates. The one characteristic of university graduates now is despair. That is probably the most telling criticism of this Government. When one talks to people aged 28 or 30 who have worked their way through a university career-most of them have jobs but a number of them do not-about how they see Australia, instead of being full of zest, drive and enthusiasm for the careers that are before them, for the community they live in and for the country they are resident in, all one finds is the comment that we are now a Third World country. I find that absolutely terrible. I never had that view when I was a graduate. I was proud to live in this country, I was proud to contribute to the society and I was eager to make my contribution in my own profession. But today, if one asks lawyers, doctors, dentists and engineers how they see the future, all one hears is despair. I think that is a terrible criticism.

We have falling standards of living, the collapse of the Australian manufacturing industry, and an uncontrollable balance of payments position where the $30 billion debt that existed when this Government came into power has blown out to $130 billion. Why in those circumstances would the Government-particularly when it has no commitment to democratic principles-not move to curtail any challenge to its retention of power? That is what this is all about: the retention of power. It is not about fairness in elections, disclosure or anything else; it is merely about the pursuit of power through any means.

No Government, no party and no parliamentarian with any comprehension, let alone any regard or respect for the democratic system, would contemplate the legislation that is before us today. I am not surprised that the Labor Party has brought it up, but I am surprised that the Democrats have played footsy with it for so long because the issues are black and white. If one understands what democracy is about, one cannot support this ban on advertising.

The only reason the Democrats have changed their position at the present time is that the current leader pro tem is under challenge. Something like 100 of her supporters or members of the Party-probably 70 per cent of the Party-have written in and said, `Hey, the leadership is on the line. We do not agree with you'. One of the really tragic things that this has exposed has been the collapse of the Democrats. We now have a Party which has gone downhill ever since its founder, Don Chipp, left it. We had the nasty machinations whereby Senator Haines, as she then was, completely got rid of the successor to Senator Chipp, Senator Siddons. From that point the Party started to lose credibility, but the real collapse has come under the present leadership of Senator Powell. I look forward very much to whoever her successor might be because it will be an improvement. The Australian Democrats which once had some principles--

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the Liberal Party? You have lost four elections in a row. You are the ones who have collapsed.

—Senator Richardson might not have agreed with the principles of the Democrats, and I certainly did not agree with them on a lot of things, but under former Senator Chipp they had some principles, they had a coherent policy and they had some integrity. They have lost all those under the present leadership and they have become a party of opportunistic scavengers around the parliamentary refuse heap. They are into any sort of issue where they think they can pick up 100 votes. They have no political philosophy at all and they have no concept of democracy. If this legislation goes through we will be well down the road to a one-party state. That will be the consequence of it. This side of the Parliament, the Liberal and the National parties, will oppose with all the vigour we have in our possession this ban on political advertising because of its basic abridgment of our human rights, our democratic principles and our freedom of expression.

SPEECH.PARA: The second part of the Bill deals with donations. We favour frank, full and open disclosure of donations but, as I said in the opening part of my speech, we are not going to be part of the formula proposed by the Labor Party whereby it can raise tens of millions of dollars from the union movement without the consent or approval of the unionists who have their fees compulsorily levied from them, and we are not going to expose people who make contributions to any party to the risk of intimidation by the bully boys of the union movement. That is a reality; that is one of the real things in the world today.

I did not have any intention of speaking at length on the donations side because I think the case is so clear that it is transparent.
