But one of the previous speakers, a senator from the union movement in New South Wales, made some quite sanctimonious statements about where the Liberal Party might have got its funds from and that provoked me to go to my files and get the submissions for the Labor Party for the 1987 election by one Robert Francis McMullan, who was then the General Secretary. I find this a very interesting document. It did not fall off the back of a truck; it is a public document that one can obtain. We find that in the period preceding the 1987 election the total value of all gifts received by the ALP Federal Secretariat in Canberra was $2,981,062. When we go through the list we find some great surprises. There is a long list of six or seven pages of donations from organisations such as the Australian Workers Union of $25,000; from the AMWU national council political fund account, $100,000; and from the Operative Painters and Decorators Union of Australia, $3,500.

TALK.START.PARA: —All tax-free.

—Yes. As Senator Parer correctly says, these donations are all tax-free. We find the Federated Coal Storage and Meat Preserving Employees Union of Australasia with $2,000; the Building Workers Industrial Union of Australia, $20,000; the Shop Distributive and Allied Employees Association, $50,000; the Federated Miscellaneous Workers Union of Australia, $55,000.

SPEECH.PARA: I am glad the honourable senator who made those outrageous claims is back. The chickens have come home to roost.

TALK.START.PARA: —What?

— I am glad the honourable senator raised this matter and provoked my memory to send me back to look at my files. I have never raised funds for a political party, but I would imagine it is rather hard to find donations of $55,000, as we have here in 1987 from the Federated Miscellaneous Workers Union of Australia. We have these pages and pages of donations at around the $50,000 to $100,000 mark, building up into millions, out of the union movement. No other party can garnishee the profits or the takings of the union movement the way the Labor Party can, and that is the system it wants to enshrine through legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: When we go through the pages of this document-and remember I said it was about $2.9m-we come to the final entry and we find there is a body called the ALP Legacies and Gifts Ltd, 22 Brisbane Avenue, Barton, ACT. This would have to be the grandaddy of all slush funds. I would like the said Robert Francis McMullan, since he is now a senator, to explain to the Senate some time just what the ALP Legacies and Gifts Ltd is, because out of a total contribution of $2.9m we find that nearly $2m comes from the ALP Legacies and Gifts Ltd.

Senator Harradine, with his great experience of the Labor Party, is smiling. He knows, the way I know, that it is the old mates who contributed to that. That would be TNT, that would be News Ltd, that would be Bondy, that would be all sorts of old mates who are up for dinner at the Lodge every time they are in town.

This leads to the whole reason for the legislation coming before the Senate. Look at the balance sheets today: where is TNT, where is News Ltd, where is Bondy, where is Skase? He has fled the country. All the old mates are in trouble. So $2m out of $2.9m from this slush fund is no longer there. Their idea of a level playing field, since their income has declined, is to bring in this declaration of full disclosure, to preserve their vested interest within the fundraising world.

In addition, before I leave the ALP fundraising, I might say that what I read out there related to the Federal Secretariat. It must be remembered that the State secretariats also had contributions from unions. I have the figures for the same election from the Queensland Secretariat. We find there that the Seamen's Union of Australia kicked in $10,506, the Australian Workers Union $18,450, the Queensland Colliery Employees Union $8,690, and so on. They were getting it on all sides.

In conclusion, this legislation is a blatant attack on the democratic principles on which this society was founded and on which our government is based. It takes us down the first step to a one-party state. It has all the hallmarks of a totalitarian regime, and it must be opposed right at the outset. The denial of funding, the denial of advertising, are potent weapons in the hands of the government of the day and have no part in a democratic society.

I say this with the greatest of respect: it is the first step to a one-party state, and the next step will be the elimination of all elections. I can remember a leader of another socialist party, in the 1930s, who made that part of his policy. In 1933 or 1934 he said that the next election will be the last one.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today we are debating the referral of the Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures Bill 1991 to a select committee. This, of course, is welcomed very much by the Opposition-the Liberal and National parties-even though it has taken an inordinate amount of time, yet again, for the Australian Democrats to wake up that this was a necessary course of action, that this was such a complicated piece of legislation, and a piece of legislation that had disastrous consequences for the nation.

SPEECH.PARA: In the last week or so we have seen Senator Powell, the temporary Leader of the Australian Democrats, in an effort to shore up her leadership, suddenly coming up with the idea as though it was something new and revolutionary that we can send the Bill off to a committee. `That seems a good idea', she said, `so I am going to recommend that we send it off to a committee'. At the end of the last session she refused point blank to send this Bill off to a committee and now she is considering it something revolutionary, the same way in which Senator McLean was talking a little while ago. Needless to say, with Senator Spindler wandering around the chamber from time to time, he is probably going to say the same thing.

The matter we are talking about is a clear example that the Hawke-Keating-Kerin Government's days are numbered-thank heavens-because, on top of the economic disasters that it has set upon this country, we have this hopeless Minister for Administrative Services (Senator Bolkus) who is absolutely unable to acknowledge that to gag free speech in Australia is simply not on. People from all sections of the community-as my colleague Senator MacGibbon has just outlined-have protested very angrily and for long enough now for the Government to at last recognise that it is not just the Liberal and National parties that value free speech; it is also valued by many people in the community. Look at how many people have actually set about signing petitions to this Parliament to express their desire not to have free speech wiped out by this Government.

The Minister has had more positions on this Bill than the Kama Sutra, I will go so far as to say, but his second last position to date was to prohibit advertising during election campaigns. Was that not a smart idea? `We will advertise as a Government all the way along the line, and we will advertise in government departments right up to an election campaign, we will tell you what a wonderful job we have done and what a wonderful job we are going to do in the future, yet no-one else will be able to tell the Australian community what they are going to do.

TALK.START.PARA: —Only they know when the election campaign will be.

—That is exactly right. Only the Government will know when the election campaign is going to be so that it can manipulate the system. What is it that the Minister is afraid of? Is it that his wealthy mates have all gone bust, or are living the high life in Spain? Is it that the party is simply broke, both of money and ideas? Is it that the Minister recognises that the Hawke-Keating-Kerin Government is so on the nose that it could not be sold in a chook raffle? Is it that they cannot figure out a way to tell the people of Australia that unprecedented high levels of unemployment and losing their jobs is good for them? Is it that they have not yet figured out a way to paint some pretty pictures that record bankruptcies is a real hoot and also good for the Australian people? Or is it that the Minister-simply no more, no less-wishes to impede political communication in a democracy, because it seemed like a good idea at the time?

SPEECH.PARA: I honestly think that maybe it is a combination of all of those things, but the latter is probably more close to the point than anything else, because the Minister has acted so illogically over all of this. He has not been able to explain to the Parliament, or the public, why he has set about this course of action, but of course the other part of the Bill-to disclose political donations-is just an amazing position by this Minister as well.

Yesterday the Minister in his speech on this referral motion mentioned that the Leader of the Opposition, Dr Hewson, had supported the other aspect of the Bill to which I just referred-stopping advertising. The Minister at no stage gave any explanation as to why he made that statement, yet he is talking about truth in advertising.
I digressed there for a moment. Coming back to disclosure, the party that has really had the problem with disclosure over recent years is not the coalition-it happens to be the Labor Party.

TALK.START.PARA: —How do you figure that out?

—Senator Richardson asks me how I figure that out. It is his mate, Senator Loosley, who decided, `Woops, I forgot to declare some things. I forgot to declare some donations. Oh dear, oh dear'. It is now his mate, Bob Hogg--
—What did the courts say? Has the court overruled you or are you better than the court?
—No, the court has agreed that he forgot to declare the donations.
—Get it exactly right.

—The Minister should not try to say that Senator Loosley, in his previous incarnation as Secretary to the Labor Party in New South Wales, failed to declare donations according to the Government's legislation. That is what he did. Now we have Mr Hogg, the Labor Party's national Secretary, or whatever he is called, also saying, `Woops, I forgot to do it as well'.
—No, `I misunderstood'.

—`I misunderstood. Oh dear, oh dear'. This is the Minister's legislation, this is his Party, and it is his people who say, `Woops, I forgot to declare it'. Then there is Mr Burke over in Perth, Western Australia, who forgot to declare a whole lot of things. There is Mr Parker, who simply put the money in his briefcase in his office. Mr Burke set up advertising account No. 1, advertising account No. 2 and advertising account No. 3.
—What about stamps?

—Then, of course, we have stamps. The advertising accounts were very interesting because they allowed the Labor Party to ask companies to donate to the Labor Party but, instead of writing out cheques to the Australian Labor Party, they wrote them out to advertising account No. 1, advertising account No. 2 or advertising account No. 23, 24 or 25. Not only did the Labor Party not declare those as donations, but also the companies which donated them claimed them as a tax deduction.

SPEECH.PARA: Here is the Party that is saying, `Oh, we've got to be honest. We've got to declare all our donations'. It has rorted the system blind in Western Australia. Mr Parker has now decided-only due to the Royal Commission into Commercial Activities of Government and Other Matters-that he has to disclose all the money that he has kept in a briefcase. It has also been exposed in the Royal Commission that he used the money that was given to him for his re-election campaign to put a cash deposit on his private home.

Of course, there is Mr Dowding, Mr Grill and, naturally enough, the now Senator Beahan who was State Secretary of the Australian Labor Party at the time and who aided and abetted in advertising accounts No. 1, No. 2 and No. 3. He knew that the money was going into these fake accounts so that the Labor Party did not have to declare them and that the companies which donated could, in fact, claim a tax deduction illegally. So everyone else had to pay more tax, but the companies which donated to the Labor Party got a plus-a benefit.

Senator McMullan, now Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer, was Federal Secretary-or whatever it is called-of the Labor Party at the time. He was fully aware of all of these advertising accounts but, oh, no, we now have to have stronger legislation for declaration of donations. It is your legislation that you have already blown out of the water, and you expect to now stand on some platform and say, `We are pure; we are honest; we are innocent'.

Royal commissions around this country, and particularly in my State of Western Australia, are showing exactly the reverse, so do not come the sanctimonious claptrap with me or with the Senate because we will not tolerate your attitude and your previous manipulation of political donations. It is on the public record how you have done it and, needless to say, you will continue to do it in the future.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Knowles, every time you say `you', you are really referring to me.
—I am very sorry, Mr Deputy President. I would not dare do that to you.
—Perhaps you might address your remarks through the Chair.
—I will certainly do that, Mr Deputy President. I apologise personally to you. I would not be so bold, but I have been baited by Senator Richardson and Senator Faulkner on the other side.
—I think you might be right.

—I was keen to respond. Sending this Bill off to a committee will, at best and at least, demonstrate that the intention of the Bill and the Minister is a formal breach of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, which Australia loudly professes to uphold in the international arena. Following the collapse of outright totalitarianism and dictatorship in so much of the world it has, however, become apparent that not all supposed democracies can be described as liberal in upholding free speech and strong independent institutions.

SPEECH.PARA: The Hawke-Kerin Government must be condemned for its attempt to diminish liberal democracy in Australia, and I am only too pleased to support the position that my colleagues Senator Parer and Senator Olsen, and the Opposition generally, have put for many months now, and that is to have this Bill properly scrutinised at a committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let it be put on the table.
—Let it be put on the table, as Senator Parer says, and allow the community to have its say on whether or not it wants free speech.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —The motion before the Senate is to refer the Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures Bill to a select committee of the Senate. That motion commences with the words, `noting the findings of Report No. 4 of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters'. I was a member of that Joint Standing Committee and I have been through this backwards, forwards and out the other end. I am fully aware of the detailed consideration that that Committee gave to this whole question.

SPEECH.PARA: I might mention at the outset that, had the Government followed the recommendations of that Committee, it would have come up with a Bill which would be far more acceptable than the Bill which it has before the chamber at the present moment. I might mention, however, that I did write a dissent report to certain of the recommendations of that Committee. I do not want to canvass those here in the chamber because they are contained on page 135 of the report of that Joint Select Committee, entitled Who pays the piper calls the tune.

I want to say a couple of things very briefly about this referral. I think it is important that this Bill be referred to a select committee because it raises a number of questions. Certainly, the public is sick and tired of the slick political image makers during election campaigns. The image makers and the minders of the political parties and political leaders will simply divert the money saved by this Bill to slick advertisements in the print media, magazines, video trailers, direct mail and junk mail and to costly inserts into daily newspapers, et cetera. There is no guarantee that the alleged primary purpose of this measure will be satisfied, that is, to remove the perceived inordinate reliance of political parties on money from the political process in Australia.

Besides expenditure in areas other than television advertising, the political parties will be able to pour money into the production of lavish campaign launches, with all the accompanying razzamatazz, which under this Bill the ABC and the commercial television stations will be required to carry. Together with current affairs programs, whose agendas are set by producers and the political minders of party leaders, and the 10-second news grabs, glib campaign launches will be the only political messages received by television viewers and radio listeners.

If the views of community groups or individuals on policy issues do not happen to coincide with or are not considered important by political image makers or producers of talkback and current affairs programs, these community groups and citizens in general will be prevented by law from airing their views over television and radio. This is the bone of contention amongst a number of community groups which have written to honourable senators concerned about this question.

Voters who rely on the electronic media for information are entitled to know where political parties and candidates stand on issues of concern and why they take that stand. It can be argued that this right has been sullied in recent political campaigns by the dominance of the glib image making television political advertisements inflicted on viewers by the political parties.

However, there are ways to reverse this costly dominance without resorting to decisions which attack civil and political rights. This is a matter which, of course, the proposed committee will have to consider. It is a very important aspect to which reference was made in Report No. 4 of the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Matters entitled Who pays the piper calls the tune. I wish the proposed committee well in considering that matter, because it must be considered.

It is a disconcerting feature-which may be tending towards a dangerous feature-of our political process that election campaigns are becoming so costly that they are way out of the reasonable range of political parties reliant on their members for financial support. Perhaps the committee which will be set up could consider the question of ceilings being placed on expenditure by political parties during political campaigns. It might also consider the extension of free political broadcasts which should be of such duration and format as to ensure that political parties and candidates deal with elections as serious topics for debate, rather than as subjects for a shampoo commercial or the like.

There are other aspects of this Bill which might have resulted in a High Court challenge to any adverse election results by persons such as me or others in my situation. Depending upon what is meant by the term political party in an election and depending on what is meant by the party's chief executive officer, there could have been only two or three people in this existing Parliament who would have been denied the right to explain to the voters who rely on television and radio for information where they stand on issues.

So far as I can see, there is no definition of the party's chief executive officer in the legislation, and so far as I am aware there is no such definition in the principal Act. I am fairly familiar with the legislation because I am a member of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters. Depending on the definitions of those particular terms, the Government could have very quickly ended up in the High Court with a constitutional challenge to aspects of this legislation.

Finally, I want to deal very briefly with this question of disclosure. I agree that there should be full, equitable disclosure provisions. I make one comment here: it is unwise and unfair to pre-judge what might emerge out of commissions of inquiry which are currently proceeding.

I also make the observation that a number of people believed that at least one person was acting, according to his lights, in the best interests of a political party. That person has been left carrying the bag, and there is no money in it. The Minister for Social Security, Senator Richardson, who was previously in the chamber, might know what I am talking about. I am talking about the shuttle service between Sydney and Perth. It seems unfortunate that a particular person has been left carrying the bag. That person perceived that he was doing the right thing, but there was no money in that bag.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —There have been very few occasions in the history of this country when a government has attempted to remove the freedoms that our citizens claim as their right. Each time this has occurred in the past the people have risen to the occasion and forced the Government to back down. They have not just relied on the Opposition of the day, but have taken action themselves to bring about that change.

SPEECH.PARA: Once again the people have risen to the occasion. We well remember the previous occasions because this Government, of all governments since Federation, has attempted to curtail the freedoms of its people. Let us look back at the Australia Card and how the people reacted to that. There were public meetings, marches in the streets and, finally, the Government was forced to drop it. We then come to the so-called Bill of Rights and what the Australian people did on that occasion. Again there were public meetings, marches, and the Government finally backed down.

Now we are on the same old issue-the banning of all political advertising. This is not just in the lead-up to an election, but it is for all time. These three attempts to do away with the rights of ordinary Australians are a clear demonstration to me of the true Labor Party. Its philosophy is that the people are subservient to the state because the state knows best what is good for the people. Our philosophy is that the state is subservient to the people, that the people know best what is to their good.

Senator Bolkus, in attempting to tell the people of Australia that the Government will not permit them to criticise any political party through placing advertisements on radio or television has, once again, forced the Government virtually to throw out the legislation. Who does Senator Bolkus think he is? Who do members of the Labor Party think they are? They say to the Australian people, `We will not tolerate any criticism by the people of Australia of anything we have done or of anything that we intend to do. We will not put up with it. We will not allow you to place any advertisement on television or radio which is critical of us'. That is not applicable only to the Liberal Party, the National Party and the Democrats, but to everyone else in Australia. They will not tolerate it. That does not just apply to the Federal Government. The Australian Labor Party has also tried to enforce this in the States. It has said, `We already own the majority of States and we will not tolerate any criticism of those States'. It also applies to local government.

As an Australian, I have been extremely proud that in the past, according to a survey put out by Freedom House, entitled Freedom in the World, Australia has been one of 28 countries, out of 167, which have as top priorities freedom of political rights, civil liberties and general freedoms. Even countries such as France and Greece do not reach our high standard. We are referred to as having complete freedom and basic rights, freedom of speech in the media, in religion, in movement and in association, et cetera. If this legislation ever gets through that will no longer be the case. We will go out of that select group of countries and back to the types of countries which have less freedom. It would degrade our description in that survey.

We have repeatedly asked Senator Bolkus what he is afraid of. Why does he want to throw out the advertisements the people of Australia might put up? He says that rorts and corruption could result. We know that there has been no corruption on our side. What corruption has occurred in the Labor Party that Senator Bolkus is so frightened of? We on this side have no fears.

I can tell honourable senators what Senator Bolkus is frightened of. He is frightened that at the next election the Government will lose power. He is determined to hang on to power at any cost, even at the cost of taking freedoms from the country. He is frightened that the Brotherhood of St Laurence will accuse the Government of breaking promises. We all remember the promise made by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) that no child would be living in poverty after 1990. Yet there are so many extra homeless children on the streets at the moment.

Senator Bolkus is frightened that St Vincent de Paul might accuse the Government of not doing enough for the poor, that it might say, `We need more money as we are treating so many more poor people', and that it might advertise on television and on the radio for people to help because the Government is not doing enough. Senator Bolkus is frightened that, as an Opposition, we might remind the people at the next election that the Prime Minister publicly admitted he had told a lie at the last election. He said that if he had not told the lie the Government would have lost the election. He is frightened that we might remind the people that they can no longer trust the Prime Minister to tell the truth.

Senator Bolkus is frightened that Commissioner Burdekin, who reported on homeless youth, might accuse the Government of not taking up his recommendations on how to overcome the problem. He is frightened that the Opposition will remind the people of all the shenanigans that Brian Burke has been up to and of all the corruption that has occurred in Western Australia. He is frightened that we might remind the people, through a little advertisement of a rowing boat with Mr Hawke and all his mates almost foundering, of his promises on the gold tax.

Senator Bolkus is frightened that we might refer to Mrs Kirner and Mr Cain, and that we might remind the Victorian people of the problems and the corruption that have occurred in that State. He is frightened that we might remind the people in South Australia about their banking problems. This is what Senator Bolkus is frightened about. He is frightened that we might say to the people of Australia, `This is the unemployment rate that this Government has brought to the people'. He is frightened that we will say, `Of course, that rate is ever so much greater because the Government has hidden the figures', and tell people that the Bureau of Statistics figures show only people who say they have not done any work in the previous week or month.

If the Bureau of Statistics asks people whether they have done any work and they say, `Yes, I went out and helped a mate construct a fence', they are still entitled to unemployment benefits, but they are not classed as unemployed for the statistics of the Bureau of Statistics. Even if they were not paid for the hour's work that they did in a week, if they said they had done anything for an hour, remuneration or not, they were not classed in the Bureau of Statistics figures. Imagine what the true rate is! Even the Bureau of Statistics says that it is well over one million people. This is the sort of thing that Senator Bolkus is frightened of.

He is also frightened that, come an election, the Opposition will remind the people of Australia that this Government has seen the largest number of bankruptcies in Australia's history. I remind people of a claim made by the Prime Minister a few years ago. He said:
. . . let me make one point so that even our opponents can understand it; and let me make it beyond all their powers of misrepresentation and distortion. There will be no capital gains tax.

What do we have? A capital gains tax. Who could trust the Prime Minister? Of course, Senator Bolkus is frightened that we will be saying this to the people of Australia with advertisements on television and radio. He is frightened that we will remind them that on 22 March 1990 Mr Keating said, `We won't let there be a recession', yet on 29 November Mr Keating said:
And the first thing to say is the accounts do show that Australia is in a recession. The most important thing about that is that this is a recession that Australia had to have.
These are the sorts of things about which we have Senator Bolkus so worried that he is willing to bring in this type of legislation.

He is also worried that, when we are putting forward our goods and services tax, Dr Hewson may quote Mr Keating and Mr Hawke when they were saying in 1985 what a wonderful idea it was. He is also worried that we might start quoting the fact that Bob Hogg admitted he made a mistake on donations of $400,000; that Senator Loosley forgot to account for some donations; and that Senator McMullan, when he was national Secretary of the Australian Labor Party, also had such problems.

I am glad to see Senator Tate in the chamber, because he was closely associated with the original disclosure legislation in 1987, and he knows that we know that he is aware of where Senator McMullan's skeletons are buried.

TALK.START.PARA: —And Senator Beahan's.

—As Senator Knowles says, let us not stop at Bob Hogg, Senator Loosley, when he was New South Wales ALP Secretary, and Senator McMullan, national Secretary. What about Senator Beahan? Let us stir the lot. These are the things that not only Senator Bolkus but also Senator Tate and all the others are terrified about, because people are handing things to us and we are getting to the bottom of the problems that they have had. Senator Bolkus is trying to stop us from bringing them to the attention of the Australian people.

SPEECH.PARA: I reiterate that, according to this legislation for advertising, not only the Opposition but any other individual in Australia is stopped on any matter intended or likely-even if the intention is not there-to affect the voting at a Commonwealth, State or local government election. Let us be perfectly clear. From the moment the Bill is passed it will be the case that, not only in the lead-up to an election but for the whole time, no Australian will be able to advertise and express his or her view criticising a government-not only a government but also any individual member or any branch. We could not advertise and criticise the right wing of the New South Wales Labor Party for its branch shenanigans, nor could any person in Victoria or New South Wales. That would be illegal-all wiped out. What lengths this Government will go to in its effort to wipe out any criticism of its actions!

Until Senator Powell said yesterday in her speech that the Democrats had never supported the complete ban on political advertising, I was not going to mention the Democrats. I would like to read from Hansard, because this morning Senator McLean said that we had distorted the Democrats' comments and views. Hansard does not lie, so I will read from it. On 20 June, regarding political advertising, Senator Powell said:

Our priority is amendments which we have had before this place previously-most recently in May last year via former Senator Macklin-to introduce truth in advertising. At the moment, the Electoral Act is a licence to lie. We will put those amendments forward.

We have also announced publicly that we want to regulate in the area of advertising to insist that political advertisements are informative and not just ad agency hype, which not only gobbles up money but also does not give any information to the voters. Our amendments will require a talking heads process. We will get those amendments before the political parties, the public and the people who have written to us, and we will discuss them and make comment.

Senator Powell said that the Australian Democrats were not against political advertising, but she was going to tell the people just how they would put that advertisement across. She is as much against political advertising as the Labor Party is, for the same reasons. The Democrats believe that the people are subservient to the state.

It seems to me that the people have already made their views very clear. I do not know which group finally broke the camel's back, but I will read out the names of a few of the groups which have objected very strongly to this legislation: the Australian Petroleum Exporters Association, the Real Estate Institute, the Press Council, the Salvation Army, ACROD, the Law Council of Australia, the Australian Conservation Foundation, the National Federation of Blind Citizens, the Council of Civil Liberties, the Australian Chamber of Manufactures, the AMA, the Australian Parents Council, the Human Rights Commissioner, St Vincent de Paul, the Media Council of Australia, the Business Council of Australia, the Automobile Association of Australia, the advertising and broadcasting industries, the Vice-chancellor of the University of the Northern Territory, the Confederation of Australian Industry, Roy Morgan of Morgan Research, the Australian Council of Social Service, the National Farmers Federation, the Forest Industries Association, the head of the Journalism Department at the Queensland University, the Australian Mining Industry Council, and the Australian Free Enterprise Foundation.

Going through that list, I would say that very few groups in Australia have not objected. It is a travesty to say that people are sick of advertisements at election time. People may well be-and I do not blame them-but they can turn off their televisions or put them on mute and go to make a cup of coffee. I cannot believe that Senator Schacht would agree that the alternative is not to allow people to express any view the Government does not like. It is such a travesty of freedom of speech. It is such a dreadful alternative that I do not know how Senator Tate could be party to it. I do not understand how he can face his electors and say, `I will not allow political advertising. I will forbid it and I will penalise any Australian who dares to place an advertisement criticising me, my branch and my political party or anyone else's'. I cannot believe that even Senator Tate would be party to that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen C.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —After hearing Senator Walters's remarks, I think she is trying to find a new definition of free speech. Senator Faulkner earlier today made some very pertinent points about the question of free speech. We all support free speech, but we do not support it if it means that someone can go out in the streets or to a public meeting and make false remarks about someone else's character. That is a limitation on absolute free speech. We all think that is the civilised way in which a society should conduct itself. There are limits on free speech in all democratic countries. Those limitations have been accepted as the only way in which a mature and sophisticated society can operate. When people start shouting about the need for free speech in absolute terms, they forget that even in this country there is no absolute free speech. We all accept that there have to be limitations. I believe that in this context it is not unreasonable to say that free speech should not be dependent upon one's ability to raise large amounts of money to pay for access to television and radio advertising.

SPEECH.PARA: An overwhelmingly large number of those organisations whose names Senator Walters read out are organisations that have access to large amounts of money. She did not read out a long list of organisations at the very base of the community-for example, the play group associations and the pensioners groups at a very local level-which have political views and views about issues in society but have no access to the hundreds of thousands of dollars that are needed to pay for television and radio advertising. Her list was overwhelmingly the list of organisations that have the ability to raise the hundreds of thousands, if not millions, of dollars needed to pay for an effective television and radio campaign.

Figures have been published which show that in the last Federal election campaign the Forest Industries Association spent over $1m in advertising its view. The Australian Conservation Foundation spent $80,000. But, overwhelmingly, many other conservation groups in the community at a local grassroots level could not raise even the $80,000 that the ACF could to put some advertisements on. Overwhelmingly, Senator Walters in her list has indicated whom she really supports and who supports her and her political party. It is those vested groups that are able to raise the large amounts of money to dominate the political process. Her concept of free speech is free speech based on the power of money. Under no definition is that democratic. If we want a democratic society, it should be based on the right of all people to have equal and appropriate access to having their views heard and not on the ability to raise large amounts of money.

Some speakers from the other side have mentioned that the Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures Bill is in contravention of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights. That is one opinion given by some experts. Other experts give a different view. What I find extraordinary about the statements of the experts who say it is in contravention of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights is that that means that practically every other Western democracy is also in breach, in one form or another, of that Covenant, because most other Western countries have some form of limitation on political advertising on television and radio. I do not see people in those countries going to the International Court or the United Nations claiming that, for example, Sweden and Germany are in breach of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights because they ban paid television and radio advertising. If it is such a serious breach, I would have thought that people in those other Western democracies would be taking those cases up. They have not, because they know that on balance their democracy works better if the power of money to buy television and radio advertising is limited.

Senator Faulkner's remarks today about the definition of free speech are very pertinent and I support them. We still have laws in some States that deal with blasphemy. People cannot get up and make blasphemous remarks while claiming the right to free speech, because there are laws that limit it.

We cannot make remarks about the state in some areas because it can be sedition. Society has always placed limits on free speech. There is always an argument-quite rightly-about what those limits are; that is part of the healthy debate of democracy. But never let it be said that this country has unfettered free speech. We have never had it. None of us have ever supported it because we believe that unfettered free speech may in fact do more damage to individuals than good. I support those limitations. So for Senator Walters and others opposite to claim great moral virtue about free speech is absolute humbug, and they know it.

The conservative parties over the last 100 years in this country and elsewhere have been much more willing to take action against people on free speech and to curtail people's rights than have been the parties of the Left, such as the Labor Party. We have always been much more to the forefront in defending the rights of dissenters to argue against society. We are absolutely consistent because those opposite are the people who represent big money. They are the people who represent wealth. They want that wealth to have unfettered right to dominate the political process because they see it as an advantage for the interest groups they represent.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about your big mates in business?

—I will deal with the interjection of Senator Patterson and the references in other speeches we have had today about what has been exposed in various royal commissions around Australia. Let us not beat around the bush. Those royal commissions-whether it was the Fitzgerald Royal Commission, the Royal Commission in Tasmania, the one in Western Australia, or the Costigan report earlier this decade-have all embarrassed political parties for their involvement in raising funds.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not excuse the efforts of political parties, whether it is the Liberal Party, the National Party or my own, to make arrangements to raise large amounts of money. But why are they forced to raise the large amounts of money? Because political parties-whether it is the Liberal Party, the Labor Party or the National Party-know of the desperate need to raise large amounts of money to pay for their election campaigns. Once they start on that process of raising money, people's judgments start to err on the side of making some arrangement to raise that money and appear to give some favour.

Already in Queensland people have gone to gaol because of the exposures of the Fitzgerald inquiry and subsequent inquiries there. We have had the case in Tasmania-Senator Walters's own State-of a senior figure of the local community trying to bribe a member of parliament to cross the floor to bring down a government. He is a well-known supporter of the Liberal Party.

TALK.START.PARA: —He was not a Liberal member at all.

—But he was involved in raising large amounts of money. I may not know much about Tasmanian politics, but I do know that Mr Rouse was not an active supporter of the Labor Party or the Green Independents in Tasmania. All his associations were with Senator Walters's Party. The evidence so far in that Royal Commission indicates that he was in contact with Mr Gray about making some arrangement to stop the Labor-Green alliance coming to fruition. He was not phoning Mr Field to make those arrangements. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted; debate adjourned.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —The President has received a letter from the Acting Leader of the Government in the Senate nominating senators to be members of various committees.

INTERJECT.PARA: (1) That Senators Burns, Loosley, Reynolds and Schacht having been duly nominated in accordance with the resolution agreed to by the Senate on 21 June 1991, be appointed members of the Select Committee on Community Standards Relevant to the Supply of Services Utilising Telecommunications Technologies.

(2) That Senators Childs, Sherry and West having been duly nominated in accordance with the resolution agreed to by the Senate on 20 June 1991, be appointed members of the Select Committee on Superannuation.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Will the Minister clarify the objective of the Government's monetary policy? Is the objective to take a medium term focus in order to reduce inflationary expectations and improve price stability-that is, the fight inflation first strategy-or is it, in the words of the former Treasurer, Mr Keating, to be flexible and dexterous in the setting of interest rates; that is, quick adjustments in response to the latest economic figures, which is what the present Treasurer, Mr Kerin, calls a knee-jerk reaction?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think I should get a higher duties allowance for answering these sorts of questions. I am not going to respond to the specifics of what particular people may say by way of commentary and have the agenda set for me in that respect. I will simply, very cheerfully, describe the Government's policy on interest rates and monetary issues. The point is-as everyone knows-a period of tight monetary policy was necessary in order to slow demand and reduce inflationary pressures. As evidence of slowing demand growth and falling inflation emerged, monetary policy has been progressively eased. There have now been eight easings since January 1990, the most recent of which was on 16 May, which have led to a fall in short term professional rates of 7 1/2 percentage points over that period since early 1990. As a result, business lending rates and home loan rates have fallen, as everyone knows, and are likely to fall further. However, recent easings have yet to impact fully on the economy. There is a lag time involved, as we all should know by now.

ANSWER.PARA: A host of factors is considered by the Government when reviewing the level of interest rates including, particularly, the achievement of a sustainable reduction in inflation and inflationary expectations and the level of economic activity. In this respect, inflation, as a relevant consideration, is clearly continuing to trend down, with our policies succeeding in reducing the annual inflation rate from over 11 per cent, when we came into office, to 3.4 per cent in the year to the June quarter. That-as, again, ought to be well appreciated-is the lowest annual increase since March 1970 after adjusting for Medicare effects and it is well below the latest annual average OECD inflation rate of 6.2 per cent.
We are confident that the economy is poised for a sustainable recovery and, indeed, the progressive easing of monetary policy over 1990-91 will be a major factor underpinning that recovery.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The Minister, in his failure to answer the question I put to him, has merely added to the monumental confusion over the Government's attitude to this major element of economic policy. I ask him whether he agrees, for example, that real interest rates are still at near record levels. I also ask him, given that he is so obviously incapable of answering the question: will he refer it to the Treasurer for a considered reply and, in so doing, will he request the Treasurer to clear his response with the Prime Minister and Mr Keating to see whether it is just possible for the Government to produce a response that, for once, has some agreed logical consistency to it?
—Senator Short has had the only answer he is going to get from me on this subject.

—Has the attention of the Minister for Industrial Relations been drawn to reports of a recent paper by two academics which rejects the argument that the reason for the gap between male and female earnings is discrimination? Is this conclusion accepted by the Government and other agencies working in this field? What role will the equal pay unit have, if any, in looking at this particular issue and problem?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I have seen the paper. It is a paper on reasons for the earnings gap between male and female workers of Australia. It is a paper by Professor John Nevile and Dr Binh Tran-Nam at a conference at the University of New South Wales on social and economic inequity. It is one of a series of papers which argue that the gender earnings gap is due only to a narrow definition of what is direct discrimination by employers. This paper proposed that only 4 per cent of the 35 per cent earnings gap between male and female rates is due to direct discrimination; that is to say, discrimination which is intended by employers.

ANSWER.PARA: I query the value of this sort of conclusion. I do so because there is indirect, unintended, indifferent discrimination which is nonetheless discrimination; it matters little to the victims of discrimination whether it was intended with prejudice or intended with indifference because the impact on them is exactly the same.

The other thing about this paper is that it adds to the argument of some in the community who wish to pretend that there is no, or virtually no, discrimination. This paper is misused in the way in which it is presented to bolster that type of conclusion.

Importantly, though, this paper ignores the structural and systematic discrimination which characterises women in the Australian labour market. For example, it undervalues the importance or effect of deskilling of casual and part time work on women. It does not recognise that often or mostly work is organised around the role of the male as the breadwinner and, therefore, casual, temporary, part time work is work traditionally done by women and dominates work categories in which women are the most populous and that women rarely have anything like the same access to overtime that men have.

It does not take account either of the clustering of women in occupations or industries in which their skills are undervalued because those areas are regarded as women's work. Until award restructuring came along-something that this Government supported in the 1987 national wage case-there were very few career options for women and their jobs were mainly dead-end jobs. Their job options have now to some extent opened up due to award restructuring.

It is for these reasons that the Affirmative Action Agency has criticised the findings of this paper. The Government is firmly committed to removing the barriers. The pay equity unit in my Department to which Senator West referred was set up specifically to look at those issues. We believe that some progress has been made through the minimum rates adjustment process in awards in which classifications for women and men are linked because of the value of their work, the content of their work, and not characterised in women's work and men's work and thus have no comparative value. Award rates of pay for women have increased by 5 per cent in the 17 months to January 1990 due to the minimum rates adjustment process compared to a 4.4 per cent increase for males. I think that indicates that there is some impact on the problem. As I have said, the equal pay unit in my Department has had a hand in that, as have employers and unions dedicated to trying to remove this discrimination.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Royal Commission Into Commercial Activities of Government and Other Matters

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Acting Leader of the Government in the Senate and Minister representing the Prime Minister. I refer the Minister to sworn testimony given at the Western Australia Inc. royal commission yesterday of the involvement of a member of the Federal Government in the Burke Government's 1987 rescue of Robert Holmes a Court in his problems with BHP. Who was the member of the Government contacted and what was sought of the Federal Government? What action did the Government take on the request?
—I have no knowledge of the matter to which Senator Hill is referring. I will seek advice as to what it may be possible to say on the public record about that.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. In recent months, an agreement between the G7 countries was reached to establish a register of countries which buy arms-I think that includes conventional arms. While I support that, I ask: will the Minister urge that there also be established a register of countries which sell arms and/or manufacture them?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Crowley intimated, the G7 group of leading Western economic powers decided at its London summit meeting last month to endorse the establishment of a register of conventional arms transfers under the auspices of the United Nations. Such a register was also endorsed at an earlier meeting in Paris by the five permanent members of the UN Security Council. The establishment of the register has been recommended by the UN expert group on conventional arms transfers, which has been studying ways and means of enhancing transparency in such transfers. In its report, that expert group also encouraged all states to work towards greater openness on arms holdings and production. Australia is an active participant in the growing exchanges taking place on this issue, particularly in that expert group. We are looking to the finalisation of its recommendations, which will address these issues.

ANSWER.PARA: At the UN conference on disarmament issues in Kyoto, I indicated to that very wide-ranging international audience my firm view on behalf of Australia that the establishment of an arms transfers register, which would cover both sides of the equation-which, as Senator Crowley points out, is necessary-would be a very useful step forward. We certainly support the establishment of such a register. With that expert group's recommendations having been finalised, and with the support that now exists from the G7 and the P5, there is strong expectation of early action. I cannot put a date on when that will be achieved, but we are certainly going to be working actively for that result.

TALK.START.PARA: —I address a question to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I preface my question by advising the Senate of a comment made to me three weeks ago in the United States by Congressman Henry Gonzales, Chairman of the House Standing Committee on Banking, when I met with him to discuss corruption in banking in Australia. Congressman Gonzales and two of his senior staff members strongly advised me to examine possible Australian banking involvement in two major scams. I refer also to a comprehensive CNN report on American television concerning corrupt practices in American and global banking. I ask the Minister: firstly, has the Reserve Bank or any law enforcement agency investigated any allegations concerning involvement of Australian banks in conduiting funds to Saddam Hussein's weapons development program; and, secondly, has any investigation been undertaken concerning alleged involvement of Australian banks with the Bank of Commerce and Credit International?

—I am not in a position to answer that at the moment, notwithstanding a degree of advance warning from Senator McLean. All I can say is that I will respond to his question after I have received advice through the Treasurer from the Reserve Bank and the relevant law enforcement agencies.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Will the Minister undertake to examine the CNN report on these scams? The report said that virtually every major bank in the world conduited money through the BNL in Atlanta to Saddam Hussein's weapons development system. My question is: will the Minister undertake to investigate quite specifically whether any Australian bank fell into the category of `virtually every major bank in the world'?
—I will draw Senator McLean's question to the attention of the Treasurer, for such answer as he thinks may be appropriate.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs. I refer to a report stating that more than 23,438 people were killed last year in America, with as many as three out of five murders being a result of the use of guns. In light of these figures, and with the reported increased use of guns in crime in this country, I ask the Minister: does the Government intend to review the present laws in relation to the type of weapons allowed under gun ownership in Australia? Is there any move towards taking action to reduce the ownership of guns in the community?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I believe that all honourable senators and, indeed, all Australians would be concerned that we do not develop into the sort of gun-ridden violent society which can be found in many areas of the United States. The figures that Senator Jones has brought to the attention of the chamber are quite horrifying. The latest figures that I was able to get indicate that there were some 300 murders in Australia in 1989-90 and that, of those, about 25 per cent were committed using weapons.

ANSWER.PARA: The figures are not so bad, relatively speaking, when compared with that gun-ridden violent society which is part of the culture of the United States. Nevertheless, it is horrifying that some 75 or so murders in Australia in that year were committed using weapons or explosives. I suppose what is even more tragic for us in Australia is that in the same year there were 450 suicides which involved the use of weapons. That is, of course, a terrible tragedy also.

I refer to the honourable senator's question about what governments are doing. Constitutionally, the possession and control of firearms is a matter for State governments. The Australian Police Ministers Council has been trying to come to a common position for some years. It has been aided in that by the report of the National Committee on Violence, which was set up by the Prime Minister and all Premiers in response to the Hoddle Street and Queen Street massacres which shocked the nation. Certain recommendations made by that committee, in relation to the better control of firearms within State jurisdictions, are being considered by the various States.

As far as the Commonwealth is concerned, our responsibility lies with the importing of weapons into Australia. In that regard, with the cooperation of the Minister for Small Business and Customs, Mr David Beddall, I was able to ensure that there were no further imports into Australia of semi-automatics of a military kind or of a look-alike military kind based on Russian Red Army models and Chinese Army models. That regulation has taken effect. With the support of the Senate, it has been in place for a couple of months. This is, at least, an attempt to help change the culture in Australia so far as the importing of those types of weapons is concerned.

I think all governments are very concerned to help change the culture towards a less violent gun-ridden society-if it is possible to do so-not only through use of the import regulations in regard to certain sorts of weapons but also in relation to laws relating to possession and control within various jurisdictions.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Industrial Relations to his recent proposal for an accord six and three-quarters, which he announced on the Sunday program-a proposal that has now been rejected by both the ACTU and the Australian Industrial Relations Commission. Given the Minister's much vaunted confidence in his ability to negotiate packages with the ACTU, when and how will the Government or the Minister be able to determine a wages outcome for the next year?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —This question must fall within the realms of a fishing expedition because it is indeed speculative. I did talk on the Sunday program about a short accord, or an accord six and three-quarters-whatever words one would use in terms of the numerical definition of an accord.

ANSWER.PARA: The reason I proposed the idea is that our Budget will be presented next week. There is a need for an agreement on aggregate wage outcomes for the next year; there is a question of superannuation; there is the question of what will be our approach to the national wage case which, from yesterday's decision in the metal trades case, will resume with written submissions on 2 September. There are a number of fundamental questions about the next wage round that are important to our objective to lock into the Australian economy a low level of inflation and things of that nature.

It seemed to me-and still does-that it is appropriate that we have an understanding about those outcomes with our accord partner, the ACTU. The fact that there is some criticism of the idea may well deter Senator Durack, but it does not deter me. I believe that at an appropriate time we will reach such an agreement and that will guarantee that when the recovery starts to strengthen in the latter part of this year it will create jobs and be able to sustain itself. That recovery will also mean that through an accord where we negotiate wages, taxes, the social wage and other aspects of an accord we will provide a living standards outcome for Australians and will not simply concentrate on the narrow element of wages, which are eroded by taxes. We will get an accord that will see us through and enable us to get moderate wage outcomes during the recovery period, and that will be a good thing for the Australian economy.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a supplementary question, Mr President. In view of the failure of the Minister to be able to answer my question, I repeat: when does he expect the Government to be able to reach the agreement with the ACTU of which he spoke? In view of the fact that it obviously will not be reached by next week, how will the Government determine a wages outcome estimate for that Budget?

—That supplementary question is premised on the assumption that I did not answer the question. I would contend that I did answer the question; I said `at an appropriate time'. That remains the answer. Senator Durack will have to sit and wait a bit more quietly for the appropriate time to arrive when the Government announces these things, and it may be a lot closer than the honourable senator thinks.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. In view of the continuing human rights abuses in Burma and the refusal of the State Law and Order Restoration Council to recognise the democratically elected government there, can the Minister advise, first, whether the decision by the SLORC to increase legal detention without charges from three years to five years will encourage the international community to consider again imposing trade and economic sanctions against the SLORC; secondly, whether the Australian Government will co-sponsor the Swedish resolution in the United Nations to put pressure on the SLORC to recognise the results of the May 1990 election; thirdly, whether ASEAN's response to the call by Western governments at the July ASEAN meeting to apply pressure to the SLORC for a peaceful transition of power to the National League for Democracy has been favourable; and, fourthly, whether any further information has been received on a possible release date for the leader of the National League for Democracy, Aung San Suu Kyi?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government remains appalled at the extent of the repression that prevails in Burma and at the military regime's continued refusal to implement the results of the elections now held over a year ago. There will be no relaxation in the strict approach we have adopted as a matter of Government policy to that bilateral relationship.

ANSWER.PARA: There is very little evidence to show that the Burmese regime is considering ameliorating its policies in any way. The former leader of the NLD, Aung San Suu Kyi, has recently entered, as Senator Schacht said, her third year as a prisoner within her own home. More than 80 of the members of parliament elected in free elections only one year ago have been removed by death, arrest or detention or have felt obliged to flee the country for their own safety. Around 60 members of the NLD are currently in prison; at least three of them have recently had their prison sentences-originally of seven to 10 years' duration-arbitrarily increased by 10 years each.

A recent media report indicates that this year the regime might convene the National Convention composed of the remaining elected representatives-those who are not dead, in gaol, disqualified or out of the country-and representatives of so-called ethnic nationalities. The regime has said that it would draw up a new constitution. The regime has previously stated that it has refrained from convening this body on the grounds that the post-election procedures have not yet been finalised. We have been concerned that the regime's real purpose has been simply to ensure that all potential sources of opposition among the candidates for the National Convention are prevented from voicing their opinions.

As to the specific questions that I have been asked, reporting from our embassy confirms that the regime has amended the law under which many of Burma's political detainees are held to increase the maximum period from three to five years detention. That has, among other things, the effect of deferring releases which would otherwise have been due in the next two or three months. We will continue to consult other countries concerned about the situation in Burma, and we will certainly keep the question of economic sanctions under review. Regrettably, the indications we have had-both from my own direct discussions and from soundings taken in other countries-are that effective international sanctions are unlikely.

As to the UN resolution, it is not yet clear whether Sweden will be putting forward the same resolution as last year, but certainly we have been talking about and urging support for a resolution at this year's General Assembly and have indicated a willingness to co-sponsor that. It is on the agenda; it is just a question of shaping up an appropriate resolution.

As to the third question about the ASEAN response, in discussions with my colleagues at the ASEAN post-ministerial conference recently in Kuala Lumpur I raised the issue of Burma in both private meetings and formal sessions. On that occasion the ASEAN countries decided to designate the Philippines Foreign Minister, Raul Manglapus, as their spokesman on these issues on a visit he plans to make to Burma quite soon. This is an important new ASEAN initiative. Our embassy has been holding discussions with the Philippines authorities on the proposed visit. It is of particular value in the context of Burma having regard to and taking seriously the views of its trading partners and closest friends. For ASEAN to be prepared to raise these questions of international concern is an important new development.

Finally, on the question of the release date for Aung San Suu Kyi, we have received no information on a possible release date for her. The orders for her continued detention have regularly been extended, most recently in July this year. She could now, under the recently amended terms of detention, be detained until mid-1994. The military authorities have let it be known that she could be released from detention but only if she first agreed to go into foreign exile. She has rejected this blatant attempt to remove her from the political scene and, in her determination to remain, has become a symbol of the Burmese people's aspirations for democratic change.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. What is the Government's position on the question raised by the Australian Industrial Relations Commission to the parties in the national wage case principles review concerning the future of national wage cases and, in particular, their relevance in an enterprise bargaining environment?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The full answer to that question by the Industrial Relations Commission will be provided to it in written submissions on my behalf and on behalf of the Government on 2 September. I will refer Senator Crane to that answer when it is given.

ANSWER.PARA: The question posed by the Commission certainly does raise for public consideration and debate a whole series of arguments about wage fixation in the future. For example, in a recent policy statement the Confederation of Australian Industry announced that it thought that the Commission should be turned from a compulsory institution into a voluntary institution, only to be accessed when both parties to a dispute felt the need for it, and that national wage cases should cease. It posed the question: does the Confederation of Australian Industry want there to be a national wage case this year to set minimum wage standards for Australia or not?

I was interested to read in the newspaper this morning that the Director General of the CAI, Mr Brian Noakes, is quoted as saying-I imagine accurately-that the Confederation of Australian Industry would see an important and continuing role for the Commission while it is translating itself into whatever is the new wage framework for the future.

At this stage I am considering what the Government's reply will be. The Government's policy direction is to manage the devolution of the centralised wage fixing system to more of a workplace focus than it has had in the past, and to embark on a course of encouraging workplace bargaining around achieving higher productivity outcomes so that prices for commodities can fall and returns to profits and wages can increase at the same time, as each of the three elements of productivity are shared between those in the community who have an entitlement to it.

We are managing the very tricky and very difficult task of altering the centralised system that has served us so well until now to one with a productivity based enterprise focus. Our answer to that question will be about balancing the speed with which we meet that objective with the recognition of the needs of those people who are not in a position to bargain for productivity, or who are in a weak bargaining position and have a traditional bargaining relationship with their employers-not a common approach to the question of productivity, but an employer-employee relationship of the old conflict model. It is a matter of how we balance their needs to access wage increases at a time of economic stringency. When it is given, our reply will deal with an answer that sets out how to devolve the system and how to balance the needs of those people who will be left out in a workplace negotiating future.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs. Can the Minister tell the Senate what action the Government is taking in relation to the problems concerning consumer credit insurance highlighted in the report of the Trade Practices Commission?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Consumer credit insurance is extremely important for consumers in the marketplace in Australia. Obviously, it deals with that circumstance where, because of death, illness, unemployment or some accident, people are unable to keep up repayments in relation to credit that they have obtained to purchase a car, whitegoods, furnishings and so on. It is usually sold in conjunction with a finance package. That is the way that most Australians know of consumer credit insurance.

ANSWER.PARA: The meeting of consumer affairs Ministers last Friday had before it a report from the Trade Practices Commission which I directed to be provided at about this time last year. The Commission undertook research into the promotion and the supply of consumer credit insurance and came to certain findings which validated the grave concerns, the misgivings, which were held by Ministers and members of the general community concerning this product.

Amongst the problems highlighted by the Commission were, firstly, the fact that about one-quarter of those who obtained this form of insurance had no idea that they had purchased it-they were not even aware that they had purchased it as part of the package of getting the credit-and, secondly, it was found that at the worst end of the market commissions ranging between 30 per cent and 60 per cent of the premium were not uncommon. This creates a great incentive for those who sell this particular form of insurance to do so, regardless of the suitability for the consumer. Finally, there was a clear finding that on the whole consumers get back about 33c in the dollar from the premiums that are paid in relation to this form of insurance. That is considerably different from the general level of return to those who hold insurance. The general insurance industry as a whole has a loss ratio of between 78 per cent and 89 per cent.

Ministers expressed concern at these findings by the Trade Practices Commission. Very authoritative, definitive research was done. They said that in relation to the loss ratios over the next three years they certainly want to see a better return to those who hold these sorts of insurance arrangements.

Recommendations made in the report deal with disclosure so that consumers are aware that they are purchasing this form of insurance and the fact that the documentation ought to be written in very clear English and legible type. The Ministers also agreed that it is very important that there should perhaps be a 14-day cooling off period in relation to taking out this insurance. They have set a three-month discussion period for recommendations and for comment from the community in relation to those recommendations.

I would certainly like to thank the Trade Practices Commission, its officers and those consumer organisations which made representations and helped to carry out research for this very important document presented to consumer affairs Ministers. I believe that it will be very important in the marketplace as Australians deal with the fact that we are a credit ridden society; we need to obtain credit for everyday purchases and for the big purchases such as cars, whitegoods, furnishings and so on. In relation to that, whether one takes out insurance should be a matter of clear choice.

Under most fair trading Acts around the States, it cannot be made a condition of obtaining the credit. That should be very clearly understood by consumers. They should be wary of being forced into taking out such insurance. We are determined that consumers should know precisely what they are purchasing and that there should be restraints on the profit margins and certainly on the commissions that are charged in relation to this product.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does the Minister for Industrial Relations accept that the enthusiasm with which both workers and management have greeted the decision of the Queensland State Industrial Court to exclude union involvement from Power Brewing's voluntary employment agreement confirms that employees are capable of negotiating enterprise agreements without union or Industrial Relations Commission interference and should have the right to do so, if they choose?
—There were two questions. The answer to the questions is no and no.

—Has the attention of the Minister for Industrial Relations been drawn to a 10-point action plan for the Australian economy put forward by a group of nine business leaders? Is the Minister aware that the action plan made no reference to the benefit to economic conditions contributed by the wage restraint shown by Australian workers under the terms of the accord between the Government and the ACTU? Would economic conditions be further benefited if major business leaders were to show similar restraint?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I have seen the 10-point plan put forward by nine eminent Australian business people, entitled `Action Program'. It is certainly seen as a program for future policy adjustments that need to be made in their view. It is not a report on how or why we are in the present economic circumstances, nor is it a report which would acknowledge the considerable wage restraint entered into by Australian workers over the last 14 months.

ANSWER.PARA: I have great agreement with some of the points raised in this action plan. For example, point three in the plan states:
In the past we have focused on improving past performance as our standard.

It goes on to talk about raising Australia's industrial performance to best international standards. Yesterday I answered a question on the Australian Government's best practice program. The nine businessmen's 10-point plan focuses exactly on the purpose of our best practice program; that is, to lift, by international benchmarking, the performance of Australian industry to best international practice. Point eight states:
Past labour relations have been characterised by conflict and low productivity.

That is an observation with which I agree. It was typified in the Fraser period of government in this country, but it is not so typical of our Government which has tried to focus industrial relations on the cooperative model, not the conflict model. Several things are then said, with which I agree, about the need for productivity negotiation. I answered that in some detail a moment ago. Point 10 states:
The nature and level of education and training in Australia is poor compared with many other countries with which we compete.
It then talks about the need to improve the quality of our human resources. Point 10 continues:
We strongly support the new attention being given to this issue.

That is a comment on the education and training programs that this Government has introduced. The businessmen identify the urgent need to train managers for senior supervisory levels in the management of people. I concur with that.

Many elements of this 10-point plan are beneficial and useful. I have respect for each of the nine Australian businessmen who sponsored this plan. One of them is a person I know reasonably well, Mr Ian Burgess, the Chief Executive Officer of CSR. Therefore, in that context it is disappointing that I should read that CSR voted Mr Burgess, its Chief Executive Officer, a salary increase-from his current range of $460,000 to $470,000 to a new range of $610,000 to $620,000, an increase of 32 per cent. This is at a time when the aggregate wage outcome for the year is 6 1/4 per cent. Many workers will not get such an increase.

At the same time as this occurred at the CSR annual general meeting, the report to shareholders was that the after-tax profit had fallen by 21 per cent. In this case, the 32 per cent salary increase could not be said to be based on performance but rather was based on so-called market factors. I am disappointed that, at a time when wages for ordinary wage and salary earners in Australia are moving at moderate levels-indeed, they have almost been in freeze for the last 14 months-and at a time when wage restraint is being practised massively by ordinary wage and salary earners, increases at the rate of 32 per cent still occur at the chief executive level. There is a need for the captains of industry to recognise that they should exercise the same restraint as the workers do.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade and it refers to the purchase by New Zealand of Saudi Arabian wheat at $85 to $95 a tonne, which the Saudi Government has been subsidising by $US600 to $US1,000 a tonne since the mid-1980s. Considering the closer economic relations between Australia and New Zealand, will the Government request the New Zealand Government to act against this New Zealand purchase of highly subsidised Saudi Arabian wheat by countervailing duties or other available means? What other action does the Government intend to take to stop subsidised wheat taking Australian international markets?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —There have been newspaper reports, to which Senator Boswell is obviously referring, describing that purchase of subsidised wheat from Saudi Arabia for sale in New Zealand later this year. It reportedly involves 25,000 tonnes of a total New Zealand import market of some 200,000 tonnes. The precise details of what may have occurred are not yet clear and my Department is seeking further details. We will certainly be making our concern known to the relevant authorities in Saudi Arabia and New Zealand if the sale is confirmed.
