ANSWER.PARA: I understand that New Zealand farmers are considering the possibility of a domestic countervailing complaint as a way of responding to this, if the sale is confirmed. I have no doubt also that the New Zealand Government will itself be concerned, if it is confirmed, because of the effect of such sale on the return to New Zealand's own wheat growers and because of the position that New Zealand has taken, along with the rest of us, in the Uruguay Round. The origins of all of this lie in what has been a longstanding practice, as I understand it, of Saudi Arabia paying its wheat farmers many times the international price to ensure national food security but then selling the surplus abroad at a major discount. This is not a new phenomenon; it has been around for a long time but the amounts have been relatively small.

TALK.START.PARA: —Everyone is doing it.

—Yes, but they are doing it for different reasons and this is the reason why the Saudis are doing it. Saudi Arabia is not a signatory to the GATT and therefore is not part of the Uruguay Round talks in agriculture trade. Nonetheless, in the interests of the global wheat market and trade liberalisation, we would be looking for Uruguay Round disciplines to be applied globally. The final point is that obviously we would be disappointed if the traditional Australian wheat market in New Zealand were to be distorted by Saudi sales of the type which have been reported.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Obviously, Australian wheat sales will be disrupted if there is 25,000 tonnes of wheat going into a traditional Australian market. My original question was: will the Minister ask the New Zealand Government to put countervailing duties on the wheat that is coming in from Saudi Arabia?

—I have said that the sale is not yet confirmed and until we know clearly what is going on we are not going to be asking anybody to do anything. We will obviously be discussing it with the New Zealand Government. We would expect the New Zealand Government to be concerned, for exactly the sorts of reasons that we are concerned. I have already spelt those out. I have indicated that it has come to our knowledge that New Zealand farmers are considering the possibility of a domestic countervailing complaint in relation to the import in question. There is plenty of activity going on but I am not in a position to make a commitment to doing anything until we know precisely the basis on which such action would be premised.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I refer to reports that the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce and Minister representing the Treasurer in the Senate has given up on getting life insurance and superannuation funds to contribute capital to the development fund he has been trying to establish. Further to the inconclusive response offered yesterday to a more general question on this issue, I ask the Minister: first, does he agree that Australian savings should be applied to the creation of jobs in Australia rather than off shore? Secondly, does he agree that the rise in Australia's foreign debt must be contained and, indeed, that the debt must be reduced? Thirdly, in this context would the Government give consideration-no more at this stage; just give consideration-to measures requiring superannuation funds to place a proportion of their funds into government guaranteed public utilities loans as a first step in addressing these issues?

—To the extent that Senator Spindler is seeking Senator Button's personal views as to whether he has given up or is soldiering on or what he feels about this or that, I am afraid that Senator Spindler will have to ask him personally. He will have an opportunity to do that when Senator Button gets back this time next week. The Government generally is, of course, committed to maximising and ensuring the most efficient use of national savings. I do not think there would be too much disagreement with the general thrust of questions 1 and 2. As to the third part of Senator Spindler's question, the answer is no.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Mr Burke was to verify his international phone bill for the residence in Dublin. Could the Minister tell the Senate whether he has done that. Was the estimate of 10 per cent for personal calls previously given to the Government correct? If not, what is the now agreed percentage of personal calls?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The amount that Mr Burke owed for private international calls in Dublin has been paid. It was offset against his final termination payment. From his arrival in Dublin to August 1990 Mr Burke paid a 10 per cent flat rate as his contribution-as has been said in the question-for private telephone calls. From August 1990 until his departure he kept a log of these calls and paid accordingly.

ANSWER.PARA: In May this year it was established that a call logging facility was available for residential and chancellery telephones in Dublin from 1 January 1990. Itemised accounts were accordingly obtained by the mission and sent to Mr Burke. The company supplying the car phone had records from May 1990. Mr Burke checked the accounts thus made available to him and did identify personal international calls. The embassy administration has certified the accuracy of his statements in this respect.

As a result of that further check of the specific itemised accounts, the amount owing was $7,724. As I have already said, that was offset against his final termination payment. That represents a final payment of his personal contribution to these accounts.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I ask the Minister whether that is in addition to the previous $6,000-plus he was paid as part of the 10 per cent.
—Yes, that is my clear understanding.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Oil Spillage on Great Barrier Reef

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support heard reports of an alleged oil spillage on the Great Barrier Reef, with one report claiming that the crew of the Sevilla Wave alleged that:

QUESTION.PARA: A Cyprus-registered ship has flouted international environmental laws by pouring tonnes of oil and petrol on to the Great Barrier Reef off Townsville . . .
Has the Minister heard these reports? Are they correct? Will he investigate these concerning claims?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to Senator Reynolds's question is yes. I did receive a report last night that the first mate of this vessel, the Sevilla Wave, has made allegations that the vessel discharged 13 tonnes of oil, several drums and oily rags outside Cleveland Bay on 8 August. State inspectors from the Queensland Department of Transport have interviewed the master and the chief engineer, and inspected the oil record book on the ship, but have found no evidence of any discharge recorded in that book; but, more importantly, Coastwatch aircraft overflew Cleveland Bay on 8 and 9 August and reported that there were no signs of any oil pollution.

ANSWER.PARA: I have also received a report from officers who have been on board the ship that there does in fact appear to be a serious industrial dispute between the Greek master and his Polish crew, and this indeed may have some bearing on the reports from the Polish first mate, who has apparently indicated a desire to fly back to Poland rather than go back on the ship.

Officers are continuing to carry out the investigations, but at this stage it does not appear that there is any evidence of any actual pollution of oil. I understand that there has been some prominent coverage given to this story in north Queensland and in press reports in the Townsville media. We are treating the matter seriously, Mr President, and I will advise Senator Reynolds and the Senate if those continuing investigations turn up any evidence of actual oil pollution.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Administrative Services. I refer the Minister to the socalled `information package' concerning the Government's policy of banning electronic political advertising circulated by him to his Caucus colleagues on 21 March this year for the use of Australian Labor Party members and senators. Under the heading `The Broadcasting Tribunal' it is stated:

QUESTION.PARA: Politicians will play no role in deciding what should and should not be allowed.

How can the Minister honestly make such a statement when the Acting Chairman of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal, Mr Peter Westerway, has been General Secretary of the New South Wales branch of the ALP, the party's Campaign Director in that State, Chairman of the Economics and Trade Committee of the ALP Federal Executive and Treasurer of the Federal Executive?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I must admit, I was saying to some friends on the weekend that the talent level in the Opposition slipped enormously when Senator Bishop managed to knock off Senator Puplick. What we see today is that not only the talent level has slipped enormously, but the level of decency in this place has slipped to the level that Senator Bishop normally grovels in.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. I refer to a ruling of Sir Magnus Cormack in 1973 setting out the basis of rulings concerning how questions shall be answered. The Minister concerned, Senator Bolkus, is one who continually abuses the process. I ask you, Mr President, to direct him to answer the question asked of him and not to insert gratuitous material.

—Senator Bishop, I do not have to be reminded of the rulings of Sir Magnus Cormack. I was listening carefully to what Senator Bolkus said. Some of the remarks he made were probably unparliamentary, and I would ask that they be withdrawn. Senator Bolkus should answer the question.
—Mr President, if it is your judgment that the remarks were unparliamentary, I withdraw them.
—Take your hands out of your pockets.

—I can put my hands where I like, Senator Newman. The point I was making was that this self-same question was asked in this place some three months ago. Senator Bishop got a response then. I do not know who asked the question at the time, but exactly the same question was asked. Maybe the honourable senator needs to get a new researcher, for a start.

ANSWER.PARA: The second point I make in response to Senator Bishop's question is that it is very easy for me to make the assertion that was covered in the information package she referred to. Mr Westerway's last involvement with politics, I believe, was some time in 1973.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was 1972.

—In 1972. Since that time, he has served governments of our persuasion and of Senator Bishop's. He worked under Minister Staley; he worked under Prime Minister Fraser; he worked under a whole host of Ministers. He was adjudged by all of them to be a competent, impartial person who performed his duties objectively and well. It is now 18 or 19 years later. One wonders where Senator Bishop has been hibernating for all that period.

ANSWER.PARA: A slur on Mr Westerway does this Senate's reputation no good, and for Senator Bishop to come in here with pumped up indignity, imitating the person in front of her, does her no good either. This chamber should be concerned about issues. Rehashing slurs that were brought up here three months ago about a person who has served this country enormously capably, diligently and competently does her no good.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. At no stage did I suggest that Mr Westerway had behaved in any way other than in accordance with his duty. I have made that statement on previous occasions, as the Minister will see if he notes my press releases. However, my supplementary question is this: as the Minister made the statement that politicians would not be involved in any way in deciding what should or should not be allowed, I ask him to tell me when a politician is no longer a politician.
—I think in most professions an 18-year period off the bench means that one is no longer a player.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support. While attention has been focused recently on the stevedoring aspects of the Government's waterfront reform program, can the Minister advise what action is being taken to improve other links in the waterfront transport chain?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I have advised the Senate on a number of occasions, only about 50 per cent, to put a figure on it, of the potential productivity improvements that need to be gained on the waterfront are gained on the waterfront itself. As the Inter-State Commission correctly pointed out, an equal amount of productivity is available through improvements in port performance and the very important area of the interface between the port and the land transport chain, whether it be by road or rail.

ANSWER.PARA: Yesterday the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure released an excellent and very important discussion paper on issues arising from its inquiry into the land transport interface with our sea ports. In July last year, in consultation with the Chairman of that Committee, I provided it with an extremely broad terms of reference which enabled it to have complete scope to identify the problems in terms of this interface and in making it more efficient.

The discussion paper produced by the Committee yesterday follows a very extensive round of public hearings and inspections of ports earlier this year, and it provides a very comprehensive and clear outline of the various areas involved in the cargo handling chain. From this examination the Committee concludes that, while individual operations in ports are addressing the important question of their own efficiency, there is no overall coordination between all of the links in the chain. Consequently, improvement in waterfront efficiency not only has to involve each individual party in the process but also has to ensure that the links and interactions between other parties in the transport chain operate as efficiently as they possibly can.

Going by the feedback I have been getting from the industry, the inquiry has benefited greatly from the very high regard in which the Chairman of this inquiry, Mr Peter Morris, is held by people in the transport industry. The discussion paper reflects the very considerable experience and expertise that Peter Morris brings to this task. The Committee is actively soliciting further submissions to its inquiry, which it hopes to bring to a conclusion by the end of this year.

In conclusion, I urge the reading of this discussion paper by all members of the Senate and anyone else who is interested in the area of waterfront reform. I urge anyone in the industry who wants to make further submissions to the inquiry to do so speedily.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. I refer the Minister to recent statements by the chairman of the Government's tourism task force, former Labor Minister the Hon. John Brown, in the latest edition of the task force's bi-monthly bulletin. Mr Brown expressed the view that there is a need to phase out penalty rates in the hospitality industry-comments which it was reported were made to support the Minister for Tourism, Mr Simmons, who has also indicated that penalty rates are detrimental to the hospitality industry. I ask the Minister: is the Government prepared to assist hospitality industry employers and employees in determining a more flexible wages system and if not, why not? Further, does the Government acknowledge that the recent comments by the Minister and Mr Brown reflect the damaging effect which the present archaic penalty rate system is having on our hospitality industry and its ability to compete on the international market?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —To answer the first part of this question, I should send Senator Calvert a copy of accord mark 6. Accord mark 6 is about decentralising the centralised wage fixing system to make it more flexible and looks at how to achieve productivity at enterprise level. So if I heard the first part of his question correctly-are we interested in a more flexible wages system-the answer is that we are in the process of doing it.

ANSWER.PARA: The wages system is infinitely flexible. Indeed, if one does not wish to stick within the wages system as it is now structured, under section 115 of the Industrial Relations Act one can take a certified agreement, as it is called in the Act-that is, an agreement between the union and the employer at a particular establishment-and opt out of the system if that certified agreement is recognised by the Industrial Relations Commission as being bona fide and not an agreement based on exploitation by one party or the other. Effectively, we do have a flexible system and we are moving to make it even more flexible in the circumstances.
On the question of penalty rates, I do not agree with what Mr Brown has said. Penalty rates do serve a purpose in Australian industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —A disincentive purpose, yes.

— Penalty rates serve an important purpose. They pay people for working overtime and odd and peculiar hours, and for all sorts of other things. Senator Newman may not know this, but penalty rates are determinations that have been made by the Commission over the years as to what is an appropriate and fitting rate to pay for a particular disability as identified and found by the Commission.

ANSWER.PARA: The bottom line here is always what the wages outcome will be. Within the context of maintaining a reasonable wage outcome, there is the possibility of any of the major players in the hospitality industry negotiating directly with their staff. Under section 115 of the Act, if they reach a certified agreement-as is the case with ICI at Botany-they may remove some of those penalty rates by agreement. Usually that occurs when there is some performance payment or some other sort of payment which acts as a substitute. To simplify the payment system and get a better level of remuneration for better productivity outcomes, an agreement of that nature is reached.

It is possible to do such a thing in the hospitality industry. I do not agree that it should be done in isolation from anything else because that is simply negative. But if the hospitality industry directs itself to how productivity is improved, how to get a better team work approach in industry, how to break down the high turnover of staff and how to recognise the odd and peculiar hours worked, there is a possibility of getting wage outcomes by agreement through the existing Act in the present form.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday Senator Panizza asked me a question abouta possible inquiry into the activities of the CBA and other banks regarding foreign currency loans. I am in a position now to give him a response from the Treasurer which is in the following terms. The Government has no plans to hold an inquiry into the foreign currency lending activities undertaken by the CBA or otherbanks. The Martin parliamentary committee, the House of Representatives StandingCommittee on Finance and Public Administration, which is currently inquiring into the Australian banking industry, has taken evidence from both the Foreign Currency Borrowers Association and the banks, including the CBA, on this subject. The Committee is scheduled to report later this year and its findings may address past activities of the banks in this area. Dealings between the CBA and its customers are not a matter for the Government. They are, as I indicated yesterday, commercial-in-confidence matters, and disputes which cannot be settled between the parties are best left to the courts to resolve.

—In relation to a question from Senator Macdonald yesterday about legal action the Commonwealth is taking with respect to the Ravenshoe Mill, I advised the Senate, on the basis of advice from the Attorney-General's Department, that the Australian Securities Commission had commenced a section 597 examination of the matter. The Australian Securities Commission is in fact conducting an investigation under section 13 of the Australian Securities Commission law. Both options have been considered. My answer yesterday was based on advice which incorrectly indicated that the section 597 option rather than the section 13 option had been chosen.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Loosley Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a personal explanation.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —During the debate this morning on the Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures Bill, Senator Knowles made two claims: firstly, that I was guilty of breaching the Federal electoral law and, secondly, that I admitted having done so. Both claims are untrue, and maliciously untrue. The facts speak for themselves. In September 1990 Mr Justice Knight in the Federal Court of Appeal found that I was not guilty of a breach of section 315(2) of the Commonwealth Electoral Act, and, all along, for a period of nearly two and a half years, I had argued my innocence. In the eyes of the Australian system of justice, therefore, I am innocent. It is a pity that the independence of the judiciary and the validity of its findings are not acknowledged by some opposite. I repeat that both of Senator Knowles's claims are untrue and are, indeed, maliciously false, and the Senate earlier today was an involuntary and, I have no doubt, an unwitting witness to an exercise in McCarthyist smearing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a short statement on the same matter.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make the brief comment that there was no malicious intent whatsoever in what I said. I did not accuse Senator Loosley of any illegality whatsoever. I simply accused him of not declaring donations, and there is no denial of that fact.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Loosley Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not resile from anything I said in the earlier statement. The facts speak otherwise; indeed, the finding of the court stands in absolute contrast to Senator Knowles's allegations just then.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Alston interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —They just did not lock you up, that's all.
—Order! Senator Alston's remarks were clearly unparliamentary; he is not even sitting in his seat. I would ask Senator Knowles to withdraw that remark.
—I withdraw.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Advance to the Minister for Finance

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

The Advance to the Minister for Finance for June is a very voluminous document. It was received in the Senate earlier today and it has not been possible to study fully all the items which go to make up the applications to the Advance for the Minister for Finance in June. On the examination I have been able to give it to date, there are some items which require the attention of the Senate. I will single out only two in view of the time.

Firstly, I draw the attention of the Senate to the enormous blow-out in the funds required in 1990-91 for payments for Austudy and Abstudy. The number of applications for Austudy in 1991 has been almost 50 per cent higher in terms of growth than the Budget estimates. I think my friend and colleague Senator Michael Baume will be commenting on that, and I assume he will comment on the blow-out in Abstudy. So I will not pursue it further, other than to make one of the points that I think he is going to make; namely, amongst other things, it is a considerable reflection of the massive deterioration in the state of the Australian economy.

I particularly draw attention to the final paper in this great bunch that has been submitted. It is an application through the Advance to the Minister for Finance for a payment of $2m for the purpose of meeting the undertaking given by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) to the Premier of Queensland for infrastructure restoration following the recent natural disasters experienced by Queensland. I will seek leave to incorporate these papers after I have spoken to them, because I believe they are significant.

Attached to that application in the papers to the Senate are three letters, the most important of which is a letter dated 8 May 1991 from the Prime Minister to the then Treasurer, Mr Keating, referring to the Prime Minister's letter dated 13 March 1991, almost two months earlier, to the Premier of Queensland, concerning Commonwealth assistance for infrastructure restoration following the recent natural disasters experienced by the State. In that letter, the Prime Minister says:

I am concerned that the processing of my commitment to Queensland has been unacceptably delayed because payments cannot be made from Financial Assistance Grants. Would you please therefore arrange payment of a capital grant to Queensland of $2 million in each of 1990-91 and 1991-92 for infrastructure restoration by way of an Advance to the Minister for Finance under the Treasury appropriation.

I assert that that is a gross violation of every conceivable use that was ever intended for the Advance to the Minister for Finance. I believe that it is an illegal application and I believe that that money has been illegally paid.

Apart from that letter there are two accompanying letters-a letter from Mr Keating to Mr Willis, because it is Mr Willis's job, as Minister for Finance, to approve payments under the Advance to the Minister for Finance, plus the Prime Minister's letter-which make it absolutely clear that the Prime Minister had no Cabinet approval, first of all, to make that commitment, so he entered into that commitment personally, on behalf of the Government. It appears that he received no further endorsement of that undertaking which he gave to the Premier.

Under the rules of the Advance to the Minister for Finance, applications are supposed to be made before payment is required. That was not done. It is an example of the enormous arrogance and presumption of the Prime Minister in playing with the money of the taxpayers of this country. It amounts to a virtual blackmail of the Treasurer. No wonder the former Treasurer is not getting on too well with the Prime Minister. I believe that this is an absolute disgrace and it needs to be investigated by the Auditor-General and all those concerned with the proper finances of this country. I seek leave to incorporate those letters in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The letters read as follows-
PRIME MINISTER
CANBERRA
The Hon P J Keating, MP
Treasurer
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
My dear Treasurer
I refer to my letter of 13 March 1991 to the Premier of Queensland concerning Commonwealth assistance for infrastructure restoration following the recent natural disasters experienced by the State.

I am concerned that the processing of my commitment to Queensland has been unacceptably delayed because payments cannot be made from Financial Assistance Grants. Would you please therefore arrange payment of a capital grant to Queensland of $2 million in each of 1990-91 and 1991-92 for infrastructure restoration by way of an Advance to the Minister for Finance under the Treasury appropriation.
You will appreciate the urgency in this matter given the severity of the natural disasters and the resulting drain on Queensland's resources.
Yours sincerely
R J L Hawke
Treasurer
Parliament House
CANBERRA 2600
The Hon Ralph Willis, MP
Minister for Finance
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
My dear Minister

The Prime Minister recently wrote to me concerning a commitment he had entered into on behalf of the Commonwealth to pay a capital grant to Queensland of $2 million in each of 1990-91 and 1991-92 for infrastructure restoration following the recent natural disasters which have beset the State.
The Prime Minister's letter (copy attached) specifically indicates that the payment for 1990-91 should be by way of an Advance to the Minister for Finance.

I understand (following consultation on this matter between our officers) that your approval for the payment to be made in this way, in writing and in response to my request, is necessary by virtue of Finance Regulations 44B. In view of the Prime Minister's specific request, I would be grateful if you would give the necessary approval.
I have, of course, copied this letter to the Prime Minister.
Yours sincerely
P.J. KEATING
MINISTER FOR FINANCE
Hon. Ralph Willis M.P.
The Hon John Kerin, MP
Treasurer
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear John
I refer to Mr Keating's letter of 29 May 1991 requesting my authorisation for an immediate payment of $2 million as a capital grant to Queensland in 1990-91 for infrastructure restoration.

I understand that the Prime Minister has informed the Premier of Queensland that, in view of the impact of successive natural disasters on the State budget, the Commonwealth will provide additional assistance of $2 million in 1990-91. This commitment was made after the Additional Estimates Bills for 1990-91 had been finalised.

I support the proposal to provide additional financial assistance to Queensland to relieve budgetary stress. I understand that an application for funds from the Advance to the Minister for Finance will be forwarded to my department shortly for processing in the usual way.
I have copied this letter to the Prime Minister.
Yours sincerely
Ralph Willis
7 June 1991

TALK.START.PARA: —I point out to Senator Short that some of the words he used in his short speech came very close to being considered unparliamentary. I refer to the words `blackmail' and `illegal'. I indicate to him that he should be more careful in his use of terms in referring to other members of Parliament, be they from this or the other chamber.

—Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President. I accept your words. I must confess that I feel so strongly about the misuse of public money that has occurred in this instance that I felt moved to use such language.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. The document that has already been tabled states that the advice received from the Department of Finance is that there is no legal basis for this. I hardly see that you can rule that the allegation of illegality is correct. If you wish, the word can be used, but the document states that there is no legal basis.

—Take a seat, Senator Herron, and think about what I said. I said very carefully that Senator Short went close to using unparliamentary words. I did not make a judgment because I was aware that he may have been quoting from a document that was appended to the one he was discussing. Therefore, I made no further comment on it. If, for example, he had quoted that word directly, it would be unparliamentary and I would have asked him to withdraw it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Like Senator Short, I am staggered by parts of the facts revealed in the Advance to the Minister for Finance for June. I particularly want to take up the question of an extra $52.7m being made available to Austudy. I am not complaining about the fact that Austudy, which is a demand driven payment, has gone up, because, after all, people are requiring Austudy assistance. What intrigues me is that it reinforces exactly the point I have been making in this Parliament over and over, and that is that Austudy and payments to Austudy are hiding the real extent of youth unemployment in this country. This submission admits that Austudy is being used for that purpose.

SPEECH.PARA: The documents reveal that the extra money-$52.7m-is required because, at the time of preparing the latest Budget, the Department had predicted a 9.5 per cent increase in beneficiaries. Then, based on figures available in January and February, these figures were revised upwards by a further 4 1/2 per cent at the Additional Estimates that we dealt with early in the year.
The Department goes on:
It was assumed that the growth witnessed in the early months of 1991 was the result of improved marketing and earlier delivery of application forms.

That is utter bunkum. We said in this Parliament that the reason for the increase was the massive surge in unemployment amongst young people. Austudy was being used by the Government as an escape hatch to hide the real number of young unemployed.
The Department goes on:
It was predicted that the growth would taper off in April and May to give a total number of beneficiaries for the year of nearly 320,000.

At the time, we said that was bunkum; we said that the figure would be far greater than that. The Additional Estimates included an extra $28.7m to cover the estimated cost of the increase. We now find out belatedly that the growth in beneficiary numbers was, however, sustained throughout April and May. It is now estimated that over 405,000 students will be placed on pay before the end of the financial year. That is 85,000 more than the estimate given when the Department asked for an additional $29m or so earlier this year.

This is interesting because it is now conceded that basically the changed economic environment is one of the factors in this matter. How curious it is, as I pointed out yesterday, that something like 72,000 young Australians have disappeared out of the unemployment figures in a couple of months, yet 85,000 young Australians who were not budgeted for as recently as March or April this year are evidently being funded to stay at school or in tertiary institutions. These figures dramatically show what the disaster in the economy has brought to young people.
I would extend this further because there is an item where $900,000 in urgent and unforeseen funding is required to assist unemployed people to set up self-employed ventures. That item states:
Demand for New Enterprise Incentive Scheme (NEIS) places is very strong and has increased substantially over previous years as a result of . . . effective Managing Agent structure--
The real reason for the big increase is then admitted:

The increased demand is also attributable to increases in the number and skill levels of unemployed people combined with a reduction in employment vacancies which make self employment often the only option for employment.

We are seeing here in these Estimates figures the clear and direct result of the Government's recession that it says we had to have. We are seeing where multi- millions of dollars are being spent-not through the unemployment benefit-and in such a way as deliberately to hide the true level of unemployment and the huge costs of unemployment from not only the people involved but also the taxpayers, who are funding it.

Frankly, the device used here is one that should be exposed. That is why I am speaking today: to reveal that these documents give a clear indication of the extent of the hidden unemployment in Australia. There are many other items, by the way, in this Advance to the Minister for Finance which are due and depend entirely on the level of recession, but none so blatantly hide the level of true unemployment as this $52.7m for Austudy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, like Senators Short and Baume, I would also like to refer to the Advance to the Minister for Finance being used in what can only be described as an abnormal and unusual manner to pad out and pander to the Government's recession. In particular, I draw your attention to the allocation of some $4.32m through the Department of Employment, Education and Training portfolio for special employment, education and income support, specifically with regard to the Aboriginal study assistance scheme, colloquially known as Abstudy.

SPEECH.PARA: This vote is, of course, vitally important to Aboriginal people throughout Australia. I would refer to Budget Paper No. 1 of last year and, in particular, to the description in that document where it was highlighted that the financial year would have a total Budget figure of some $92.7m for this particular allocation. What we now see at the eleventh hour, or the eleventh month of the year, is that there is a requirement that was not foreseen months earlier. The supporting documents have three special requests that were processed on closely linked dates in June in order to put this extra $4.3m through the books.
Like Senator Baume, I am concerned about some of the reasons that have been advanced for this particular advance. Let me quote from one:

It is thought that this increase in the take-up is due to wider economic circumstances in terms of a down-turn in the labour market resulting in a larger number of people seeking to enter full-time or part-time education and/or training.

Before that, the paper outlines how DEET had been anticipating a growth in secondary beneficiaries of about 5 per cent, that there was similarly an anticipated growth in the beneficiary numbers of Abstudy of about 10 per cent, and that there had been a staggering 100 per cent increase in beneficiary numbers for tertiary part time allowance.

Why was not that seen, prophesied and planned for at the time of the Supplementary Estimates earlier in the year? To have left it to the last month of the year either implies incompetence on the part of the Minister or departmental officers or, alternatively, that there has been such a deterioration in the national economy that Aboriginal people and students, many of whom live in isolated, remote communities of Australia, where the impact of the recession is very different, have been forced into the scheme.

I will pursue this matter; I put the Government on notice that for the forthcoming Budget Estimates I want to see the plans not just for the coming year and the changes in that particular vote item, but also details for the next three years. There needs to be long term planning for the remote, isolated and special communities-which are already in tragic circumstances and where much still needs to be done to improve Aboriginal education-to ensure that the votes and the financial underpinning of this program are not fiddled at the last minute because someone either got it wrong or deliberately planned an economy to have an adverse reaction on sectors of the community that just cannot afford to have hiccups in their major programs.

This is a major program that has important social, economic and personal consequences. It is one that I believe Senator Baume has highlighted in the general education area, particularly in relation to Austudy; however, this one highlights that it has even further and more tragic results for Aboriginal communities.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I too wish to refer to the payments made pursuant to the June Advance to the Minister for Finance. I would like to address a couple of remarks to the matter raised by my colleague Senator Short concerning the payment of $2m to Queensland, which purports to be for infrastructure payment for national disasters. I think it is particularly interesting to note that there is a specific allocation in the body of the Advance for June 1991 for further payment pursuant to the national disasters relief program, which draws upon the Advance to provide further money for disasters that have occurred in other States, but this one is deliberately set aside and not included in that amount. I think that perhaps highlights the fact that there may well be bureaucrats who are just as concerned about the use of this Advance to the Minister for Finance as we are.

SPEECH.PARA: I also draw attention to the so-called reasons for it being asked; namely, it says that the application for funds meets the guidelines of the Advance for the Minister for Finance. I would seriously challenge that statement. It says that funds are required urgently, given the nature of the occurrence in the State. The only nature of the urgency seems to be that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) demanded that the payment be made. I do not think that in any way, shape or form meets the criterion set down. It is cited as `Unforeseen' because the requirement for the grant was unforeseen at the time of the preparation of the Budget Estimates and the Additional Estimates for 1990-91. That is quite obviously the case, but it is certainly not within the spirit of what the Advance is meant for. I put on notice that I will be most interested in pursuing this matter when we come to the Estimates hearings in order to find out just how that matter was treated.

I also wish to raise the question of the $31m sought by the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce for payment to the Australian Trade Commission in respect of payments of national interest business. This matter particularly concerns me because when insurance is carried on the so-called national interest, that means EFIC, which is the insurance arm of Austrade and which is to be severed from it. That was to be effective from 1 September, but I now understand it is not to take place until November, despite the fact that a board has been appointed. The reason for the delay is that the legislation is yet to be settled. This is a most unsatisfactory way to do business. The fact is that when EFIC considers that an insurance is not a commercial insurance, such as insuring our trade of wheat to Iraq, it states that it will not carry the insurance.

The Minister of the day-and nobody else-makes a determination about whether the national interest will carry that risk and that simply means Consolidated Revenue. The Minister makes that decision; he may not delegate it. The Minister may take it to the Cabinet to have a Cabinet solidarity decision made if he wishes, but it is his responsibility. I want to know by what mechanism the payment is actually made. From the nature of this application I can only presume that a drawing is made from Consolidated Revenue and is then paid to EFIC to make the payment to people who have suffered the loss. I will make it my business to find out more particularly how that occurs, but I find the explanation given here-that the amount required for payment by way of insurance to the people who have suffered the loss-was erroneously understated. It says that the amount of $31m applies to the EMDGs and that the amount of $1.6m relates to EFIC. The reason for the EMDG blow-out of $31m is the erroneously understated amount; the reason for the blow-out in the EFIC payment is simply that there was a devaluation in the dollar. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak briefly on the Advance to the Antarctic Division for lay-up costs for the Aurora Australis. No doubt, Mr Acting Deputy President, on your visits to Hobart you have noticed the large red vessel laid up beside the dock; it has been there for quite some time.

SPEECH.PARA: I have spoken about this matter before, but I would like to draw it to the attention of the Senate again because it is the first time in the history of Antarctic chartering that the taxpayer has had to pay for the lay-up costs of this vessel. Not only that, but, as I said earlier, the taxpayer is now also paying the cost of an ice pilot this year. Nevertheless, the Minister for Finance (Mr Willis) told us that this is all going to change. I wonder how much more it would cost if the vessel were not laid up in Hobart. Part of the agreement negotiated between the Government and the owners was the Government would pay the lay-up costs and it is just fortunate that the vessel was laid up in Hobart. Had it been laid up in Sydney, for instance, not only would the taxpayer have been up for the extra-and more expensive-lay-up costs there, but the taxpayer would also have had to pay the cost of getting the ship there and back.

When I raised the question of lay-up costs earlier in the year, the Minister told me that it was expected that next year the Aurora Australis would have 40 days' alternative charter work with the Cooperative Research Centre in Hobart. I think that is great, but the Cooperative Research Centre in Hobart was promised $2.8m by Mr Hawke for research work on ice temperatures, marine research and so on, and the charter work at this time seems very convenient. When I raised a question of lay-up costs a couple of years ago in the context of the contract between the Government and the builders of the ship, I was told that during the lay-up period the Aurora Australis would be chartered out for private work and thus that would negate the cost to the Government of the lay-up. That was fine at the time, but as we see from this, the Government obviously could not find any work for the ship this year. The Minister has told us that over the next seven years there will be work for the ship, but the taxpayer will pay for that. So whether the Aurora Australis sits at a wharf in Hobart or is doing some charter work for the Cooperative Research Centre, the taxpayer will have to pay the extra money.

I suggest that it has been very convenient that charter work for the Aurora Australis over the next couple of years was found by the Government because it puts paid to the Minister's statements at earlier times. In fact, the Minister's statements were just a lot of hot air as far as I am concerned. The extra money that is to be provided by the taxpayer for work for the Aurora Australis is just to get egg off the Government's face.

While I am on that subject I raise the question again: who is the owner of Aurora Australis? The Minister will not answer. I have put questions on notice. He will not tell me who the owner of Aurora Australis is. He will not even tell me the name of the company on the list of non-statutory bodies that Senator Coates managed eventually to get for the Parliament. It is Antarctic Shipping Pty Ltd. As I said, who is the owner of Aurora Australis? Is it P &O Polar or is it Antarctic Shipping Pty Ltd? We know that Antarctic Shipping Pty Ltd is a $2 company. All its shares are held by the Commonwealth of Australia through the Commonwealth Bank. I believe that it is the owner of the ship.

My time is about to expire so I will not be able to pursue this matter any further now. But I certainly will be pursuing the matter to find out the story behind this because we know that P &O receives favourable treatment from the Government. If the Government is paying for the ownership of the ship, a lot of questions need to be answered.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Olsen Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to speak briefly to the Advance to the Minister for Finance of June 1991 as it relates to the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs-an additional allocation of $1.5m, bringing the total amount to $2,081,000 for the year ended 30 June 1991.

SPEECH.PARA: This clearly relates to the cost of administering the Department and the cost of housing and looking after a number of refugees, in particular the Cambodian refugees housed in Darwin. In May the Joint Standing Committee on Migration Regulations visited Darwin and looked at the situation applying to the number of refugees who were being held in security pending a determination of their application for refugee status. We have been apprised of the fact that in many instances these people had been on Australian soil for almost 12 months but at that time no application had been submitted to the Department for consideration. In the meantime, the taxpayer of Australia is picking up a very substantial tab of $2m, of which $1.5m is for additional allocations included in the Advances referred to in the Government documents tabled in the Senate today.

It is inappropriate, reprehensible and totally inefficient for the Minister and his Department not to ensure that those people had their applications processed in a shorter period than 12 months. I am talking not only from a practical point of view and a cost point of view as far as the taxpayers of Australia are concerned-that is what we are talking about; the bottom line is that the taxpayers pick up the Bill-but also from a humanitarian point of view. These people are in secure accommodation. We are feeding them, clothing them and attempting to give them some basic education. But the point is that we are not meeting what I believe are our humanitarian responsibilities, let alone what we ought to be doing from an efficiency point of view in the expenditure of taxpayers' funds.

I understand that a number of refugees have now submitted their applications. When we were in Darwin in May, 10 of those people had had only preliminary interviews with departmental officers. It is simply not good enough when millions of dollars are expended because of lack of efficiency within the Department in processing applications such as that. If they are to be returned eventually, the longer they stay on Australian soil the more difficult it is from their point of view as individuals to return home, if that is the bottom line or the determination is such that they have to go home in due course because they do not qualify for refugee status. In the meantime, we have spent millions of dollars looking after them as a result of lack of efficiency within the Department.

Let me take the matter one step further. The new Migration Act introduced by Senator Robert Ray several years ago has been an unmitigated disaster. Officers of the Department find it confusing and cannot give clear, concise advice to people seeking it; neither can people recommend a course of action to individuals as to the course they ought to follow-the type of application they ought to submit, what their rights are, and the requirements of the Act. Over this period we have seen new regulations and amendment after amendment. We get a new batch of regulations every couple of weeks, trying to plug another hole that has been identified by the Department.

It is clear that the Migration Act is failing, and failing badly. It does not give clear, concise guidelines upon which people can make a determination and upon which advice can be given to people in what in many instances is a very emotively based set of circumstances. In some instances these people go through trauma while applying for permanent residency in Australia. Therefore, I think it is incumbent upon the Government, recognising the cost that is flowing through to the taxpayers, to look at that Migration Act, to acknowledge that it is not working efficiently and well, and to recognise that it is an unmitigated disaster and that the Government is compounding the problem by the regulations it keeps bringing in week after week, to the point, I understand, that we will not get a rewrite of the Migration Act incorporating the regulations brought in over the last 12 months for at least another year. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —The time alloted for debate has expired.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —In accordance with the provisions of the Audit Act 1901, I present the following report of the Auditor-General:

INTERJECT.PARA: Audit Report No. 1 of 1991-92-Project Audit: Industry, Technology and Commerce Portfolio-Australian Customs Service.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

I see that Senator MacGibbon wishes to speak to this paper, so I will be very brief. This Auditor-General's report is very important because it points to some needs to make significant changes to matters relating to prohibited goods and the search, basically, for drugs. There is no doubt in my mind that the need to improve the arrangements outlined by the Auditor-General must be taken up by the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce, even though there is evidence that the Australian Customs Service is reluctant to undertake some of the measures recommended by the Auditor-General.

In particular, the Auditor-General points to the need for Customs to obtain suitable premises in Sydney and Brisbane for the conduct of discrete examination of containers for prohibited goods. I imagine that Senator MacGibbon will be dealing with that matter, so I will not go into it at great length, other than to say that in 1982 under the Fraser Government some legislation providing adequate security requirements was passed but relevant amendments to the legislation were not proclaimed because Customs said that it would impose unreasonable burdens on people using it and that therefore they were not appropriate.

However, the Auditor-General remains concerned about the potential for any reduction in the standard of security at any stage in the clearance of containerised sea cargoes, and it considers the development of national security standards for licensed premises to be an appropriate course of action. It considers that covert cargo examinations should be undertaken in an environment which ensures secrecy so that the effectiveness of drug detection efforts are not compromised. That is not the situation which presently exists. The Auditor-General has recommended that a 24-hour surveillance operation be set up while these changes are being made and the Customs Service has said that it is not considered appropriate. I believe that action should be taken about that.

One other matter I want to raise briefly is the drug dog detection unit, the DDDU. I think that everyone is aware, from a lot of publicity, of how effective that unit has been. However, the Audit Office found that in Sydney there had been a very high incidence of illness amongst the dogs as a result of an inadequate standard of accommodation, thus reducing the overall effectiveness of the unit. It seems to me to be appalling that the Customs Service did not get its act in order well enough to make certain that this important element of the fight against drugs-the dogs-was properly looked after.

I note that Customs advised that it had been aware of this problem and that the health of dogs is now of a desirable standard and accommodation has improved. Quite frankly, it is all very well to have that assurance, but maybe the Auditor- General should make certain that the accommodation for those animals has improved. It would be an enormous waste of resources if that was still the situation. I hope that it was not only the Auditor-General's complaints that prompted Customs to smarten itself up on this issue. If it was, I think that the organisation should quite properly be criticised.

Another matter raised by the Auditor-General was that dogs were not available for approximately 20 per cent of the examinations for which they were requested, apparently because of training commitments for dogs and handlers. That seems to be an extraordinary situation. I see that Customs responded by saying that it was aware of the need to increase the number of operational dog teams and it planned to have 45 teams operating by mid-1991, which is an increase of almost 50 per cent. I welcome that. It is no doubt unfortunate that it seems that it had to depend on an Audit Office recommendation that priority be given to improving the standard of accommodation for the dog unit before it happened.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Auditor-General's Audit Report No. 1 relating to the Australian Customs Service is before the Senate. I wish to speak briefly on it. Audit reports are simply a sampling of one or two-or half a dozen-operations of a large department. In this survey Customs came out without criticism on a number of elements that were examined and, as my colleague Senator Michael Baume said, came in for some criticism on others.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to comment briefly on the containerised inspection techniques. Most of the cargo coming into Australia by sea now comes in in containers. They are quite large. They are very robust. They are of heavy steel construction with a door at one end. Despite their massive structural integrity, the weakness is in the lock. It is very easy to break into a container because they usually only have a simple padlock or a simple sealing device on them. It is important that security is maintained on containers before they are released by Customs because they are relatively easily broken into. That requires a secure area for them to be stored in.

The Customs Service goes through a percentage of those containers to make sure that they do contain what the manifest says they contain. In most cases it is a very big job to go through a 40-foot container-I forget the number of man days of operation that are involved. The amount of time involved in going through a container full of golf balls which are packed six to a cellophane pack, a dozen packs to a box and a dozen boxes to a carton in detail is quite mind-boggling.

Nevertheless, I do agree with the audit report that there is a case for a secure area out of sight where containers can be gone through, if only for the convenience of the Customs officers who have to work in all weather. It should be a reasonable expectation that they can do that safe from prying eyes at a distance seeing what containers they are going through. It often happens-particularly where drugs are concerned-that their presence will be established and they will be left so that the recipients of the drugs can be apprehended at the final point of their distribution.
There is also some criticism of the contraband enforcement teams from an administrative point of view, with suggestions as to how that, and methods of control of mail coming in, could be improved.

The fundamental point is that Customs cannot do any more than it has resources for. It is important that Customs is supported financially. If it does not have enough resources, the Commonwealth suffers a loss of revenue in that goods on which duty should be paid enter the country duty free, and that is a loss to the Treasury.

The Customs Service is also important from a surveillance point of view. While the quarantine provisions are primarily a matter of health, Customs is often the first point of detection of illegal foodstuffs and foodstuffs which might carry parasites which pose great potential risk to the Australian primary industries.

Then there is the matter of contraband itself. It is generally accepted that, while personal couriers with drugs concealed on their bodies form a significant vehicle through which contraband or illicit drugs enter Australia, the great majority of drugs come in through containers. Given the hundreds of thousands of containers that come into this country each year, checking them out is a major job. It all leads to resources, and that leads to money in the budget and having the detection techniques and the officers to do that. In my experience with Customs, it really is a conscientious and capable organisation. It is well led and well motivated, but it can only do what the resources at its disposal will allow it to do.

Last week, when I was in the Cape York and Torres Strait Island area, I had the opportunity to meet with senior Customs officers in Cairns and the Torres Strait region and talk to them about their problems. I was very satisfied with the level of professional competence that they showed and their interest in and dedication to their jobs. However, that Torres Strait area is becoming an area of increasing relevance in illegal trafficking of goods and human bodies-illegal migrants. The Customs Service is the primary barrier against that in the region.

It is an area characterised by quite short distances internationally. It is probably not much more than 120 miles from Cape York to the New Guinea border just beyond Boigu Island and Saibai Island. There are numerous islands in the area, giving a dispersed population-a population which, nevertheless, has quite strong family and community links within it so that it knows who is moving through the area.

It is an area of very great mobility. The standard means of transport is a 14-foot aluminium dinghy with a 40 horsepower motor. Anyone in those dinghies-there are hundreds of them in the area-moves without comment and without notice in any way at all. It is very easy for people to island hop from the New Guinea border to Cape York, or even bypass the islands altogether and move from the New Guinea mainland into Australia. When we talked to the community leaders-the equivalent of shire chairmen-in the four or five regions in Torres Strait, they told us that this year they were increasingly aware of and increasingly concerned about illegal traffic in the region. I think that, although the evidence is anecdotal, they have grounds for their concern.

In looking at this audit report, it is quite proper for me to comment on the need for increased resources for Customs in that area. We are not talking about a huge increase in resources, but clearly something that increased the surveillance techniques, and the ability to have personnel on the ground talking to the communities around the island groups and on Cape York itself, would be very much in the national interest. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —In accordance with the provisions of the Audit Act 1901, I present the following report of the Auditor-General:

INTERJECT.PARA: Audit Report No. 2 of 1991-92-Project Audit-Australian National University-Housing Operations.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tierney Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

The Senate is considering the Auditor-General's Audit Report No. 2 of 1991-92-Project Audit-Australian National University-Housing Operations. The Australian National University maintains a stock of 575 dwellings for renting to accredited visitors, postgraduate research scholars and full time undergraduate students. The current value of the housing stock is $51m, and in the last calendar year the net operating surplus from this investment was $302,703.

TALK.START.PARA: —Even I could do better than that!

—Yes. This is somewhat alarming because viewed as a return on capital it represents only 0.53 per cent. Even when the non-operating revenue is included, the surplus amounts to a little under a million dollars, which is a return on capital of 1.7 per cent. Given the value of the asset, this is obviously a very small return. Some of the reasons for this are quickly apparent in the `Key Findings' at the beginning of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: The project audit raises a number of queries: the appropriateness of the current level of investment in housing stock and alternative uses for the funds committed; the condition of the housing stock and the required maintenance levels; the unsatisfactory financial performance of the operation; and the low level of rents which are below market rates.

The original objective of the housing operation was to induce suitable academic staff to join the university back in the 1950s. The inducement was thought necessary in 1950 because the university was new and Canberra was a small country town. At that time Cabinet approved the building of 99 units. This is an excellent example of what happens with a bureaucracy when it is unchecked. It is fortunate to see that the Auditor-General is bringing it into check at this point, because the city has expanded and it is a very attractive place to live. The university also now has a world reputation. One would ask: why are these sorts of things continuing in 1991?

The audit notes that in March 1991 there was an aggregate weekly difference of $756 between market rents and rents being charged by the university's office. On an annual basis the weekly difference extends to $39,312 per annum. The Australian National Audit Office considers that setting rents below market rates may be illegal as well as bad management. It has recommended to the Australian National University that all rents be increased to market levels as soon as possible. The Australian National University has apparently agreed to this recommendation and appropriate action is being considered.

Apart from the fact that we have a very valuable resource which is being wasted and a loss of potential revenue to the Australian National University, this is an excellent case for privatisation. Because the Australian National University does not have to subsist on the return of these assets, there is no bottom line, there is no emphasis on making a reasonable return on capital and the institution is losing income which could be ploughed back into supporting the basic functions of the university.

One has to ask a number of questions. How long has this been going on? Presumably since that Cabinet decision in 1950, which means it has taken 40 years for this matter to now be brought before the public. If there had not been this report by the Auditor-General how much longer would it have taken to come to our attention? How much money has the ANU lost through the financial mismanagement of its housing operation? Why has it devoted so much of its resources to this activity?

There are 577 houses and 18 staff to run them. That is 32 dwellings to one supervising staff member instead of 90 to one staff member, which is usual in housing operations. If the Auditor-General had not acted and produced this report and we in the Senate had not had the opportunity to examine the report, how long would it have taken the university to introduce reforms in this matter?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the motion that the Senate take note of Audit Report No. 2 1991-92 Project Audit-Australian National University-Housing Operations. My concerns do not parallel those held by Senator Tierney. There is little hint in the report of the sorts of concerns that the report could well encourage the Australian National University to explore.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Tierney rightly points out that the original intention of the housing operation, which is repeated in the report, was to provide an inducement for suitable academic staff to join the university. He rightly observes that the nature of the small town character of Canberra has altered since the introduction of this scheme in 1950. The report tells us on page 3:

The present policy is to offer accommodation for continuing staff who require temporary accommodation, for approved visiting staff, non-continuing staff and postgraduate students. There is also a program to offer a limited amount of accommodation off campus for undergraduate students to supplement that available on campus.

It seems that the original intention has been altered somewhat. It would be reasonable to assume that that has altered in response to the unique demand for housing at the Australian National University. Because it is our Australian National University its housing requirements for its students and staff are unique due to the very nature of its program.

This aspect requires further emphasis and exploration by both the university and the Government. The opportunity of equity of access to our national university is dependent upon not only the entrance opportunity that all Australian students have but also the opportunity for those students to be accommodated within Canberra or the university's precincts. That accommodation opportunity is reduced somewhat if we do not have this unique housing operation which presently exists. On page 4 the report tells us:
Short term accommodation services on this scale generally do not exist in Australian universities.

That emphasises the unique nature of those services. The unique charter to serve as a national university, on its own, justifies the provision of a short term housing option so that those students who come from further away in Australia have an equitable housing opportunity. This operation, with its admitted emphasis on provision for staff and postgraduates, may not necessarily meet the sort of demand that I am speaking of. Even in the housing operation strategic plan of 1989 to 1993, which is quoted again in this report, there is an emphasis on staff and the staffing philosophy.

In response to this report, I am suggesting that further attention could be given to the unique nature of the Australian National University and its charter and the reduced opportunity which students throughout Australia would have in attending that university if there was a reduction in accommodation.

Let us look at equity of access. The accommodation arrangements which have to be made by students before the beginning of an academic year-whether they come from somewhere close by, somewhere else in New South Wales or somewhere very different, such as from Western Australia or perhaps the wilds of Tasmania-quite rightly, are noted in this report. Page 4 of the report reads:
Of particular value to both the University and the visitor is that time is not wasted in searching for housing prior to taking up an academic appointment or study place.

I suggest that those who are mostly concerned with studying are less interested in spending time looking for accommodation. That is also recognised. It is reported that the demand is of a cyclical nature. When one person is looking for housing at the beginning of the academic year, several hundred others are also looking and so it very much becomes a seller's market.

These are the sorts of things which would discourage one from supporting the idea of privatisation advanced by Senator Tierney. Privatisation might be satisfactory if private enterprise could guarantee, without taking advantage of those seeking accommodation, to meet both the cyclical nature and the particular cultural requirements which may be placed upon the housing market by people attending our national university from overseas. There is a particularly important skew in that direction where people who are experienced in dealing with clients, students or staff from overseas would know the sorts of special considerations that need to be given. Within this housing operation those people have developed those particular skills.

I suggest that the evaluation brought to this operation by Senator Tierney, which used as its main criterion the return on capital, is not the only method of judging the success of the housing operation of the Australian National University. Many other criteria could be brought to that examination which could be of even greater importance than a simple return on capital because it is not always money which drives this operation. The audit report, quite accurately, brings to our attention that money is not the only criterion which should be brought to judge this operation.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
