DEBATE.TITLE: POLITICAL BROADCASTS AND POLITICAL DISCLOSURES BILL 1991

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen C.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the suspension of the sitting for lunch, I was speaking on this Bill and on this motion to refer the Bill to a select committee. I was responding to some remarks made by Senator Walters in her speech, in particular, the impact of money on the political process and the need for parties to raise large amounts of money to pay for the high cost of election campaigns. I pointed out to Senator Walters that in her own State of Tasmania there has been a royal commission into such matters as the attempt to bribe a member of parliament to cross the floor to enable the Government to survive. As part of that Royal Commission there have been investigations into why the leader of the Liberal Party in that State had $10,000 in a drawer for three months. I make no bones about the fact that the unsavoury events which have been uncovered by the Royal Commission in Tasmania and by other royal commissions around Australia--
—And the one in Western Australia.

—Including Western Australia. Irrespective of the political party all prove my point, and the point of the Government, that unless something is done to control the high cost of election campaigns this problem will continue to bedevil all political parties. In the end, it will mean that people in political parties will start taking desperate measures to raise money to pay for the cost of campaigns. Unless something is done, we could take that risk which in the end could pervert the political process in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: In my view, we have already had evidence that the perversion is taking place; whether it is in Queensland where a number of people have actually been charged and been found guilty; or whether it is in northern New South Wales with the ICAC report. I point out, of course, that the ICAC report did not just deal with one political party, it dealt with members of both the National Party of Australia and the Australian Labor Party who were involved in raising funds for their parties.

We also have the case in Western Australia where the evidence so far in the Royal Commission, although it has not completed its findings, is that there was a major effort made by the leader of the Labor Party in the mid-1980s to raise large amounts of money. The reason for that is quite clear: money was to be raised and established in a trust fund and the interest thereafter would be used to pay for future election campaigns so that the party in Western Australia could be free of the perennial problem that all parties face from all sides about raising enough money to pay for an effective election campaign.

It is quite clear that the overwhelming cost of election campaigns is television and radio. In metropolitan Sydney where a 60-second advertisement costs $30,000 to put on air in prime time-one might be required to put that advertisement on three or four times a night across all commercial stations-one is running up a bill of $100,000 plus on one night for one political party. If that is done over a 20-day campaign, one is looking at $2m or $3m worth of expenditure to run a reasonable campaign.

People say that to raise this money should be an unfettered right. Of course, one can take that simplistic view, but if one does one is accepting the fact that only a limited number of organisations and individuals can make those sorts of donations and that, in the end, all political parties will be beholden to those donors. All political parties would want to be released and free from being beholden to those sorts of people who make those donations.

As a former Party official of the South Australian Labor Party, I certainly wanted to ensure that donations were made without strings attached. And when I was Party secretary they always were. There has been no evidence in South Australia to the contrary. But it meant that the South Australian Labor Party was always facing considerable financial difficulties to run any sort of election campaign.

The restriction-if people want to call it that-on free speech to enable the removal of the power of money over the political process is a price worth paying. The Government is now proposing only the removal of the ability of political parties and third party interest groups to advertise during an election campaign-a similar ban exists in most other Western countries with which we, as a democracy, would compare ourselves. In those countries people do not jump up and down in the streets or carry out extreme campaigns such as that of the Opposition, which is saying that it is an attack on free speech. It is and has been accepted by conservative, radical and social democrat governments in Western European countries that that is a reasonable outcome for democracy.

Australia has, with Japan, the most unrestrictive rules of all the major democracies. Therefore, it is not unusual that in the last decade in Japan there has been one scandal after another involving the liberal-democratic party, the socialist party, the social democrat party and even the democratic socialist party-the so-called clean party of Japan-all about raising money from business interests. In Japan there is no limit to how much one can spend in an election campaign. As a result, business interests have influenced the political process to such an extent that there are now endless scandals. As a result of those scandals, in the last 10 or 15 years Prime Ministers have fallen- come and gone. Japan, like Australia, is the only country in the Western world that has no restriction.

America has some restrictions on presidential elections. It has restrictions on congressional elections in that television and radio stations are forced to sell political advertising to candidates at the lowest discount rate offered to the biggest commercial bulk buyers. In Australia it is the other way around: political parties are charged a surcharge to buy television and radio advertising at short notice. Australian political parties pay more. They pay the highest rather than the lowest rates, as in America. Even the home of Western capitalism, America, has more restrictions than does Australia. Therefore, it is humbug of honourable senators opposite to talk about the end of free speech if this measure proposed by the Government is adopted.

I was particularly interested in Senator Walters's speech. She made claims about free speech and cried out that it would be the end of free speech. Yet Senator Walters is a very active member of the Senate in wanting to ban 0055 telephone calls. She thinks that they contain matters of a sexual nature offensive to some Australians. Even though those phone calls are between consenting adults she wants to have them restricted.

Because of Senator Harradine and others, the Senate Select Committee on Community Standards Relevant to the Supply of Services Utilising Telecommunications Technologies is now having a look at ways in which a restriction can be placed on adults making private phone calls to each other. That is a restriction on free speech. She is quite happy to have that restriction put in place. She thinks that it serves a social good.

I do not disagree that free speech has to be modified to meet the social objectives of society. But just as Senator Walters claims that a social good can be achieved by restricting 0055 telephone calls-private calls of a sexual nature; I do not necessarily agree with all of that-I believe that a social good can be achieved by restricting the power of money over the running of election campaigns, which strike at the very heart and the fundamentals of democracy in this country.

When I hear those opposite talk about free speech in election campaigns I would like them to be a little more consistent about free speech in other areas of society. But they want to pick and choose what suits their social prejudice.

Much has been made here by the Opposition about the fact that this has now been referred to a select committee. The Opposition proposed this two or three months ago. That is a matter of fact; no one can argue with that. The Government has referred it to a select committee-we are quite open about it-because the Australian Democrats cannot quite make up their minds about what they wish to support on some sort of restriction or reform in this area. Until we get agreement, at least from the Democrats, we know that the numbers in this place mean that nothing can be carried. Of course, those opposite are implacably opposed to any reform at all, no matter what the consequences for democracy.

We make no bones about the fact that we are willing to put it to a select committee to ensure that there is still a good chance that a major reform can be achieved on the disclosure of donations and on the control of election spending.

I have been nominated by the Government side to be one of the members of that select committee if it is established by the Senate. I look forward to taking part in that committee's work. In the last parliament I was a member of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters, which brought down the report Who pays the piper calls the tune : minimising the risks of funding political campaigns. It was the first time in the history of this Parliament that a committee attempted to deal with the problem of advertising costs. This report broke new ground in Australia. This report is a seminal influence on where we are today. Though many people might not agree with all its recommendations, it started the public debate.

I conclude about the public debate. Endless numbers of people have said to us that if these measures banning election advertisements in election periods were to be carried they would be the end of free speech. I do not disagree that a whole range of interest groups oppose this ban. Overwhelmingly, they represent money, they have vested interests and they have access to large amounts of money. They know that if their vested interest is under challenge by community debate or by legislation in this or other parliaments, they have the money to conduct a campaign in the media to get that legislation stopped, often by distortion, lies and misrepresentation.

Most other groups in the community do not have access to that sort of money to pay for that sort of campaign. I draw the Senate's attention to the fact that in the mid-1980s the Victorian Government proposed changes to third party insurance for cars and workers compensation. This would have stopped the legal profession having a major involvement in that area of that industry, that commerce.

Obviously, it would have made the whole industry cheaper. They were the recommendations of various reports. But the legal profession was able to raise in excess of $1m to conduct a campaign in Victoria. There was television and radio advertising against that legislation. It was successful in convincing the Opposition-the National and Liberal parties in the upper House of Victoria-to reject the Bill in a major way. So a major reform that had been rationally proposed to reduce costs to consumers was ultimately defeated because of vested interests. The Victorian legal profession, which could have lost money, was able to conduct a campaign because it had access to that large amount of money.

I believe that that is the perversion of democracy-the situation where one side has access to the money to carry out that sort of campaign. It might be of interest to the Senate to know that there was one lawyer in Victoria who objected to having his compulsory levy-a membership fee of a law society and a practitioner's fee-paid partly into that fund for that campaign. As a result, because of actions taken over several years by the law society in Victoria, he has now been struck off; he cannot practice. He has now been held in contempt of the Supreme Court of Victoria and is in hiding. It is the famous case of a Mr Little and it is all to do with the fact that he objected to his money being used to carry out a vested interest campaign, which he disagreed with, and his having no right of conscientious objection.

That is a side consequence, where there is a vested interest using its unfettered power. I believe the recommendation to send the Bill to a select committee takes note of the realities that we are faced with in this place in getting any reform through. One of the other opposition parties, whether it be the Democrats, the National Party or the Liberal Party, is going to have to agree to it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do the unions have a conscientious objection?

—Yes, they do have conscientious objection in the Industrial Court. If someone has a conscientious objection to joining a registered industrial union, that person can take a hearing to the Court and ask for conscientious objection, and in most cases that is upheld. There is no conscientious objection provision in respect of paying practitioner's fees to the law society of Victoria; none whatsoever. These are the very same people-the Law Council of Australia-which the Opposition is quoting as advocating free speech. They are not in favour of freedom of speech for Mr Little; they want to rub him out and put him in gaol for contempt. They will not give him the same conscientious objection that someone can get as a member of a registered blue collar union or other industrial union in Australia. The Law Council quotes freedom of speech. I hope it comes and gives evidence to the select committee, because I would like to ask a few questions about its notion of conscientious objection and of freedom of speech because of the way it has treated Mr Little in Victoria.

SPEECH.PARA: I conclude by commending this motion to the Senate. I hope that we can return here with a report and a package of reform within a couple of months that at least a majority of the Senate can agree to and which will mean two things: full disclosure, so that there are no more hidden donations-no more money in paper bags or black suitcases or wherever it may be; and, secondly, no more right for a vested interest with access to unlimited money to dominate an election campaign, buy off political parties and pervert the political process in this country.

This is one of the most important reforms the political process in this country has had to face for a long time. I am proud that this Government has had the guts to fight it through, despite the opposition from the vested interests who are distorting the case, and so on. I look forward to coming back here in two to three months time, having the debate and getting the substantial reform through.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the decision to refer the Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures Bill to a committee, as do other senators on this side of the chamber. We have been seeking it for some time.

SPEECH.PARA: I begin by reading a letter I received today. I have received many letters in relation to this matter. This letter is from the Borough of Eaglehawk, Victoria Street:
It has been brought to the attention of my Council that legislation has been introduced, proposing bans on political advertising on radio and television.

My Council considered this matter at its Ordinary Meeting held on the 25th July, 1991 and resolved to inform you that Council objects most strongly to legislation which proposes to ban political advertising on T.V. and radio. Such action is regarded as an attack on the freedom of speech in this country and furthermore, it can be seen as a distinct plot to prevent legitimate campaigning on such issues as road funding and financial support for the community. Accordingly, such legislation should not be deemed as appropriate.

That is typical of the many letters and the many communications I have received from the community about this Bill. Contrary to what Senator Schacht, the previous speaker, had to say, outside the political parties, most groups that get involved in advertising of a political nature-and, of course, this affects them-are in fact community groups that are protecting the community interests. The ramifications of what is before us are very significant.

It is appropriate that this Bill should be referred to a committee because it is insidious and it is flawed. It is a serious breach of the freedom of expression-I emphasise the word expression-and speech. I do not believe, as Senator Schacht has said, that one can legitimately compare the situation which exists between 005 calls and a ban such as this, albeit with the suggested amendments that came in late from the Government on the banning of political advertising on radio and television.

The real question that has to be addressed in this Bill is: what are the purposes behind it? I would like to identify two of those. One is to try to overcome the financial problems of the Australian Labor Party and to fool the Australian public that it is trying to overcome the odium of the brown leather bags with the initials BB on them.

Let us examine two aspects: one an omission and the other the flawed analysis regarding the costings around this Bill. It is interesting to note that there are amendments to the Broadcasting Act 1942, amendments to the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918, amendments to the Radiocommunications Act 1983, amendments to the Referendum (Machinery Provisions) Act 1984, yet there are no amendments to the Industrial Relations Act 1988. Once again we see that this Government is protecting the elite in the trade union movement; the capacity which exists in section 269 and regulation 127 of the Industrial Relations Act makes it quite clear how simple it would be for the trade unions to launder money out through the back door. If the Government were truly genuine, in terms of this particular Bill, it would have put up amendments to address those particular problems.

I quote, for example, the recommendations that were made by the Cooke inquiry in Queensland in terms of changes that needed to be made as far as the Industrial Relations Act was concerned, so that there would not be laundering of money out the back door and there would be protection of the individuals who were members of the unions. The first recommendation states:

(1) An industrial union shall not expend money which expenditure constitutes political objects unless it maintains a political objects fund which fund shall be separate and distinct from the other funds of the union.
(2) (a) A member of an industrial union shall not be required to make any contribution to the union for political objects unless-
(i) a separate contribution therefore is determined by the union; and
(ii) the member has notified the secretary of the union in writing (and has not subsequently revoked the notification) that he desires to contribute to the political objects fund.
This Bill is very limited in its coverage of the full aspects of political donations. It leaves at least one aspect very wide open.

The next matter I would like to raise about the reference of the Bill to a committee concerns a point that Senator Bolkus has consistently emphasised. I want to go to the interview he did on the 7.30 Report the other night. In answer to the second question that was asked of him by the interviewer, Paul Lyneham, he said:
The Government's proposal from the start has been to target the issue in total and the only way you can do that is not just to have disclosure but to contain campaign costs.

I emphasise the words `to contain campaign costs'. In question No. 6, once again Senator Bolkus makes reference to grappling with the costs of campaigning. Senator Bolkus puts the emphasis on containing costs, as he has done in other public statements and in this place.

I would now like to take the Senate through some of the costs of campaigning. I want to emphasise particularly how this Bill will transfer the costs of election campaigning to the taxpayer, the public purse, rather than campaigners raising money by means such as donations and functions. I will compare the costs of campaigning in Sydney and Perth, and the number of constituents in each. The figures that I cite do not include production costs. They are the actual costs of having advertisements shown or getting direct mail out.

In Sydney the cost of four 30-second spots of prime time television advertising is $50,700. For radio advertising the cost of 30 spots on top rating stations in Sydney is $9,200. For press advertising in Sydney, the cost of full pages in most popular tabloids, as I said, excluding production costs, is $11,600. Now we move to what the emphasis will change to-that is, public purse expenditure. The cost of direct mail to households in Sydney, which number 1,252,000, is $137,700. If we look at personalised direct mail, which the Labor Party has specialised in in recent times--

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the former Leader of the National Party?
—I am not defending the former Leader of the National Party.
—I am delighted to hear that.

—I am talking about the costs here. I am not defending anybody. I am pointing out the facts. Obviously, the facts have sunk in a little. The cost of personalised direct mail, which the Labor Party has specialised in, for those 1,252,000 households is $538,300. In other words, for one personalised letter to all householders in Sydney, there could be 36 television advertisements in prime time or 510 radio advertisements.

SPEECH.PARA: But the fundamental difference-and what has to be emphasised-is that it is a transferral of the cost of election campaigning to the public purse. The Australian public should not be fooled. We have seen preparation for this transferral in recent times, and the Minister is not going to deny that, is he?

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not listening to you.

—The Minister pricked up his ears. Let us look at Perth, the capital city of my State. On the same basis, the cost of television advertising is $15,900; radio advertising, $4,600; press advertising, $4,900; and direct mail, $40,800. The cost of personalised direct mail to the 371,000 households in Perth is $159,500.

SPEECH.PARA: Putting aside all the other arguments that have been put forward, I suggest that this proposal would increase the cost of election campaigning because the main means of communication with the electorate will be forced to be through direct mail and personalised direct mail. That will have to be done in the election campaign context-and it will happen; people should make no mistake about that. It is happening now. But I re-emphasise the point that that will be paid for primarily from the public purse.

No doubt we will have the Bill back before us and we will argue points other than the details. I support the position to refer this Bill to a committee-a position that we on this side of the chamber have adopted for a significant period of time-but re-emphasise that I do not believe that this move will, as Senator Bolkus claims, reduce the cost of campaigning. In fact, it could well increase it, but at the expense of the taxpayers of Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are not debating the Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures Bill 1991 at this stage, but we are debating whether it gets referred to a committee. The purpose of the Bill is notionally to impose a ban on the broadcast of political advertisements, to strengthen the rules relating to donations received by political parties and to increase public funding for each Senate vote. That is how the Australian Labor Party would have us describe the Bill and, albeit rather pathetically and without much gusto, that is how it has tried to sell it to the Australian electorate. That, at least, is what it was saying until the end of last week. It is said that a week is a long time in politics, and nowhere is that better applied than to the Labor Party. But we all know the real story behind this legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: The simple fact is that the Labor Party is on the nose around Australia, even in States where it holds government. Even in those States, its hold is fairly tenuous. In Western Australia, Victoria, South Australia and Tasmania, the prospect of going to the polls is frightening because the Labor Party knows that it will be resoundingly and deservedly thrashed in those States. The money makers of the Labor Party, my colleagues on the other side of this chamber, have lost their enthusiasm for their jobs. They are under the scrutiny of various royal commissions and the like. The fact that there are no Brian Burkes raking in the lolly over cosy lunches any more is obviously worrying the Party in government here. Those days are over, and the local bagmen do not have the charisma to entice too many people to the dinner table.

The hard fact is that the various State offices of the ALP are still trying to pay off the excesses of the last Federal election campaign. Some say that the Party is $7m in debt. Some other people say that it may be $17m in debt. But I do not think it matters whether it is $17m or whatever. Maybe $17m is close to the mark.

Against that background, we have been brought back here this week to talk about this Bill. We have been called back to Canberra a week ahead of schedule because the Federal Government was convinced it had to have this political broadcasting ban Bill put through. Government members have had two months to change their minds, but Senator Bolkus obviously could not be bothered with work during the recess and clearly only put his mind to his job last week-or maybe he put his mind to the job when the Australian Democrats decided that they were going to have a leadership tussle. Maybe that changed his mind. I do not quite know what changed his mind. It might have been that Senator Parer and Senator Olsen have done such a good job in exposing what the ALP is trying to do to the Australian people. I think that probably has a lot to do with it.

It is only since the end of perhaps last week that we have heard from the Government or from the Minister on what is supposedly the burning issue for the Government of the day. Since the end of last week two entirely different positions have been put before us. Two months ago, any talk of sending this legislation to a committee or of curtailing the ban to an election period only was cynically dismissed by the Government. In fact, it was basically thrown out by the Government at the time. We were told that we could not do that because-and remember this-the Bill was all about preventing corruption at the Federal political level. But since last week all that seems to have changed. Apparently we are no longer worried about corruption outside an election period and now it may be a good idea to send the Bill to a committee. So things have changed quite dramatically.

Is it any wonder that the Australian electorate is fed up with governments? It is a pity that Senator Bolkus is not here because I think he would have learnt a little from the speeches made during this debate. Senator Crane gave a good speech a short time ago. Senator Bolkus cannot honestly think that people out in the real world will believe him when he takes one position on this legislation one day, another tomorrow and a third the following day. The Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters has already examined political advertising. That Committee said that banning political advertising would be a denial of free speech. Are we now to assume that this Committee has changed its mind? We should not forget that the ALP was represented on that Committee.

The ALP would know all about doing favours for people in the corporate sector. It also knows that those corporate figures who supported the ALP so generously in the past are unlikely to do so in the future. Many of the cosy mates of the Prime Minister and the Labor Government who so generously supported the Labor Party in the past are now bankrupt or in gaol or have woken up to the fact that the ALP will not win another term, so they are asking themselves why they should waste their money by donating it to the Labor Party. If the Government had wanted to send this Bill to a committee, it could have done so during the recess and we could today have been debating the final outcome of the Bill, or we could all be in our electorates talking to our constituents, where we like to spend a great deal of our time.

This legislation remains an attack on free speech and the basic freedoms associated with democracy. It presents horrific problems for people in the country areas in that during an election period the only source of communication that many people in outback areas have is television or radio. Those people will be denied hearing about the parliamentarians standing for election in their areas because advertising will not be allowed if the Labor Party gets its way with this Bill. The view of the Human Rights Commission and of many professors of law at several universities around Australia is that this legislation represents a denial of free speech. This Government is again wasting taxpayers' money. All it is doing is shuffling the chairs on the deck of the Titanic. If this legislation does not come back from the proposed committee completely dead, it will definitely be defeated in this place.

I will finish on the point made by the National Secretariat of the Salvation Army in a letter that was sent to many of us just recently. I will quote that letter again because I think it is worth quoting. It says:
The Salvation Army has a further concern as the Bill affects the illiterate within our society who depend so much on the electronic media for their understanding of community issues.

If this Bill were to go through, that opportunity would be denied to people who are illiterate or to those in the country areas who have access only to the electronic media. All that will be allowed is talkback radio or people being seen on particular shows on television. I suppose the Government would have a bit of a start in that instance, and that is why it wants to ban any advertising on the electronic media.

TALK.START.PARA: —Television political advertisements are pretty intellectual stuff!

—I suppose it comes down to how one takes them. If the Labor Government worried about fixing up the third runway at Mascot instead of about some of the other things it worries about, we would have a lot of good things done for this country. If Government senators read about that issue while sitting at their desks, that will be a great help to us. The argument for political advertising has been well and truly put during this debate by many other people. I support the speakers from this side of the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to rise this afternoon to speak on the Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures Bill 1991. I am sorry that I have to do so in the present circumstance. This piece of legislation is the most sleazy, sordid and grotty measure to have been introduced into this Parliament in my 10 precious years in this place. It is designed for two purposes. The first is to overcome the acute financial dilemma in which the Labor Party finds itself-the bankruptcy into which it has plunged itself. The second is to be seen to be cleansing the Labor Party of the machinations and the imbroglio that are consuming it from the west coast of this nation. The Labor Party is attempting to be seen to be on the side of the angels when the vast majority of its funding has come, no doubt, from those on the west coast.

SPEECH.PARA: Labor is already in debt. It knows that its financial base, its capacity to raise funds, is totally exhausted. Labor asks itself in a pragmatic way where it will get funding for the next election that will compete with that of the Liberal Party, modest as our resources are. Under Labor big business becomes small business. The big businesses that are left would never support Labor under any circumstance. When Labor looks at small business it sees record bankruptcies. It sees small businesses closing down every day, taking down the shingle. It asks itself, `Is that a source of funding for us?'. Of course it is not. If the businesses that are left could afford to fund anybody, they would be funding alternative parties.

The Labor Party then turns to the untaxed, traditional source of funding, the trade union movement. It sees a million people out of work. It is not just in percentage terms that the workers of this country, few as they are, are leaving the trade union movement. The aggregate percentage of people in the trade union movement has dropped dramatically because people are now in the unemployment ranks. They are not paying their union dues; they are trying to scratch together a few dollars to buy bread for their family.

The Labor Party knows that it has no economic capacity, no financial base, no ability to mount a competitive campaign for the next election. We have been told by Senator Schacht and Labor senators who have been audacious enough to try to justify this cynical piece of legislation that there is a touch of altruism about it, that it is actually intended for the good of this country. That is breathtaking in its audacity. The truth of the matter is that if the Labor Party were altruistic, if it believed this legislation had some intrinsic virtue, it would have introduced it eight years ago. Eight years ago Labor was more popular than it is now. There was a more benign and misled community, prepared in part to finance the Labor Party. But the Labor Party knows now that it cannot get financing, and it is trying to find a way of creating an even playing field. That does not mean simply that both parties are on the same plateau; it means that the Labor Party denies all other political parties any advertising, which, of course, means any funding.

As a result of that cynical, crude attempt at bludgeoning the community into ignorance, this Government is prepared to smother freedom of speech. It is prepared to snuff out the essential, legitimate right of freedom of expression. It is prepared to strike at the very heart of the first basic freedom. While we have this Government pontificating, strutting around the world stage, hectoring South Africa because the black community does not have the freedom of a vote, the Labor Party in this country is denying the essence of freedom of speech, the freedom of knowledge and the freedom of getting of wisdom.

TALK.START.PARA: —Television ads?

—Senator Collins says, in a very cynical way, `television ads'. I heard him interject earlier and say, `Whoever learns anything from television ads?'. If the Labor Party thinks it is a waste of money and a waste of time, why does it not simply stop advertising?
—Because everyone else does it.

—In other words, if I jumped off a cliff Senator Collins would follow me because everybody else was doing it. It is an absurd, illogical argument, as Senator Collins knows. The reason this Government fell into office at the last election was because of those outrageous advertisements which showed the Liberal Party blowing up Kakadu National Park and destroying the fabric up there which we had seen in such a pristine state.
—Blowing up Kakadu National Park?

—Senator Collins did not see the advertisements. I would like to think that if he had, he would have been outraged. It was those advertisements which convinced people to support the minor parties who were putting the Labor Party ahead of the Liberal Party, and in blessed ignorance people thought they were voting against both the major parties when in essence, of course, they were voting for the Labor Party. There was nothing clever about it. That is exactly what happened.

SPEECH.PARA: Here we have this Government now seeking to deny people the right to freedom of speech. What is the price which is being paid to remove and trade off this intrinsic right? It is a last, desperate, dying act by a decadent, corrupt, illegitimate and discredited Government going through the death rattles but trying to find--

TALK.START.PARA: —Corrupt?
—Morally corrupt.
—You're talking about moral corruption?
—Anybody who comes into this Parliament and argues that there is some altruistic, legitimate, genuine purpose for this outrageous legislation is morally corrupt.
—Are you the benchmark for what we should all aspire to, Senator Crichton-Browne?

—I know it is out of Senator Collins's grasp and reach, but I would recommend it to him. This is a blatant and crude attempt to hide the truth about this Government from voters. This proposal, of course, is a stark contradiction. I love this about the left wing of the ALP: it is the first in the vanguard with these tricks, and these deals and these whiz-bang, clever manoeuvres to hang on desperately to office, yet it goes out with this heart-rending care for the right of expression, the right to freedom, the right to representation and the very right to life itself. The moment there is a little angle to be had to survive, all that goes out the window and we find these sorts of tricks.

SPEECH.PARA: Where are these members of the left wing when it comes to the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights which says:
Everyone shall have the right to freedom of expression;
It does not say, `except for television advertising during election times when the Labor Party cannot afford it'.

. . . this right shall include the freedom to seek, receive and impart information and ideas of all kinds, regardless of frontiers, either orally, in writing or in print, in the form of art, or through any other media of his choice.

In other words, it enshrines the right of people to the getting of wisdom, to the getting of knowledge, to the getting of information-the right that this mob, this Government, would deny them because it cannot compete in terms of dollars and cents. For a crude political purpose it is snuffing out a fundamental right which men over the centuries have died for.

TALK.START.PARA: —You want to stick to the golden rule.
—I am sticking to the golden rule. I am sticking to the truth and I am sticking to the legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course, without freedom of speech there cannot be freedom of elections. Without the right of communication, without the right of transfer of information, nobody could be genuine in the claim that there could be free elections. A free election is about competition for ideas. A free election is about exposing one's philosophies and ideals and policies to the public in each and every forum. It is about the competition between conflicting philosophies and ideals and policies. It is about the interaction amongst voters; intellectual intercourse between members of parliament, candidates and the public.

It is about exposing voters to what one believes in, to what one's ideals are, to what one aspires to and to what one offers people. It is about parading that which one represents in all forums. In modern society a fundamental part of the transfer of knowledge is communication through the television screen. A free election is about having the opposition-whoever it might be-scrutinise and criticise and examine the policies which are being put up. It is about assisting the public in arriving, at the end of the day, at what they judge to be, on balance, a sensible conclusion in terms of the competition being offered between the conflicting political parties and their candidates.

When one takes away the capacity to impart that knowledge, as this legislation would have us do, one takes away the right of individuals and the right of the community to make those judgments. They are being asked to make those judgments in darkness and in barren ignorance. That is the last, desperate throw of the dice of this Government. Frankly, if it could get away with it, it would abolish polling booth workers because it will be short of them too this time around. It would abolish how-to-vote cards.

TALK.START.PARA: —We would.

—Absolutely. It would abolish any mechanism which allows the public to be exposed to the ideas and recommendations of any political party. This Government would simply have it as a raffle, as a roll of the dice, as people going to the polling booths in ignorance.
—Better than harassment, isn't it?

—I do not know the purpose of that interjection, but I am sure if it is to have some meaning for me Senator Kernot will expose me to it when she speaks. I do not know what harassment she is talking about, but simply having somebody talk through a television screen hardly--
—What about at the polling booth?

—From my observations, I think that people are attracted to having a choice. They are attracted to having proffered to them a how-to-vote card. It might well be that citizen X is one of that rare, not yet totally extinct, species which might be going to vote on the Senate ticket for the Labor Party. That person trusts, in good faith-misguided though he might be-that the Labor Party's recommendations on the how-to-vote card for its Senate ticket is the way it judges will best help it to be elected. He does not want to make a mistake; he wants to faithfully fill in the how-to-vote card as the Labor Party would have it.

SPEECH.PARA: To that extent he is very glad to go to somebody who has a Labor lapel badge and take a how-to-vote card, although it was rather confusing at the last election because Labor Party workers took `Labor' off. It was really on the nose. One had to be a detective to find out who the Labor Party workers were. It was only because one could see `Labor' in the small print on the how-to-vote card that one actually knew who was handing them out. There are compelling reasons for having polling workers and for handing out how-to-vote cards. If the Labor Party could do away with all those devices-

TALK.START.PARA: —We have yet to hear them in this debate.

—I will not be distracted. I have 15 minutes to go and I promised I would be only five minutes. That is a different issue. But I am simply saying that it is a mechanism to allow for a greater awareness in making an informed vote. It is an extension, another step. We might say that it is harassment or people imposing their will on people, but at least it is another step.

SPEECH.PARA: I understand that the minor parties are not happy with it because, by and large, it means that they have to compete numerically with the major parties. That is always a difficulty.

TALK.START.PARA: —You could have them in the polling booths.
—That could be done. I would have them in the polling booths and I would have them handed out as well.
—You wouldn't have to cut down all those trees.

—I notice how that concerns us all for convenience on appropriate occasions. As I said earlier, the truth of the matter is that this Government limped into office last time only on the tragic but blind ignorance of a section of the community. I do not say that by way of criticism. Ignorance is not a criticism: it is an objective description.
—Only the smart ones voted for you.

—That is not true. I am saying that when the Labor Party came to the conclusion that people were leaving it in droves and would not be voting for it, it had to convince people to vote for the minor parties. When the present Government came to the conclusion that it could not get people to put it as number one on the ticket, it went to the minor parties and, having bribed and bought off most of them, it had them put Labor ahead of Liberal on the how-to-vote card and it then persuaded people to vote for it. There was nothing very subtle, intelligent or clever about it, but it worked. As a result of that, this Government limped over the line.

SPEECH.PARA: It convinced people to vote for the minor parties through those obscene television commercials which, as I said earlier, showed us blowing up Crocodile Dundee's home territory. That is how the Government was elected-by using the television; the ads that never worked. I am of the view that almost everything on television affects somebody, somehow, in some way, for some reason.

This Government, being intellectually and financially bankrupt, now wants an even playing field. It knows that dollars follow votes. It knows that when it is up in the polls, it is a sign that small business people and other members of the community will assist the funding of its campaigns.

Government members are terrorised by the ground swell of opinion against them this time around. They can see a great big wall of water about to dump on them. The Government knows that this community will pay anything to get rid of it. Pensioners will donate whatever is left of their cheques to guarantee, ensure, contribute and add to this lot being dumped ignominiously out of office. It knows that none of those contributions will be made out to the Labor Party.

So how does it stop us? It simply takes away the source of the funding. It takes away the area where people would be spending their money. That is what it is all about-nothing more, nothing less. It is a crude, cynical, sleazy scheme to ensure that there is no advertising and that people will not make the judgment about the Government that they should. Not only does it deny advertising to political parties; it denies groups in the community with a strong political view putting that forward on the television screen and conveying what used to be taken for granted-freedom of speech, the right of expression, the right of transfer of information and the right of transfer of knowledge. This Government would cynically take it away for the grotty endeavour of being returned yet again to visit a plague upon this country.

In conclusion, I will touch on the question of public disclosure. In essence, I think there is a community view in this chamber about the need to tighten the disclosure of funding of political parties, because the present system, as it works, ensures that in some way certain donations will not be shown to be accountable. I am not saying that that is illegitimate, but it is part of the nature of the present creature of legislation that we have.

This is a new-found sense of altruism that is causing blushes on the cheeks of members of the Labor Party. It is not one that has worried them before. It comes for two reasons. As I said from the outset, the first is to be seen to be cleansing themselves from the inevitable tide of discontent visiting the body politic generally, arising from WA Inc.-a royal commission, by and large, about the activity of the Labor Party in office, an examination of its relationship with big business and the community generally. Some revelations thus far could lead one to conclude superficially that it is not what it should have been.

There is a general view in the community that all is not well with the financial relationship between the Government and business. In a very superficial way-I put it no higher than that-it has already touched the Federal Government. When we get to the point where it is big news because a major donor is photographed in the same fishing boat as the Prime Minister, we can see the political hype that can be stimulated and created with this issue. The Government is not unaware of that. So, to be seen to be doing something constructive and positive, to be distancing itself from the inevitable trauma that is going to unfold over the coming months in Western Australia, it has proposed that we have a more substantial form of disclosure of funding.

With respect, it would be unwise, misleading and almost foolhardy for anybody to believe that public disclosure prevents corruption, because crooked people do not fill in a form saying, `$300,000 bribe, but do not tell anybody. I am filling in the form as the Act demands'. Those things go unannounced and unreported. To that extent, any amount of demand of disclosure will not prevent any corruption, any impropriety or any offences under any Act.

TALK.START.PARA: —It will increase the risk, surely.
—In my view, hypothetically, if people were prepared to take a half million dollar bribe, it would be my guess that they would not be tempered by the demand for that to be disclosed.
—As a campaign donation.

—Perhaps I am not understanding the point that Senator Collins is seeking to make, but I cannot see that in any way it would inhibit misconduct between the donee and the donor. I think that if people are prepared to give something to a member of parliament in a way which is illegal, they would not be worried about the necessity for declaration of the payment. In other words, the essence of corruption--
—I would.

—Surely Senator Collins is not arguing that someone who was going to take a half a million dollar bribe would say, `I won't do that, because I have to fill in a form saying that I have done it'. To that extent, I do not believe that it is going to deal with the problems.
—It allows people to make their own judgments about the connection between donations made and political decisions made.
—That point appears to be lost.

—I do not assume that everybody is corrupt. I was focusing on what effect disclosures would have on corruption. Senator Kernot is quite right in saying that it would expose the financial relationship between a political party in government and business. But I assume that, if the funding is given in a proper way and it is declared, it would not be anything else other than of acute curiosity to the public. It would not establish prima facie-and that is what we have to be very careful about-any sense of impropriety or misconduct by the recipient. If Robert Holmes a Court or his estate gave $1m to the Labor Party, I would not jump to the conclusion that there was something corrupt in that relationship. That is the difference between the giving on the one hand and the giving on the other.
—At least you would know about it.
—One would know about it and it might cause the public to salivate, but--
—It is free speech, is it not?

—I am not suggesting that I disagree. I started from the outset by arguing in support of wider disclosure. I was simply making the inevitable point that, if there are those who think that WA Inc. would not have happened if we did not have disclosure, they are very wrong. But to the extent that there is a taint and a stench about it that has been visited on this Government and that its members have felt the necessity to distance themselves, that is the essential reason for it. If there had been a more altruistic reason for imposing disclosure, they would have found it eight years ago. Another transcending and compelling reason for their disclosing is that they have nothing to disclose.

SPEECH.PARA: I cannot imagine any well judged, well run and well balanced business giving any money to the Labor Party after the last eight years. I cannot imagine any small business that would be so inclined as to make another contribution, unless it is masochistic. As for the million people who are unemployed, it is highly unlikely that any ground swell of opinion from the general public will bring a flood of money to the Labor Party's coffers. So the Government can expect a nil return.

This situation is what one would call in the newfound language of modern society a `win-win position' for members of the Labor Party. They have taken away from other political parties the need for funding, which places all political parties on an equal footing in terms of campaigning. It also distances them from WA Inc. and gives the impression of newfound integrity.The disclosures that they will have to make this time around-I suspect with the most elastic of imaginations-will not be able to imply that there is any improper conduct because those relationships will not exist. As I said from the outset, I find this a very sleazy and sordid arrangement which has been entered into by members of this Government for the purpose of preventing its death rattles becoming absolutely and inevitably mortal.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —On commencing my speech on the Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures Bill, I return to what Senator Schacht said a little earlier. He gave us a great diatribe as to why this ban on political advertising should be legislated for. What I could not understand was that all he said could have applied in 1983, 1984, 1987 or any time around then. Yet neither this Government nor the Australian Democrats, to my knowledge, said anything whatsoever at the time. Senator Schacht then said that he wanted everyone to have the right of equal access to material throughout Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: With that in mind, and in case the Democrats failed to send this legislation off to a committee or, indeed, helped the Government put the legislation through, I took some figures out. If we ban electronic advertising, we have to rely entirely on the print media. I took figures out that affected the rural and remote areas of Western Australia because the cities have proper access to newsprint if they so want it. I believe, and I can prove by these figures, that the remote and rural areas would be mostly affected.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do they have direct mail out there?

—Yes, we have mail out there, but there are different stages of mail for different areas. What is the point in getting a newspaper-even if one wants it-when it is a week old? If Senator Kernot is patient, I will come to that point in a minute.

SPEECH.PARA: The commercial television channels and the ABC provide television services in Western Australia to 426,000 people outside the cities-that is, outside the metropolitan area. However, in this case, we are looking only at the commercial stations. One hundred and fifty-six thousand people live in what I class as remote areas. In addition, there is piggyback carriage of that television coverage onto the satellite, which transmits programs to those in really remote areas such as mining camps, et cetera.

The banning of political advertising on electronic media will deprive the rights of those people in remote areas to access current information about the political parties, current affairs, et cetera. I found from my figures that 18 per cent of the city population, or 25 per cent of the voting population, buys a daily newspaper. I certainly had no idea that the percentage was so low. If there were a ban on electronic media, people could turn around and buy a newspaper, if it were available-they will certainly be available in the city-to learn about the latest news or advertising. But in remote areas it is far different.

In comparison to the 18 per cent in the city who buy a newspaper, only 13 per cent of the population in the remote areas have available, and buy, a newspaper. This means that 79 per cent of country voters do not receive a daily newspaper. As I said, even if many of them wanted to, they could not because they are in remote areas.

In comparison, access to the electronic media is almost 100 per cent because as well as the normal commercial broadcasts in electronic media there is the satellite, as I have said. Through the satellite, people can access both radio and television. If people have the necessary equipment, 100 per cent of Western Australia has access to electronic media.

As I said, newspapers are either late or not available in remote areas. When they are available in certain towns, they cannot be distributed out to the stations, mining camps, et cetera. I will give an example. I have examined different shires. Residents throughout the State in some towns-for example, from Kununurra to Esperance-receive daily newspapers. Outside those areas in the smaller communities, such as the Aboriginal communities, people may see one newspaper a week via mail runs and that sort of thing. Mining camps, individual prospectors and road gangs are all definitely cut off from receiving newspapers. This means that the vast majority of those 340,000 rural voters are without newsprint.

For example, in the Shire of Halls Creek, only people in the town have access to newspapers, yet the shire-which is right at the top of the Kimberleys, almost into the Northern Territory-has a population of 2,000. The town would have probably 100 to 150 people, and they are the only ones in that shire who have access to newspapers. Therefore, at least 1,500 people out of that 2,000 would certainly not have either daily or even weekly access to a newspaper. So it is useless for either the Government or anyone else to say that we could move over to newsprint and it would be cheaper to run. It can be done but people will not have equal access, and Senator Schacht did say that he believed everyone should have equal access.

These figures can be repeated for various communities, such as Wiluna and Warburton, which I will not bore honourable senators with at this stage. I believe that a paid advertising ban, as well as being discriminatory in whom it may reach, is certainly a blot on our democratic right to publicly express views critical of government. It will deprive groups as a whole of their right to comment. Honourable senators may remember the campaign by a national motoring association during the last election. I believe it was very effective in convincing the Government that more money had to be spent on roads. Such groups will be heavily disadvantaged.

If political parties have not had the skills in the past to manage their campaign funds and have overspent their budgets, then I do not believe their burden should be carried by all Australians. I know that in the flush of the 1980s there was a lot more money coming forward for these campaigns than at other times. Unfortunately, in this case the Labor Party seemed to budget on that sort of money coming through forever.

Mr Acting Deputy President, you know how much the Labor Party outspent the Opposition in the 1987 and 1990 elections. Unfortunately for the Labor Party, that money is not coming through any more. Senator Bolkus wants to use this ban to get over that problem by preventing the Opposition, and maybe the Democrats, from putting their views on how the Government has operated in the last 10 years. Then in the dying stages of the game, leading up to this week's sittings we had different moves to keep this Bill alive.

Forgive me if I am not totally correct in my understanding because I have just come back from a reasonably lengthy period overseas with a parliamentary delegation, but I understand that one move was to ban political advertising in the last three months leading up to an election. No-one has called out that that is wrong. The only person in Australia who knows when an election is coming is the Prime Minister. He is the only one who knows when it is coming. So the party in government can work out a good advertising campaign, because it knows within three months when there is going to be an election, and can leave the opposition of the day lamenting. If an advertising campaign were in place, would a Prime Minister be prevented from calling an election within three months? That is a question I would like answered. I do not think it is the way to go. I believe it is nothing but a suppression of freedom of expression.

The parliamentary delegation of which I was a member went to Eastern Europe and saw the result of 45 years of communist government. If honourable senators want to see what 45 years of suppression has done to four nations that we visited, then I suggest they visit those places to see for themselves. A friend of mine, the late Andrew Mensaros, who died about two months ago, came from Eastern Europe. He suffered first under the Nazis and then under communism. He managed to escape and then came to Australia. He was the first non-British, non-Celtic born person elected to a Parliament in Australia. He always used to tell me and others that Australians took their freedoms too lightly.

Every time a Bill which concerned freedom came before the Western Australian Parliament-and he had a lot to say when the Australia Card debate was on-he would be the first to speak out. He always spoke out the most in Western Australia because he believed we take our freedom too lightly. In this case the Opposition is not taking it too lightly, but certainly some Australians are. It is another freedom that we will lose if we do not watch what we are doing. If we lose it, then it will be one freedom that will be very hard to get back.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —At this stage in the debate there is little that I can contribute that is new. My colleagues have covered the debate very carefully and skilfully. But I want to clarify, from the meanderings that have come from the Government benches, what the argument of those opposite is. As I understand their argument, they are saying that free speech must be banned because it costs money: advertising free speech costs money; therefore it must be banned, because to cost money causes corruption, and corruption is bad for the state; corruption is bad for the Government and therefore we must ban free speech and ban advertising so that the state will not be corrupted. As I understand it, in a nutshell, those are the meanderings that have come from those opposite.

SPEECH.PARA: Put another way, what that seems to say is this: free expression could seriously threaten the state; overall personal liberty depends upon the degree of freedom that can be enjoyed by the nation; therefore, the freedom of the individual will be narrower the greater the danger to the state. That is what I understand the argument of the Government to be. If that is the Government's argument, can I say to you, Mr Acting Deputy President, that it is not a new argument. It is an argument that is some decades old now. I will quote from this article:

He argued that the free expression of opinion could seriously threaten the state, and that personal liberty depended upon the degree of freedom that `can be enjoyed by the nation, and the freedom of the individual will be the narrower the greater the dangers are that temporarily threaten the state'.

That is the same argument, as I understand, that the Government is putting. This is not a new argument. This is one that Joseph Goebbels put when he banned free speech in Germany just before the Second World War. That quote was from a book titled Nazi Propaganda by Z.A.B. Zeman. It is published in association with the Wiener Library, London Oxford University Press, 1964. That suggestion of limiting free speech because the greater interests of the state are involved is one that must be, and has to be, rejected at all times. It was an argument that, as well as being put by this Government, was put by a regime that will go down in history as the greatest undemocratic and dictatorial regime in our history, a regime that quickly brought in the one-party state and caused the murders of some six million people. It shows that we must be forever vigilant against any limitation at all of our freedom of expression.

One cannot limit freedom of expression one little bit without starting to lose the freedoms we enjoy. Any limitation, no matter how small, must be rejected and rejected at all cost. We must never countenance anything-any government action-that limits free speech in any way because it has been done before and is the first action that people intent on one-party states, on dictatorships, and on completely undemocratic regimes embark upon. I do not suggest that this Government intends to go that far, but once one gives away some of one's liberties, one has given away some of the freedoms one enjoy. That must never be allowed to happen in Australia.
Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Powell's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.PARA: Original question resolved in the affirmative.

That leave of absence be granted to Senator Janet Powell for the period from 15-16 August 1991, inclusive, on account of family illness.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I want to pursue the matter raised with you this morning, Mr President, concerning the industrial dispute and the disruption caused to senators in the course of their duties. I understood that you were having meetings today and were going to report back to the Senate, and I invite you to do so. In particular, I am now advised that taxis are not attending the Senate entrance because of damage that has apparently been caused to them as a result of doing so before. If picketers are damaging taxis, that is something that you should bring to our attention in the report that I hope you are now going to give to us.
—Senator Hill, if you will give me another quarter of an hour I will give you that report. I still have some people in my office; they are just about to leave.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 6 June, on motion by Senator Collins:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition supports the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation Bill. We will have a couple of amendments but they do not diminish the thrust of our support in any way. The Opposition's support for the Bill is significant because it is the first time in eight years that there has been bipartisan support for a major piece of Aboriginal affairs legislation. This has developed largely because of the volume of discourse between the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Tickner) and the shadow Minister for Aboriginal affairs, the honourable member for Chisholm (Dr Wooldridge), as both sides of the Parliament have sought to end up with a package that would have bipartisan support.

SPEECH.PARA: There is no doubt that when the matter was first raised there were some concerns on this side of the chamber. In demonstrating how talking together about these matters can be of use, it is only right to mention that there were concerns and that discourse between the two sides of the Parliament has removed them as far as almost every member is concerned.

There was concern earlier that the Council could be a body for activists and that it could end up like another Constitutional Commission doing its own thing and not really aware of the imperative put on it by the political process. As I said, many of us were concerned as to what it might actually achieve on the ground for Aboriginal people. As a result of that hard work on both sides, the Council stands a chance of setting new ground for Commonwealth advisory bodies in terms of its focus, its goals, and, hopefully, its outcome. That is the basic bottom line of this matter.

The key question we have to ask ourselves when looking at this kind of legislation is: are we doing things that will make things better or worse for the Aboriginal people and for those white Australians who are involved with and concerned for the Aboriginal people and the society as a whole?

The Opposition is particularly pleased that the Council will focus its work mainly on a process of reconciliation at a community level rather than at some other exalted level. Where things have worked well in the past, they have done so because people at a community level have made the effort to get along in solving their own problems. In the past, at the community level, many things worked in spite of governments, not because of them-and, I might say, without being too critical, in spite of some things that this Government has done, not because of them. We are overjoyed to see that the concentration of this council will be at the community level.

The Opposition also had a concern about not wanting to raise the hopes and expectations of Aboriginal people only to see them dashed. This is certainly the clear message that the Opposition has received from Aboriginal people and organisations when consulting them about this Bill. We must avoid that, and I think we have done so. The concern that expectations should not rise too much was one reason our shadow Minister in the House of Representatives, Dr Wooldridge, worked very hard with the Minister in trying to develop a common interest and to put behind a lot of the political animosity that has existed in the past eight years, in particular, in relation to Aboriginal affairs.

There is no doubt that if anything is to be achieved in the area of Aboriginal affairs it must be through simple practical solutions with realistic, measurable and achievable goals, with cooperation rather than confrontation and with hard work free from political bickering. One of the reasons we wish to move an amendment to this legislation is to establish those clear goals. The second amendment that I intend to move will be to add new clause 6(1) (k), that the Council should:
. . . monitor and evaluate:
(i) the implementation of benchmarks in relation to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander well-being, as agreed by Commonwealth, State and Territory Governments; and
(ii) the progress towards achieving those benchmarks.

TALK.START.PARA: —Have you circulated those amendments?
—Yes, I hope they have been circulated.
—It does not appear as though they have been circulated.
—In that case, I ask the Clerk to circulate them. I understand that they have been on the Clerk's desk for quite some time.

SPEECH.PARA: Another amendment which I intend to move relates to the rewards that should be given to people who are on this Council. I do not think that these are petty; they are quite significant. When the whole question of the Council first came up in the Government's discussion paper back in December, I-like, I think, all Opposition members-was particularly pleased that no fees were intended to be paid to members of the Council. In essence, this was because the Council was going to comprise a group of prominent Australians, giving their time voluntarily to try to achieve something worthwhile in this important area.

In the past, committees of government have been open to the criticism that they exist as an end in themselves, rather than to try to achieve something really worth while. While the Opposition does not want people to be out of pocket for serving on such a committee, they should not, in our view, make money out of it. We do not want to see this as another `jobs for the boys' situation.

As a result, we will be moving an amendment, which I hope is being circulated, which says that a person other than an ex-officio member of the Council who is a member of the Council or a member of a committee, or who is both, is to be reimbursed the expenses that the person reasonably incurs in performing duties under this legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I might just clarify the question of the circulation of your amendments, Senator Baume. They were circulated yesterday. It may be that some senators did not bring them into the chamber. However, they were circulated and everyone should have a copy.

—Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President. I regret to say that I do not have any further copies with me. I will be moving the amendments in the committee stage; I just thought I would mention them at this point in the second reading debate. By the way, the reason for the first amendment-that is, that there should be benchmarks-is that there always seems to be an expectation, particularly in matters affecting Aboriginal affairs, that the process of assistance somehow equals the outcome. As Dr Wooldridge outlined, when in the past he has asked questions of ATSIC about outcomes, he has generally got piles of facts and figures as to how the Government is doing things, but they do not say what the Government is actually achieving.

SPEECH.PARA: As I said earlier, we have to concentrate on the question of whether everything we are doing is making things better or worse. It is absolutely fundamental that there should be benchmarks by which we can see whether we are making things better or worse. I agree with Dr Wooldridge that the impression of many people in matters relating to Aboriginal affairs is that a lot of governmental actions over recent years have made things worse rather than better, that things have been going backwards despite all our best endeavours. Unfortunately, we have no objective way of working out where we really are, where we are coming from and where we are going to. That is one of the reasons why we think this amendment is absolutely vital.

The Opposition is hopeful that the Council will provide some leadership within the Aboriginal community. That is desperately needed in Aboriginal Australia and in the broader community today so that the whole community might take a fresh look at itself, its history and its hopes for the future. This somewhat hybrid Bill, which has been a product of Government and Opposition cooperation and bipartisanship, should--

TALK.START.PARA: —Multipartisanship.

—I will take the Democrats' point-multipartisanship. It should at last give us something of a win in Aboriginal affairs. As I said, the general perception is that government intervention has tended to make things worse in terms of the relationship between the Aboriginal community and the rest of Australia. I believe and the Opposition believes that this Council provides an opportunity to make things better. It does not guarantee that things will get better; it does not mean that no more work has to be done. On all these matters it is the bottom line that matters-the bottom line of whether we are improving the prospects of reconciliation, the prospects of relationships between the Aboriginal community and the rest of Australia. On balance, because of the manner in which this Council has been born out of a bipartisan or multipartisan approach, depending on which view one takes, it should have a much greater chance of success than the approaches that have so largely failed in the past. To that extent, the Opposition wishes the Council well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALK.START.PARA: —In my remarks I want to concentrate on the philosophical underpinning of the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation Bill, which is, quite literally, historic legislation. I am very pleased to be able to add the support of the Australian Democrats for this Bill to that of the Opposition and the Government in a multipartisan way. The establishment of a Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation also represents a significant achievement for the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Mr Tickner, and I congratulate him on his commitment to getting this Council established.

SPEECH.PARA: Despite the strong support from the Democrats and me for this initiative, at the outset I must confess to some mixed feelings. I would like to stress strong support but at the same time express a few concerns about what must not be allowed to happen, and then to outline briefly some of the things I would like to see achieved through the establishment of this Council. It is an important event, a vital event. It provides a golden opportunity to address constructively the many problems still facing the indigenous people of this nation in a comprehensive and long term fashion.

I am very pleased to note that the preamble to this Bill makes a specific commitment to addressing the disadvantages faced by Aboriginal and Islander people. The fear I have, and one that I have already heard expressed by some Aboriginal and Islander people and taken up by Senator Michael Baume, is that the Council may degenerate into another bureaucratic talk-fest and travelling circus. I know that no-one wants this to happen, and many people who spoke to this Bill in the lower House have already stressed the need for the Bill to achieve concrete results. However, once the process is under way and some of the spirit of cooperation and mutual congratulation, which is occurring now, is replaced by emerging political differences, a possible result is for the whole procedure to deteriorate into posturing and rhetoric. We have seen it all happen before.

The Opposition spokesperson on Aboriginal affairs in the lower House, Dr Woolridge, indicated in his speech in the second reading debate that an increasing atmosphere of suspicion has built up in relation to Aboriginal and Islander issues among many indigenous people as well as others in our society. It is important to understand that if this Council, which has so much potential, fails to deliver, it will mean not only that a golden opportunity has gone begging but also that further damage has been done to relations between the Aboriginal and Islander community and the non-indigenous community, with further suspicion ensuing. It will also mean that the Government's ability effectively to address the disadvantaged position of indigenous people will be further weakened. This would be a disastrous outcome.

I have commenced my speech on this negative note because I believe that it is crucial that this Council not be allowed to fail. The history of Australia's treatment of its indigenous people since European settlement is one of virtually uninterrupted disaster. Even in the past 30 or so years, when serious attempts have been made to start redressing the vast injustices of the past, our record has still been abysmal. The opportunity presented to us by this Council must not be wasted.

Let this not, though, take anything away from the great opportunities which are presented by the establishment of this Council with the universal support of parliament. This is a major, positive initiative which must be given strong support by politicians and Australians across the social spectrum. The reports of the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody-many of us spoke about them in this place, and we know them to be comprehensive and in-depth reports-describe the reconciliation process as the fundamental backdrop to reform and change.

As the Minister has noted, the final recommendation of the Royal Commission strongly supports an effective reconciliation process. The final recommendation states that all political leaders and their parties should recognise that reconciliation between the Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal communities in Australia must be achieved. This is essential if community discord, division and injustice to Aboriginal people are to be avoided.

Another recent report-that of the national inquiry into racist violence-found that racist violence is an endemic problem for Aboriginal and Islander people in all Australian States and Territories. It also concluded that racist attitudes and practices-conscious and unconscious-pervade our institutions, both public and private. There can be no clearer indication that this is a major need which must be addressed if we are to substantially reduce it within our own lifetimes.

Addressing the problems which face Aboriginal and Islander people requires more than just a set of ideals and good intentions. A lot of people have had those in the past. It requires political will on our part and a real commitment from all Australians to look again at their own attitudes and to willingly participate in creating essential changes. It is pleasing to see that the Bill makes provision for the Council to develop strategic plans for action in this regard.

This legislation is about process, but it is about goals as well. The process and the goals should both, as far as possible, allow Aboriginal and Islander people to determine the way they want their culture and lifestyle to interact with non-indigenous society, and the best way to address the massive and systematic disadvantage which so many of these people currently face. But in addressing this, the emphasis must not be on Aboriginal adaptation to our way.
