Dr Wooldridge made a reference at the end of his speech during the second reading debate to a speech that he had recently heard and found moving. This speech was by the Aboriginal Bishop Malcolm from the Anglican Church, and it outlined the Bishop's hopes for the future. Bishop Malcolm acknowledged that everyone must look to the future and that the past cannot be undone, but he said that the first essential step for Aboriginal people towards a better future is for white people to simply say sorry. This does not mean endless waves of guilt-ridden, public self-flagellation as some might suggest. It simply means acknowledging that great wrongs have been done and that as a people we regret those wrongs. It also means learning from the past in order to create a better viable future for all of us.

A similar theme is contained in the well known quotation by Xavier Herbert. Although the quotation relates specifically to land rights, I want to repeat it here because it so effectively captures the spirit which I believe must pervade the reconciliation process. Xavier Herbert said:

Until we give back to Aborigines just a bit of the land that was theirs, and give it back without provisos, without strings to snatch it back, with complete generosity of spirit, in concession for the evil we have done him-until we do that, we shall remain what we have always been so far, a people without integrity, not a Nation, but a community of thieves.

That is a well known quotation. While I know there are some Australians who will not agree with the arguments in favour of land rights-and let me stress that land rights are not a predetermined outcome of this Council's deliberations-nevertheless, I hope that all Australians would agree with the need for a complete generosity of spirit and the need to admit and apologise for the damage that has been done. In an age of so-called economic rationalism, generosity of spirit could well be a bit of a foreign concept.

Even those who see the marketplace as a sacred site must see that assisting and supporting a process of reconciliation between Aboriginal and Islander people and the rest of the people of our nation makes economic sense. Supporting self-determination for Aboriginal and Islander people; improving communication and interaction between the indigenous peoples and the wider community; enabling Aboriginal and Islander people to participate in our society in a way that is meaningful to them-all of this should be achievable through the process we are now enacting, and such an outcome can only lead to a nation which is healthier, both socially and economically.

Despite what is often said about the recognition of cultural difference and cultural pluralism in Australia, it is clear that mainstream culture in Australia does not accept Aboriginal culture as a legitimate and separate culture. Mainstream culture is exploitative and is orientated towards economic and material values, and the difference is well exemplified by our attitude to land. This is also the case in relation to a number of other cultural elements. It is, therefore, important in the Democrats' view to recognise and maintain that cultural difference.

I would like to make special mention of the role of the Torres Strait Islander people in this process. Being so far away from where most Australians live, and being so few in number-I think they total 30,000-Torres Strait Islanders are often forgotten, yet they are a people with a distinct culture and history and they are fiercely and justifiably proud of this. Although it is not reflected in the title of this Bill, the Council is intended to involve Islander people as well as Aboriginal people. I am sure Islander people will play a valuable role in the process over the rest of this decade.

There is another important component of the reconciliation process which has not received much attention to date. In addition to the widely acknowledged need to develop and establish reconciliation between the indigenous and non-indigenous peoples, there is a need for reconciliation between the Aboriginal people and the Torres Strait Islander people themselves-I think they call it sweeping their own house clean first. There are two distinct groups, with their own history and culture, and they have some ongoing differences. It is important that the process gives both groups the opportunity to resolve these. I know this is something which many people, particularly in Queensland, want to address, and I hope they can address it through this Council.

Another distinct group of people is South Sea Islanders. These are people whose descendants were brought to Australia forcibly and they are not strictly indigenous people of this country, yet strong cultural identification between South Sea Islanders and Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders exists, and these people, too, suffer similar discrimination and disadvantage. As with our indigenous people, exploitation of their labour contributed significantly to the economic development of our nation. Their role in this process is less clear, but I still hope that it will be given consideration.

It is no great statement to say that we, as part of what is broadly called European or Western society, have a lot to learn from the cultures of Aboriginal and Islander people. Yet the level of ignorance within our society about the history, culture and current disadvantaged position of Aboriginal and Islander people is still shameful. It is, therefore, pleasing to see that the Minister has indicated that education is to be a central role of the Council. This education must reach not only the younger generation but also the adults of our society who are not undertaking formal education.

The important role of the media in the educative process is obvious and I strongly urge workers, educators, managers and owners of the media-all two of them-to take this role seriously. Both the Royal Commission and the inquiry into racist violence addressed many of their recommendations to the media, but I have yet to see or hear many indications that these have been noted, or that any follow-up on their implementation has been undertaken. I appeal to the media industry to recognise its responsibility in this area.

I remind the Parliament as a whole that, as I have just indicated with the media, we also have a major responsibility not just to support this Council but to continue showing our commitment to tackling the major problems that exist now. There are many fundamental issues which need to be addressed and actions that need to be taken now. I am not going to press them at the moment, but I am certainly going to do my best to make sure that they are addressed as part of my nomination to the Council and my contribution to it.

If we need convincing that governments still have a long way to go to showing true commitment to building bridges between the indigenous and non-indigenous people in this country, we have to look only at the atrocious actions of the Goss Labor Government in Queensland in relation to land rights legislation. Here is a party that has unambiguously promised clear-cut action for many years, and it has received the electoral support of the majority of Aboriginal and Islander people over that time as a result. Once in power, out came the grand statements that it would deliver on its promise. Yet within the space of a very short time, the promises are broken and the Party's policy ignored.

Leaving aside the pros and cons of the broader issue of land rights and the final shape of the legislation, I want to argue that the damage caused by the divisive process of this legislation to the black community's perceptions of government and our society was immense. The consultation process, on which we are placing a great store here, was farcical, with mining companies, pastoralists and environmentalists all being given a better hearing than the indigenous community. The legislation was rushed through in a way that would have made former Premier Bjelke-Petersen blush.

What sort of message does this give when we are trying to convince Aboriginal and Islander people that our intentions are genuine and honourable? Ironically, this legislation in Queensland was being rammed through Parliament in its divisive way at the same time as the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation Bill-which is all about consultation, reconciliation and long term aims-was being debated here in the House of Representatives. As Mr Bob Katter said at the time, and as Dr Wooldridge also implied in his speech, in many ways it is far worse to raise hopes with grand promises and statements and then fail to deliver than it is to do very little. We must ensure this does not happen on this occasion. It is part of the nature of this process to raise expectations and it is our duty to strive to fulfil them.

I have read the speeches by Minister Tickner and by Dr Wooldridge very closely and I note the different things they are looking for from this process. Whilst there may be some differences between them, these are certainly not incompatible. I know that both men have had to do some negotiating within their own parties, and with each other, in order to get agreement to this legislation, and I congratulate them for their efforts. I was pleased to see the Minister strongly stress the need for continuing the fight to address disadvantage, and I am sure he realises that he still has a lot of convincing to do-even within his own Government-to get these matters addressed more seriously than they currently are.

I also acknowledge the aims and hopes for this process which the coalition expressed through Dr Wooldridge's speech. He also expressed the necessity for concrete achievements and specific goals, and I support that intention. I notice that the coalition also gained an amendment to the Bill which allows the nomination of a member of the Council who is not a member of parliament. I think it would be a shame if the coalition were not to have a representative from the parliament on the Council as I feel it would diminish the spirit of parliamentary cooperation which we have established with the passage of this Bill.

The coalition has also stressed the need for the Council to focus and operate at a community grass roots level-Senator Baume mentioned that-and it has made this a condition of its support for the process. I acknowledge the intent behind this condition as being a good one, but I do have some worry that the coalition might stick too exclusively to this. As Father Frank Brennan said recently in an article in the Catholic Leader:
. . . social change and reconciliation have to work on many levels-personal and local levels, but also structural and national levels.

I note that many people, including Mr Hawke, Dr Hewson and Commissioner Elliott Johnston have been making the point that the approach should concentrate on the process of reconciliation and not on any instrument which might be an outcome of the process.

Whilst I do not wish to go against this sensible approach and attempt to pre-empt any outcome, I would remind the Senate that a resolution was adopted by this House at the time the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Bill passed through this chamber. This resolution concluded with the words that:
. . . an instrument of understanding and reconciliation with the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples should be negotiated by the Australian Government.

I know those words `an instrument of reconciliation' were the words of Senator Coulter. Whilst I know some people do not place much significance on the resolutions of this place or the words of politicians, I would hope that we would all at least keep this resolution in mind and not just allow it to become, again, the mere words of politicians.

The task ahead is a difficult one and 2001 is not far away at all, but I believe there are sufficient signs to give hope that substantial achievements can be gained through the process which we are starting here tonight. The fact that all parties are supportive of the process sends a message to all Australians that we need to join together to work for understanding and justice for Australia's indigenous people. The fact that indigenous cultures in our country have managed to survive so well in the face of so many obstacles is a tribute to the perseverance and the determination of the indigenous people to overcome injustice.

There has been much talk lately of the need to make Australia a republic by the Centenary of Federation in 2001. Whilst this is a matter of importance, it will be a hollow celebration if we were to become a republic without making substantial progress towards redressing the many injustices which the original inhabitants of this country have had to endure. In 1988 we were exhorted to participate in the celebration of a nation. As we look to 2001, our sights must be set on the creation of a nation. The Council for Reconciliation must be at the centre of this. As the Minister said, this is a process which the whole nation must embrace, and it is a process which must not be allowed to fail.
Debate (on motion by Senator Faulkner) adjourned.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I did give notice to Senator Hill's office that I was going to make this statement. The Speaker and I have just concluded a meeting with representatives of the Trades and Labour Council and the Federated Liquor and Allied Industries Employees Union of Australia. A number of issues were raised at the meeting. The Speaker and I are seeking further advice on the issues raised. We asked the unions to lift the picket line but they said they would not.

INTERJECT.PARA: Concerns about transport were raised with me. I have been advised by the taxi company that no taxis have been damaged. However, the taxi company has advised that taxis will not cross the picket line. The current situation is that there will be Commonwealth cars and taxis to take senators and staff home this evening from the Melbourne Avenue entrance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the statement.

Mr President, the statement that you have just made to the Senate raises a number of issues with regard to the operation of the Senate. This has been an ongoing saga over the last few days. I think the issue of primary concern to all honourable senators is that issue relating to transport. In your statement you made the point that transport this evening would be available only from Melbourne Avenue adjacent to the parliamentary precincts because the Comcars and the taxis would now not cross the picket line.

This raises a number of very serious issues regarding the operation of the Parliament-ongoing issues raised by a number of honourable senators. It would appear that, unfortunately, the situation is deteriorating considerably as this matter continues without adequate and proper resolution.

Therefore, it is incumbent on all honourable senators to seriously consider the issues and to solicit from you and Mr Speaker whether it is intended that there will be further statements or negotiations on the discussions that you have been having or that could be anticipated in the near future.

TALK.START.PARA: —Top speech, this.

—It is a most important issue. I trust there will be speakers from the Government side regarding this particular issue. It is important to note that the Minister for Administrative Services (Senator Bolkus), who has a great deal of responsibility in this matter to ensure that services are provided properly and adequately to the Parliament, has not yet made any statement to follow up on the issues that were quite rightly raised yesterday in this Parliament, or have been addressed a number of times by you, Mr President, in all of the statements that you have made both yesterday and today. Senator Bolkus has not responded in any way, as should be his due and proper ministerial responsibility, on this particular issue. It is most important that issues relating to the proper operation of the Senate should not be allowed to further deteriorate.

—Can you advise me, Mr President, whether you and the Speaker of the House of Representatives have given any attention to the need to ask the Australian Federal Police to clear the pickets off the road so that transport can move freely along the roads and the approach to and from Parliament House is unimpeded? What is the position regarding the police? Have the police been asked to intervene?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I also raise with you a matter which I raised with your office. In view of the unsatisfactory nature of getting honourable senators to Parliament House, would the Department of the Senate be prepared to allow honourable senators to hire Z-cars or self-drive cars so that those of us who wish to drive ourselves to Parliament House, without the inconvenience of having to walk down the road late at night with the dangers and security problems--

SPEECH.PARA: Government senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!

—I do not think this is particularly funny. It is a serious suggestion that I am making to the President and one that I would hope the President might address. I suggest, Mr President, that it is one way the difficulties with Comcars, with taxis and with the pickets could be overcome, so that honourable senators are able to attend this chamber without the danger and inconvenience that are presently being thrust upon them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I find this an absolutely intolerable situation. We are not talking about the blockading or picketing of some little fish and chips shop in the suburbs. We are talking about a blockade of the Parliament. It is absolutely intolerable that you, as a Presiding Officer, and the Ministers of this Government will take no action to guarantee free access to the Parliament. This Government could not import people fast enough to break a strike that took place about a year ago. The Government turned out the armed services so that services could be provided. What was involved in that instance was something far less than a blockade of the Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: Why is not something being done in this circumstance? On the admission of the Australian Labor Party, we are faced with an illegal strike. I do not know the mythology and the hagiography of what the Labor Party goes on with. But apparently this strike has no substance at all. It has gone before the Australian Industrial Relations Commission, which has found that there is no basis for it at all and that the people involved should all return to work. The people involved in the strike were allegedly employed in this building. The Commonwealth car drivers have nothing at all to do with it. Yet, they are taking part in a secondary boycott.

Mr President, why will not you, as a Presiding Officer, guarantee free access to this Parliament? Why will not the Ministry enforce the right of passage of all the citizens of the ACT into Parliament House? I note that the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs (Senator Tate)-the Minister for Federal Police-has left the chamber. He has gone-the heat is too much for him. He, as a member of the ministry, has a responsibility, as does every other Minister of this Government, to see that the law is upheld. Why is nothing being done?

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I understand the difficulties with which you and Mr Speaker, as well as those who are negotiating on behalf of the employees concerned, are faced. I have been dropped at the Melbourne Avenue entrance to this place and have walked the distance. It is quite a nice bracing walk. I want to ask one question: why at 2.20, or thereabouts, this afternoon did Comcar No.C1 pass through the picket lines and enter the executive part of this building?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen W.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is not an argument or a discussion about whether someone has to walk 50 metres or 100 metres. It is about anarchy and who is running this place. It is about support for the decision which was found to be legal by the Australian Industrial Relations Commission. If people have a problem with that decision, the correct process, as everybody on the other side of this place knows, is to appeal that decision to the full bench of the Industrial Relations Commission.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr President, I am putting it to you that it is time to move and stop this nonsense. I sympathise with the people out there. But I also sympathise with the other 800,000 people in this country who do not have a job. That has nothing to do with the decision that you have made; it has a hell of a lot to do with the decisions that have been made by the people who sit on the other side of this chamber.

I am putting it to you, Mr President, that the time has come to stop this rot. This is no example to set to every other industry in this country at this time or, for that matter, at any other time. The people involved in this dispute are clearly in breach of the law of the land-the Trade Practices Act and the common law.

Sir, it is incumbent upon you to take action to get rid of this nonsense. If necessary, these people should be advised of the legal avenues that are open to them. I have no problem with that. But I cannot sit in this place and not voice my concern at the fact that the people who work here and the operations of parliament-the business that runs Australia-are being impeded through lawlessness and anarchy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I think it is quite clear to everybody in the chamber that you are in a very difficult position. You have acted over the last couple of days in an exemplary fashion in the way that an industrial dispute should be treated. You have tried to reconcile the parties and those that may take up positions behind them-where there is a dispute, it is a very difficult matter to deal with-and you have done that with considerable patience.

SPEECH.PARA: In my view, the situation has not become inflamed, as it might well have become inflamed had you taken actions different from those which you in fact have. I think it is in the interests of everybody in this chamber and in this Parliament that you continue your patient struggle to achieve reconciliation.

I can sympathise with people. People do not like walking in the night air. People like to have their towels and papers. I also understand-I do not contradict this for one minute-that people on the opposite side are not getting up and speaking in this way because of any personal interest in their own comfort or catering to their own sense of dignity. They are trying to vindicate their positions as elected representatives of Australia.

They do not see this action-and I say this advisedly-of some people on the picket line, waiters and waitresses, to make honourable senators walk 500 metres or so as an insult to themselves or to their own dignity but as an insult to the people of Australia whom they so competently represent. I venture to say that if we had asked the people of Australia, in a situation where their stalwart and worthy representatives had to walk half a kilometre--

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not the point.

—I know it is not the point. This is the proposition I am putting to Australia. They would say that the action that you have taken is the proper action to take. One of the problems with which you, Mr President, are faced is that people on all sides have not got a proper appreciation of the facts. Honourable senators on the other side have said that the Australian Industrial Relations Commission has decided the issue. As you, Mr President, know-and this is the unfortunate position with which you have been left-the Industrial Relations Commission has decided no such thing. The Industrial Relations Commission has decided that it has no jurisdiction to decide this issue. If one reads what Mr Commissioner Smith said, he said that he has considerable sympathy for the people on the picket line and that if he had jurisdiction he might well make an order varying the award.

SPEECH.PARA: Reading between the lines, Senator Crane, who is a man vastly experienced in this area, would tell us that the Commission, if it had jurisdiction, might well have made an order that is sympathetic to these people, these waiters, who have never been on a big sum of money-whatever they had has now been taken from them-and that their proposition could have merited a variation of the award. Mr President, you have been left in a situation where you have not got the help of the Commission.

TALK.START.PARA: —Take it back where it belongs.

—The matter cannot go back to the Commission where it belongs because the Commission has said that it has no jurisdiction. How can the Commission decide an issue over which it has no jurisdiction? It is a bit like saying, `Why don't you try somebody for a crime when you've got no jurisdiction to do it?'. The issue is not whether a person has committed a crime; the issue is whether or not the court has jurisdiction. What is being denied the President in this case is the ability to have somebody outside decide this issue. It has been thrown back into his court.

SPEECH.PARA: I know from personal experience that the President has vast sympathy with people who work and he has vast sympathy with this chamber over which he has so meritoriously presided. Nobody has said that he has not presided but with great dignity and great distinction over a number of years. He is in a dilemma and I do not think it helps him for us to get up and ask him why he does not do something when he does not have any power to do anything, other than to negotiate the matter through. It has been said that this is a secondary boycott. That would need to be argued. The people on the picket line seem to want to get their jobs back.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, it is the drivers, taxis and all sorts of things.

—That is exactly what a picket line is about; it seeks some sympathy. The Comcars are not refusing to pick us up; they are refusing to pick us up at a particular point. We cannot be too precious about all this. We are able to debate this issue: the dispute has not stopped the essential work of the Parliament. This Parliament has proceeded, as it does, in all its glory. There has been magnificent debate today on several issues.
—Not on this one.

—Except for my contribution. The reality is that we are able to proceed. I do not suggest it is done deliberately, but I get the impression from the preconcepts, presuppositions and ideals which shine through on this side from time to time and from the preconceptions and philosophies which those opposite hold, which come through sometimes-as Senator Harradine suggested so well-that the degree of difficulty we are experiencing is pretty small. We are able to legislate and we are able to carry on the business of the country.

SPEECH.PARA: I confess that I have considerable sympathy for people who have never been on a big wage being thrown out of work. I think it is tragic to see people having to stay in the cold to try to vindicate their position. That is their only way of fighting. There is no other way they can do it because the Commission will not hear them. We need to show the tolerance we have shown so far and get behind the President and endorse the considerable action that he has already taken.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would have to differ with much of what Senator Cooney said. This is not a difficult problem of principle. We can all have sympathy with those who have lost their jobs. These people appear to have lost their jobs through some confusion and mishandling over contractual discussions. The facts are clear and they are: the Parliament and its workings are being impeded and parliamentarians are being impeded in going about their proper business on behalf of the people of Australia. I suggest to you, Mr President, that you have a very clear duty of principle in this regard. Your high office demands that you take action to protect this Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: I say that because, although at the moment the Parliament continues to work, it will establish a very clear precedent in this country. If people believe that, if they have a grievance against the Parliament and the individuals in the Parliament, they are entitled to mount a blockade, it will not be the finish of the matter when this sorry event is cleared up; it will start a precedent which will come to haunt this country and this Parliament. This is one of those issues upon which the Presiding Officers have to take a proper stand. Their duty is to the Parliament-not to the Labor Party and the conventions and practices of the Labor Party. There is no question of that in my mind.

So, Mr President, I ask you two questions: have you contemplated legal action or any other remedy; and, further, if you have not, have you sought legal advice about the remedies which may be available to you in this matter? If you have not done that, my third question is: will you seek that advice?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —It seems to me that what we have from the Opposition in this debate is hyperbole based on exaggeration. Honourable senators are talking about a blockade of the Parliament. I have to say that if any trade union or any other group of people wanted to blockade the Parliament they could do it a lot better than is happening right now.

SPEECH.PARA: What is happening now is that a group of workers, who are in an extremely difficult situation, are coping with an industrial dispute and are taking legitimate industrial action. I defend their right to take it. That picket line out there is not blockading the Parliament. It is not preventing the Parliament from discharging its democratic obligations. The President has said he will ensure, while he is the President, that industrial disputes do not prevent the Parliament from discharging its obligations, and he is right to say that.

Within that constraint, I support the workers' right to take the action that they are taking. What I reject entirely is the slathering enthusiasm of those in the Opposition to inflame this dispute. Those opposite live in fear and trepidation that it might be settled reasonably, that the negotiations which Mr President is patiently undertaking-which are the appropriate means of coping with this difficult situation-may resolve it reasonably, with a reasonable outcome for the workers and the Parliament. That is the way in which all industrial disputes-including this one-are best settled.

I need to deal with one other matter that has been raised in this debate and that is the question of car C1. I am told that that particular vehicle did pass the picket line. The problem for all those people who got excited about it is that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has been in Melbourne for the last two days and is still there. The car had no passengers. I am advised that the car did not break the picket line. It certainly did not carry the Prime Minister across the picket line.

TALK.START.PARA: —What was it doing there?
—I am trying to inquire into that. It is nothing unusual for an empty car-a car not carrying passengers or goods-to drive across.
—Did you search the boot?
—You are as full as a boot.
—I thank my colleagues for their support.
—I ask Senator Faulkner to withdraw that remark.
—I withdraw, Mr President.

—My colleague may have been provoked, but nevertheless it was appropriate that the remark was withdrawn. I simply want to clarify the matter that was raised which might otherwise have created a false impression. There has not been any breach of the picket line by the Prime Minister or anybody associated with him.

SPEECH.PARA: I simply reiterate the point that was made more extensively by my colleague Senator Cooney that this Parliament continues to be capable of discharging its functions. I advise all honourable senators -I am sure that this will fill them with delight-that the Senate will also be sitting on Friday of this week in order to discharge its obligations. It will be perfectly able to do so, picket line or not. Inflammatory speeches in this chamber will do nothing to assist that matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are a number of matters that I would like to address briefly. The first is that I was disappointed that Senator Cooney made allegations of a lack of sympathy for people who have lost their jobs. I think that is irrelevant to this debate. As was said by one of my colleagues, we have sympathy not only for these people but also for the 800,000 to one million other Australians who are out of work at the moment.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not want to try to apportion sympathy. I do not want honourable senators to misinterpret what I have said, but at least these individuals have received a termination package, which is far more than what most of the other 800,000 Australians who are currently out of work have received. So I do not think the crocodile tears that we see on the other side are well founded because, if this Government really had sympathy for workers who are out of employment at the moment, it has within its resources the ability to do something about it. It could start next week with the Budget, because it is largely its economic policies that have got Australia in this tragic situation at the moment.

Let us put the situation of individual workers aside for the moment because there is a matter of principle involved here, and I think that is where we on this side of the chamber differ from those on the other side. We believe that, as a matter of principle, it is wrong to blockade or otherwise impede access to the Parliament. We can argue about the degree of blockade or the degree of obstruction-and it may be that the degree of obstruction here is not as great as it would be if there were a line of trucks placed across the road or some other more vigorous enforcement of this line-but that does not seem to me to render the argument wrong. The argument is that it is wrong in principle that the Parliament be obstructed.

What we have said to you, Mr President, is that if the Parliament is obstructed we believe that you, as the Presiding Officer, and your colleague, as the Presiding Officer in the other place, have a responsibility to remove that obstruction. Mr President, I acknowledge that it seems that you have been seeking to negotiate removal of this picket. You said to us yesterday that, after the resolution by the IRC, the picket should be removed. You said to us today that you have asked that the picket be removed, and it has not been removed. The question that therefore occurs to me is whether you have asked the Government for assistance; whether you have asked the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs (Senator Tate), who is responsible for the Australian Federal Police, for assistance; and what action you have in fact taken to ensure that this wrongful obstruction to the Parliament is removed. I ask that question because my colleagues and I would like to know what action you have taken in that regard, and we would like to know what reaction you have received from the Government in that regard.

Mr President, as you said to us yesterday, Government senators were a party to this original decision. You communicated with all honourable senators and got very little adverse reaction from Government senators. Now that we have got to this stage, it seems that you need the support of the Government for the removal of this picket. Until you tell us otherwise we will presume, particularly on the basis of what Senator Bolkus said yesterday, that the Government is not prepared to support you in the removal of the picket.

In answering that, Mr President, I ask that you answer one further question, because we on this side of the chamber are unclear as to what is now being sought in this dispute. The workers who have been dismissed have been paid a compensation package. The new contractor is now in possession and meeting the contractual responsibilities. You say to us tonight that you are continuing to negotiate in this dispute. What is being sought by those with whom you are negotiating? The two questions that I respectfully request be answered are as follows: firstly, is the Government supporting you in seeing that this picket is removed; and, secondly, what is now being sought by those who are continuing the dispute?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a couple of brief comments to make on this matter. The fact that Senator Kemp was standing there and making the speech that he made a while ago is proof positive that this picket line is not interfering with the processes of this Parliament. Senator Kemp was arguing that it was.
—You always miss the point.
—I did not miss the point at all. The point is that Senator Kemp was misrepresenting the situation.
—There is no argument that there is a picket line.

—I know that, and there is also no argument-the proof is here-that it is not emasculating this process. The fact that Senator Kemp was participating in this debate is proof positive that the picket line is not emasculating our process. It is inconveniencing us, but it is not emasculating us, and it is misrepresenting the situation to suggest that it is.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the most spectacular processes which occurred around this place was when there were literally hundreds of loggers' trucks outside. By jove, the argument of those opposite was different then! In fact, I do not think that it was an argument at all, because it was a cause that they identified with. Let us not be hypocritical about this matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —You could get into the building then.
—Senator Macdonald is in the building now and he is taking part in this debate. Opposition members are not even logically consistent.
—Get your facts straight.

—I have got the facts straight; Senator Kemp does not have the facts straight. I suggest that the facts are quite clear and that if anybody has misconstrued the facts it is people like Senator Kemp. A very important point is escaping us all. A lot of people who are participating in this process are not on strike; they are unemployed. Only a matter of days ago they were working for us and they had done so for months-and in some cases for years. It is beholden upon us to realise that we are talking about a special group of people. They are not at all a remote group of people; they are people who have served us well until very recently.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn to a point that Senator Hill raised. Just yesterday we were discussing an urgency motion about the plight of unemployed people in this nation. Crocodile tears were flooding from the opposition benches yesterday. Opposition members were citing the fact that we have hundreds of thousands of unemployed people. What they are looking at outside these doors is a very small group of unemployed people that used to be employed by us and served us as recently as a few weeks ago.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are missing the point, Paul.

—I am not missing the point at all. The point is that there is a very human, very real and very close dimension to what we are confronted with. It is misrepresenting and ignoring that to say that this picket line is seriously dislocating the processes of this chamber, because it is clearly not doing so. If we are going to be fair about this issue, we have to acknowledge who the people are, acknowledge the fact that many of them are unemployed and acknowledge the fact that they have served us well until quite recently.
—I acknowledge that.
—If Senator Archer acknowledges those things, he is looking at the human dimension of the picket line out there.
—That is not the point.

—That is the point. This picket line is about people expressing real dimensions of their lives. Most picket lines are about that. Sometimes, of course, they are about sheer pigheadedness, but this one is not. Unless we are prepared to acknowledge those simple realities, we are not being fair to the people out the front, nor are we being intellectually honest with ourselves.

—Mr President, last night when you had to vacate the chair to carry out further negotiations, I suggested that it would be simple, prior to the adjournment of the Senate, for you to approach the Minister for Finance (Mr Willis) and the Department of Finance, who overrode your and Mr Speaker's negotiations. I ask whether you have indeed asked the Minister for Finance to support the negotiations that you and Mr Speaker have had with the staff in good faith. If you have done so, what was his answer?

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —With respect, I wish very briefly to respond to one statement made by the Leader of the Opposition, Senator Hill, when he insisted on the removal of the picket line because he regarded it as an affront to this Parliament. I must say, Mr President-and this is a view I have held for a very long time, in respect not only of this Parliament but also of the old Parliament-that it is my opinion that when free citizens in a free society use the Parliament as a focus for protest it is a public affirmation of the strength of this institution, not an affront to it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Nobody would argue with the proposition and general principle that Senator Collins has just put. We are arguing about the situation which occurs when the people's right to protest, the people's right to express their own point of view, the people's exercising of what they claim to be their democratic right, impinges upon somebody else's rights and somebody else's responsibilities.
—Having to walk 50 yards!

—It is a totally different issue. Senator Collins thinks we can measure who is right and who is wrong by how far we have to walk. It is a bit like Senator McLean arguing that there is some merit in breaking the law if it happens to be somebody we know or somebody who has worked for us for a long time. I think that is an absurd proposition to put, with respect. Senator McLean does not have a mortgage on caring for these people, or their affection or relationships. But that is not the point. It is not a question of whether their cause is right or wrong. That is not what it is all about. It is a trite thing to say, and it could be said by the other side, but this debate in terms of who says what is thoroughly and absolutely predictable. If anybody on this side of the chamber dared to say that the union movement was breaking the law, that person would be automatically regarded as a union basher and Government senators would jump up and defend this breaking of the law because they felt that they had to take the union movement's side, to defend it against us.
—Except if you are an airline pilot.
—Except the airline pilots, yes.
—What law have the picketers broken?

—They are interfering. I will not allow that interjection to distract me. If Senator Sherry does not know what law they are breaking, let him ask Senator Cooney. It seems to me, Mr President, with respect, that your capacity to manage and administer the precincts of the Parliament in respect of this matter is now thoroughly paralysed. Your capacity to make decisions has been hijacked by the TLC.

SPEECH.PARA: Without judging myself to be in any way an authority, I know just enough about this dispute to know, in watching the ABC news last night and watching the TLC delegate extolling his arguments to an unwitting constituency, that blatant lies were being told which fundamentally contradicted the truth which you, Mr President, articulated during the afternoon. I have now learned from a couple of other union representatives that they are equally as horrified about what the masses are being told.

I ask you, Mr President: at the end of the day do you propose to enforce the law? How do you propose to enforce the law? What do you propose to do about it? It is not a question of interfering with the rights of individual senators. It is not a question of whether we want to walk 50 yards. If that is the best argument the Government can come up with, it shows how intellectually barren the propositions it is putting to us are. I do not run eight kilometres every day and then complain about having to walk 50 metres-eight kilometres voluntarily and 50 metres under duress.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tell us about your fitness.
—You are an inspiration to us all.

—It is absurd when the very best argument that can be put up is to try to ridicule those who have the audacity to object to the conduct of those who are breaking the law and their impingement on the Parliament.
—What law are they breaking?
—I honestly despair when I am asked those questions.
—Just give us one.

—If the Commonwealth car drivers had sought to drive through the picket line, we know what would have been the result. The picketers are inhibiting free flow of traffic and movement. That traffic which is moving is moving with their consent and approval; without it, it cannot move. If honourable senators have not got the simple message of what law the picketers are breaking, they had better go back to school.

SPEECH.PARA: There is a suggestion that the picket line is only inhibiting the normal movement of honourable members and senators. That is not true. There is now an acute shortage of most goods in this place. In the next day or two, honourable senators will find that if they want any photocopying done they will have to go to the store where they will be given one piece of paper for their photocopying.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no shortage of our staple product-words.

—We are all here for different reasons, are we not? The bottom line is that it is having a significant effect. The tragedy with these debates-it is like talking about apartheid in South Africa-is that if you do not take one position, you are 100 per cent wrong. We are not arguing the rights and wrongs of the people in the dining room and we are not arguing about the decision that was made yesterday, we are arguing about the capacity to move freely in and out of this Parliament. If it were a bunch of truck drivers who were angry about the decisions that the Government was making on their licence fees, after a day or so their trucks would be dragged away and they would be dragged away with them. This bunch has become nothing more than an illegal lobby group.
—Did you say that to the loggers who were here?

—If they had interfered with me or anybody else, the answer would have been yes. There is one thing on which I cannot be judged and that is being selective in my morality. I regret that that is not a category I can put Senator Aulich into. They are nothing more than a bunch of lobbyists, seeking to impose their will and their point of view, by illegal and improper means, on the rest of the community.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not mind the fact that three-quarters of honourable senators opposite are here because they got the nod and the wink from the union movement that agreed to their endorsements. I do not mind them standing up and offering robust arguments on the unions' behalf. But if sitting there looking stupid and giggly, and whispering trite comments to each other goes to make up substantial intellectual debate, I have to say that the sooner they lose government the better.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McKiernan Sen J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the contribution I made on this subject last evening, I made the point that the dispute that has caused these picket lines would not be resolved in this chamber, in the other place or, indeed, within the Parliament itself. The contributions that I have heard this evening, with a few exceptions, endorse my view that I was accurate in what I said last evening.

SPEECH.PARA: The dispute will be solved when all parties to it sit down and work out a settlement. In that, Mr President, I wish you all the luck in the world and the wisdom of Solomon so that you will fulfil your role-as I know you will-to bring about an early solution to the dispute that is causing the problems at the moment. There are problems for honourable senators-there is no question that there is minor inconvenience to us. It is not the first time that we have suffered minor inconvenience in getting into this place to do our jobs.

Like every other senator in the place, yesterday morning I had to walk in from Melbourne Avenue and last night I had to walk out to Melbourne Avenue. This morning it proved to be a costly exercise for me as I walked in from Melbourne Avenue where the picket line is set up, because I was carrying my lunch-I had just been to the delicatessen-and, unfortunately, chocolate biscuits were on the top. I was encouraged to share the chocolate biscuits with the picketers-people who had served me my meals in this place. I had no problems in sharing with them or in exercising empathy with them. It is not the first picket line that I have ever been associated with and it will not be the last.

Mention was made earlier that some of us are crying crocodile tears over the plight that these people find themselves in. I am certainly not one of the people crying crocodile tears. I empathise with their position because I have been there myself-I have been made redundant-and I know the fear that runs through people's hearts when they know they have dependants for whom they have to provide. They cannot run back to their farms and undertake other occupations or live on savings because few of the people have any savings that will matter or that amount to much. One has to have been there to understand what is now going through the minds of these people.

I do not intend to go on for too long in this contribution. The point has been made about the inconvenience and the right of people to protest. I said earlier that it is not the first time we have suffered this interference. Not so very long ago when the weather was warm-and I stress that point-the whole of Parliament House was encircled by huge trucks. They blocked access to the Parliament-to the Senate entrance, the ministerial entrance, the Representatives entrance and the main entrance. We had to walk to get inside, but it was a joy to us because the weather was warm. Opposition senators are like the football supporters who support the home team when they are winning but cannot stand it when they are losing on a wet day. I had no problems in getting out of the car and walking into Parliament House because I supported the rights of the truckies to protest.

We also had the motorcyclists not so very long ago. They are beautiful people, every one of them. They came here with their protest about lights. They encircled the Parliament and gave us the noise as well as the beauty of their machines and personalities. They actually blocked the entrances. I was one of the people who had to walk a short distance. There was no problem; they had a right to protest. They were not damaging my person in any shape or form. They were inconveniencing me, but they were not hurting the Parliament.

Where were the screams from those opposite on those two instances when the Parliament was being threatened because we could not get to our jobs? The weather was warm. Maybe that was the reason there were no screams from the other side. Another incident I recall very vividly involved the farmers.

TALK.START.PARA: —The pilots strike.

—The pilots are coming. Let us go to the farmers first. Not only did they block the entrances to the old Parliament House some years ago but they actually came into the building and made themselves very comfortable in King's Hall. The citizens of Australia also have the right to do that. We did not, from this side of the chamber, protest about their actions because they were minor inconveniences to us on those days.

—I raise a point of order, Mr President. Senator McKiernan quite often has his facts about him when he makes statements, but that fact about the farmers blocking the old Parliament House is not correct. They did not impede the movement of people in or out.
—Order! There is no point of order. I cannot be responsible for what people say in speeches.

—I was invited to make some comment about the pilots. Some two years ago the pilots voluntarily gave up their jobs and brought the whole airline transport system in this country to a standstill. With the exception of Senator McMullan and a couple of the other local parliamentarians, we all have to travel by air to get here. Many of us ran into severe difficulties in getting to the job. If it had not been for the service of members of the Royal Australian Air Force, and we still remember them with-
—Affection.
—Affection-I thank Senator Collins-for the job and the role they played not on our behalf but on behalf of the people of Australia, we could never have got here.

SPEECH.PARA: They were carrying not only members of parliament but also people who were going on holidays for which they had saved. They were happy to reunite relatives around Australia. But at the same time they were hindering us from getting to Canberra. Senator Panizza, Senator Crichton-Browne and I had huge difficulties in getting from Western Australia to Canberra to be in attendance to fulfil our duties. Why were those opposite not screaming then?

TALK.START.PARA: —They were screaming at us.

—They were. It was not cold. Honourable senators did not have to walk 500 metres in the cold. There are double standards. We are politicians, and I suppose that a cynical electorate expects double standards from politicians. I think we are showing it here this evening. We are talking about a dispute involving a number of people who have lost their jobs and who are taking action to recover their jobs; that is what we are talking about. They are inconveniencing us; we are talking about it. We, the senators of the Parliament of Australia, are not going to resolve the matter. The President and his colleague the Speaker of the House of Representatives are in a position to do it.

SPEECH.PARA: I doubt very much, Mr President, whether anything that has been said in this chamber in recent times has aided your extremely difficult task in resolving this dispute. In conclusion, I hope, I wish and I pray that this particular dispute will be resolved in the very near future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —These will be the first words that I have ever spoken in the Senate concerning industrial relations, but I intend to say something because of the rubbish I have heard from Senators McLean and McKiernan tonight. In the comparison they made, part of Senator McKiernan's speech was rubbish and all of Senator McLean's speech was rubbish. I believe, rather modestly, that I have employed more people than anybody else in this chamber. I have never had an argument last more than five minutes that could not be settled across the table.

SPEECH.PARA: When I was listening to this debate in my office, I was annoyed to hear Senator McLean compare this protest and blockade with that of the loggers. Senator McLean and Senator McKiernan know as well as I do that the trucks blockaded nobody. Everyone was able to come and go at their will and they were not stopped at all. The loggers were peaceful and caused no trouble at all; they definitely did not stop mail coming in; they did not stop supplies to the dining room; they did not stop stationery supplies to any offices, or anything of that sort. Yet we have had Senators McKiernan and McLean comparing them with those picketers. It is a total disgrace to compare the picketers with the loggers' peaceful demonstration. Getting onto where I agree with Senator McKiernan, I respect the right of the picketers to protest. I support them 100 per cent to do what they want, but that does not give them the right to hold up the traffic going in and out of Parliament House. That is the difference between the loggers and the people out there at present.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to make a couple of comments. I think Senator Crichton-Browne's comments were highly offensive. To compare with a lobby group the workers who are legitimately on strike and picketing-I emphasise the word `legitimately', because I understand that a number of workers today did go on strike and left this building-is absolutely ridiculous. They have been serving us as employees in this place for goodness knows how many years that Senator Crichton-Browne has been here.

SPEECH.PARA: They are taking legitimate industrial action and they are picketing. That is not illegal in this country-not yet, anyway-at least until those opposite become the government, if they ever do. It is not illegal to picket and it is not illegal to strike. The logging trucks that were here were illegally parked. For some time they were blocking the traffic and they were certainly illegally parked. We did not hear cries from those opposite that those trucks were illegally parked or demands of the President to have them hauled away.

We did not hear any comment at all about those trucks being illegally parked. It is quite clear that they were illegally parked. It is quite clear now that there is legitimate industrial action, with workers on strike-not lobby groups-and they are picketing. Certainly, as far as I know, that is not illegal.

After I spoke last night there was some reference to these matters that I raised not having been raised before. For the record, I simply point out that most of the issues I raised last night were raised in writing with both the President and the Speaker when I became aware that the catering service was to be contracted out. I think I did that on 18 June. So I did inform the President and the Speaker of my concerns that I believed might arise, and unfortunately have arisen, because of this dispute.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I claim to have been misrepresented.
—The honourable senator may proceed.

—It was suggested a moment ago that I was claiming that people who had served on me were no more than a lobby group. Let me make it clear from the outset that the consideration of who has served on me and who has not served on me has no bearing on my view or the view of anybody else when we are trying to make impartial and objective judgments. You know that better than most, Mr President.

SPEECH.PARA: I described those TLC members, who were not employees up here and never have been, as no more than lobby groups, and they are not fulfilling legitimate industrial activity and conduct. If the honourable senator thinks that illegal conduct is legitimate industrial strife, I now understand what is wrong with Australia.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —The reality is, of course, that there is a picket line, and the reality is that the Speaker and I are trying to have that picket line lifted. The operations of the Parliament at this stage are not being seriously disrupted. I know it is difficult for honourable senators to walk down there to get a car, particularly this evening if it is raining, but the operations of the Parliament are not being seriously disrupted. That is not my opinion. I have sought the advice of the Joint House Department and the Department of the Senate. I spoke to the Black Rod just before I came in here about things like mail and printing paper. I can assure honourable senators that the operation of the Parliament is not being disrupted.

INTERJECT.PARA: Senator Newman asks me: has this been brought to the attention of the Federal Police, or have we asked the Federal Police to intervene? The answer at this stage is no, because I think all honourable senators ought to be aware of the potential for this dispute to escalate, and that is what we are trying to avoid. One does not have to go past the Commonwealth cars to realise that we are being driven to Melbourne Avenue, or wherever, by a Commonwealth car. Certain action could be taken and there might not be Commonwealth cars operating anywhere in Australia. I do not know, but there is great potential for this dispute to escalate.

Senator Kemp raised a number of issues. Let me just say to him that there have been many industrial disputes in the past in this Parliament that I can remember that have been more severe than this one-and I am not trying to play down the long term potential of this one-and the Parliament has continued to operate. The honourable senator asked me: are the Speaker and I seeking legal advice on these industrial issues at this stage? The answer is yes.

Senator Macdonald and Senator Harradine have raised issues. I believe that, as far as the Commonwealth car of the Prime Minister is concerned, that has been answered, even though we are continuing to carry out investigations as to why the car came in. I will certainly have the issue raised by Senator Macdonald investigated.

I am not sure that I really understood the issues raised by Senator Walters. I have not been to the Minister for Finance (Mr Willis) seeking extra funds as part of these negotiations. If I understood Senator Walters correctly, she is really saying that this dispute could be resolved by making additional payments to those people out of work.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, I did not.
—If I have got that wrong, I will have to discuss this issue with you as soon as the Senate rises this evening.
—What I asked, very briefly, is whether the Minister for Finance and the Department of Finance overrode your and Mr Speaker's negotiations on this issue.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —That is another issue. If I can just deal with it very briefly, the officers of Mr Speaker and myself, like other Ministers' officers, have to negotiate how much money we will get to run the Parliament. It is true that in negotiations with the Department of Finance we were told by the Department that we should seek a subsidy not exceeding $1m within a period of three years. I think that period was 1992-93. That was one of the issues that led Mr Speaker and I to look at contracting out the catering services.

INTERJECT.PARA: I turn to the issues raised by Senator Hill. He asked whether the Government was involved. Yes, it is involved because negotiations continue with Government Ministers. Unfortunately, when we tried to seek advice this afternoon from the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) we were advised that he had left to attend meetings in Melbourne with the ACTU. I assure Senator Hill that those discussions will continue when he is back on deck tomorrow.

Senator Hill asked what the unions want. Unfortunately, at this stage I am not able to deal with that question because the discussions we held this afternoon were discussions in confidence. However, there are some basic issues I must quickly refer to since Senator Hill referred to them. The issue was raised whether all the people have been paid who are supposed to have been paid. The union is saying that they have not. Another issue raised was whether they have been paid the correct amount. The union is saying that they have not. Those are two of the issues raised at the meeting this afternoon. I think you will all want Mr Speaker and I to seek advice to try to find out the correct situation.

As I have said, we are in a difficult situation. I do not believe at this stage that the operations of the Parliament are being severely disrupted. The discussions that Mr Speaker and I are having with our officers and with the unions will continue tonight and into tomorrow. I hope to be able to make a statement tomorrow afternoon. However, I must say at this stage that I am not confident that the pickets will be lifted at that stage.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Collins) proposed:
That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 8 November 1990 in a short adjournment speech I referred to a quest by Sonia Turkington of Como in Western Australia regarding Italian detainees during World War II whereby she was seeking recognition, some sort of reconciliation and function, for what had been done to them. That evening I was supported by Senator Macdonald, whom I hardly knew at the time-he had just come into the Senate-and later on Senator Robert Ray gave me some encouragement. I also gave a notice of motion, which was later declared formal and carried, concerning reconciliation towards those internees. The matter was also raised in the House of Representatives by Dr Woods, supported by Mr Ruddock and Mr Noel Hicks from the conservatives' side and Mr Sciacca, Mr Ronald Edwards and Mrs Crosio from the Government side.

SPEECH.PARA: Mrs Turkington pressed on with her reconciliation dinner. After this motion went through the Federal Parliament she asked the Western Australian Government to host that reconciliation dinner, which it did. The dinner was held on 8 August this year; it was attended by 67 internees and with their wives the number of people who sat down to dinner totalled 130. The dinner was attended and addressed by the Premier of Western Australia, Dr Carmen Lawrence; at least five other members of parliament, including Mr Con Sciacca-who travelled all the way from Queensland-attended it, as I did. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) sent a letter which was read out during the dinner. I have not shown the letter to the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support (Senator Collins) who is present in the chamber, but at this stage I seek leave to have it incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The letter read as follows-
PRIME MINISTER
CANBERRA

I am pleased to greet the Italian Internees of World War II present here tonight at this Reconciliation Dinner, a dinner which has been generously held under the auspices of the Western Australian Government.
I am proud to state that your mistaken internment in the 1940s was based on community attitudes of the time and would not occur in the multicultural Australia of 1991.

It is the firm policy of my Government to acknowledge and promote cultural diversity, and to maintain harmony between all ethnic groups. Experiences such as yours as internees, strengthened by the good will which you have consistently shown to a nation which was at the time much less welcoming, have helped Australians develop a much more mature and sophisticated attitude to our multicultural society.

The Government is aware of the important contribution of our large and well established Italian community to Australia's economic and cultural growth. As a nation, we are particularly conscious of how much we owe to the hard work and determination of Italian migrants and their children. In such diverse areas as business, community service, language, education and sport, the energy and enterprise of the Italian community has played a major role in shaping our unique multicultural society.

The entrepreneurial skills and vigour of Italian Australians have major importance for all of us. Your community has also been outstanding for its determination and self reliance in building a new life in a new environment. This is a record of which you can be proud.

Your strong combined will to survive and prosper has made it possible for so many of you to meet again, 50 years on-this is a magnificent achievement. I hope that you all have an enjoyable time at this Reconciliation Dinner and I wish you and your descendants all the very best for the future. Australia is proud of you.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. The reconciliation dinner was a very successful function. I could detect no bitterness about something which happened just over 50 years ago among the 130 people who attended that dinner. However, I wish to put on the record my thanks for the support I received from all parties in this chamber and in the other place. Of course, I also wish to thank the Western Australian Government, which I seldom do, and any other groups or people who contributed to the successful reconciliation function achieved that night.

SPEECH.PARA: One thing is still outstanding from my formal motion; that is, that a notation should be put on the files of these internees. After 30 or 40 years-I do not know exactly how long-the files kept on these internees were made open to the public. One of Mrs Turkington's first concerns after she had exercised her right to examine her father's file was that it contained some statements that she considered were not totally correct and had not been corroborated or backed up by someone. That was her primary concern; certainly it is still my primary concern. I picked out the files of people I know very well and examined them, and I am sure that a lot of the accusations they contain were not true. However, those accusations remain on the files and I think it is totally unfair that when those files become available to future generations-to grandchildren or great-grandchildren-they will think that their ancestors were criminals and were locked up for nearly five years when their only crime was to be of Italian origin in Australia at that time. I call on the Government to look at the idea of making notations to those files because the conclusions on them are not necessarily correct.

Finally, I would like to record the contribution made by Sonia Turkington of Como in Western Australia and her drive and tenacity to get this reconciliation dinner under way. As I said, it was only on 8 November last year that I raised this matter in this chamber and she had written to me on 26 October. Hopefully this sort of function will be repeated in other States.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Police Citizens Youth Club in Cairns

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee Sen W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is one of the ironies-and a very sad irony indeed-of a recession that at a time when people's need is greatest the amount of money available to alleviate their need is perhaps least. This is no less so in the case of the young. Tonight I wish to take a few moments of the Senate's time to give my recognition and appreciation to a great bunch of Australians who have done their bit to alleviate the need and the particular disadvantages of young people in far north Queensland.

SPEECH.PARA: I have spoken in the Senate before about the particular needs of people in Cairns, about how in Cairns there is a very high number of single parent families and that this has caused all sorts of difficulties because parents do shift work and there is nobody at home to look after the children. This has led to the highest youth crime rate in Queensland, where 56 per cent of all crime committed in Cairns is committed by juveniles. We believe that this year the arrest rate in Cairns for juveniles will be 28 per cent-that is, almost one in three people arrested in Cairns for crime will be under the age of 18 years. Any reasonable person looking at these statistics would say that there is a major problem in Cairns and something must be done about it.

One of the efforts to alleviate this problem is being made by the Police Citizens Youth Club. A group of people is endeavouring to put together a hall so that young people can be involved in activities, be given assistance, be given day care and be out of potentially bad influences. It is but one effort to cut down the high rate of juvenile crime. But there is a problem because, in spite of the need, and in spite of the undoubted valuable contribution that the Police Citizens Youth Club is making to these young people in Cairns, there has not been enough money to fund that club. So during the recess I went with the chairman of the Police Citizens Youth Club, who happens to be even younger than me--

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not possible.

—I assure Senator Collins that in this case it is. Grant Cassidy is a fine gentleman and an excellent Chairman of the youth club. His contribution has made that club tick along. We visited some 20 national companies around Australia which operate in the Cairns area and asked them to contribute to the community in which they operate. There were many instances where those companies said that they wanted to make a contribution, that they were strapped for cash but would give goods or services, or whatever.

SPEECH.PARA: But I rise to record a donation that was made by Placer Dome Mining, which operates a number of mines in north Queensland, Western Australia and Papua New Guinea. In spite of the fact that it had a very depressed gold price and the Kidston goldmine profits had fallen quite considerably, when we went to the company's offices in Sydney we were told, `We are going to give you some money. How much do you want?'. We said, `How much money can you give?'. We discussed it at length and were told that the company was very committed to what we were doing and would give us some money. By the time we got back to Cairns a cheque for $15,000 was sitting on Grant Cassidy's desk.

Such action renews my faith in mankind. It renews my faith in the generosity of private individuals around this country. At a time when so many people seem to be saying so many negative things about Australia, if only we had more people like the good people of Placer Dome Mining who are willing to fork out of their own pocket for what they know is right, many of the problems that this nation faces would not be as difficult as they appear today. I am very grateful to Bill Hundy, John Shaw, Alf Paton and everybody else at Placer Dome Mining for their contribution.

The amount of $15,000 will not build the Police Citizens Youth Club hall but it goes a long way towards our raising the money that we need and, more importantly, it is a sign to everybody that the corporate sector and private individuals have to do their bit. If Placer Dome Mining can do it, so can many other companies. I encourage those people who may be listening and who may read these comments to recognise that a community is only a community if it pulls together. As I said, with more companies such as Placer Dome Mining, our communities would be better still.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Commonwealth Assistance for Infrastructure Restoration in Queensland

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to take a few minutes of the Senate's time tonight to progress a little on the matter I raised today in debate under Government documents relating to the Advance to the Minister for Finance. Today I drew the Senate's attention to the fact that the Advance to the Minister for Finance had been used in June to make a payment of $2m to the Government of Queensland to meet an undertaking that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke)-apparently without any backing from his Cabinet, and in a unilateral action-had made in March of this year for Commonwealth assistance for infrastructure restoration following the recent natural disasters experienced by the State. I drew attention to aspects of that today.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to pursue that matter a little tonight and provide the Senate with information in relation to the action that I believe has been taken by the Department of Finance since this matter was dealt with to try to bring back better administration and greater propriety into the handling and the use of the Advance to the Minister for Finance.

TALK.START.PARA: —Instead of the standover tactics by the Prime Minister.

—As my colleague Senator Michael Baume says, instead of the standover tactics that appear to have been used by the Prime Minister in this instance earlier this year. To refresh the Senate's memory, on 8 May of this year the Prime Minister wrote to the former Treasurer drawing his attention to a letter that the Prime Minister had written to the Premier of Queensland on 13 March on this matter of Commonwealth assistance for infrastructure restoration. Although that letter was not tabled today with the other documents relating to the Advance to the Minister for Finance, it is clear from the Prime Minister's letter to the former Treasurer that the Prime Minister had committed a payment of $2m to Queensland for infrastructure restoration in each of 1990-91 and 1991-92. He requested of the former Treasurer that that be done by way of an Advance to the Minister for Finance under the Treasury appropriation because it related to Commonwealth payments to the States.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not know whether the Prime Minister thought he was going to get a better or more gracious response and acceptance of his letter from the former Treasurer because of the fact that he crossed out the words `My dear Treasurer' and wrote in `Dear Paul'. The net effect was that as a result of the letter from the Prime Minister, the former Treasurer-he obviously did not know anything about it at the time; it was prior to the receipt of the letter-then wrote to the Minister for Finance, Mr Willis, on 29 May drawing attention to the fact that the Prime Minister had recently written to the former Treasurer concerning a commitment the Prime Minister had entered into on behalf of the Commonwealth to pay a capital grant to Queensland of $2m in each of the two years to which I have already referred.

The former Treasurer, again in his letter to the Minister for Finance, pointed out that the Prime Minister's letter specifically indicated that the payment for 1990-91 should be by way of an Advance to the Minister for Finance. He then went on to say:

I understand (following consultation on this matter between our officers) that your approval for the payment to be made in this way, in writing and in response to my request, is necessary by virtue of Finance Regulations 44b. In view of the Prime Minister's specific request, I would be grateful if you would give the necessary approval.

It is quite obvious from that letter that the Treasurer was not too keen on this at all, but he had been backed into a corner by the Prime Minister and he could see no easy way out of it. Subsequently, on 7 June the Minister for Finance, Mr Willis, wrote back to by that time a new Treasurer, Mr Kerin, replying to Mr Keating's letter of 29 May. In his letter of 7 June Mr Willis said he understood that:

. . . the Prime Minister has informed the Premier of Queensland that, in view of the impact of successive natural disasters on the State budget, the Commonwealth will provide additional assistance of $2 million in 1990-91. This commitment was made after the Additional Estimates Bills for 1990-91 had been finalised.
He then went on to say that he supported the proposal to provide the additional money. He then said:
I understand that an application for funds from the Advance to the Minister for Finance will be forwarded to my department shortly for processing in the usual way.

The significance of this is that the Prime Minister entered into a commitment, apparently without the approval of his Cabinet, to pay money to Queensland and to do it by way of the use of the Advance to the Minister for Finance, without having sought to follow in any way the proper procedures that it is necessary to follow in order to obtain money from the Advance to the Minister for Finance.

That Advance is supposed to be used for unforeseen and urgent circumstances. According to the correspondence tabled today in the Senate, the Prime Minister gave that commitment to the Premier of Queensland on 13 March.
