Apparently, he did not write to the Treasurer-let alone to the Minister for Finance, who of course is responsible for the Advance to the Minister for Finance-until 8 May. That was almost two months after he had made that commitment to the Premier of Queensland. It then took another month or so to action. Indeed, the commitment and the approvals to use the Advance to the Minister for Finance were given before any application had been made to the Minister for Finance for the payment of those funds.

We have had considerable debates in this chamber, in Senate Estimates committees and in other committees associated with the Senate-including the Joint Committee on Public Accounts-over recent times about the propriety of the use of the Advance to the Minister for Finance. We on this side of the chamber have drawn attention time and time again to this Government's quite improper use of the Advance to the Minister for Finance to make payments, particularly to State governments and particularly to State Labor governments, for purposes which are never, ever perceived to be the proper purpose of the Advance to the Minister for Finance.

One of the reasons why that has been done is undoubtedly that using the method of the Advance to the Minister for Finance very largely disguises the fact that the payment has been made. It comes to light only after the event and it normally only comes to light buried in a huge mass of papers which may be tabled in the Parliament, or subsequently buried in some of the background papers to the Budget.

But that is all after the event. It is not subject to the normal appropriation processes that a Budget has, whereby the expenditure is scrutinised before it is approved by the Parliament. All we are doing by using the Advance to the Minister for Finance is allowing the Parliament to see what has happened after the money has been committed and actually paid out. It is done in a very hidden, secretive way.

I am delighted to see that-as a result of the Opposition's pressure in relation to this matter, the attention it has drawn to this matter in recent times and, no doubt, importantly, the quite flagrant breach of the use of the Advance to the Minister for Finance which the payment to Queensland that I have outlined tonight exemplifies-the Department of Finance on 25 July issued a new statement on the use of the Advance to the Minister for Finance and the guidelines to be applied to it. That was in the form of Estimates Memorandum 1991/24. I seek leave to have the memorandum incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
Department of Finance
Newlands Street, Parkes, A.C.T. 2600
Telephone: Canberra (06) 263 2222
Telex: 62639
Reference: 87/2025
Contact Officer: Stephen MacLeod
Telephone: 263 3551
Estimates Memorandum 1991/24
ADVANCE TO THE MINISTER FOR FINANCE (AMF)-GUIDELINES

Guidelines for the use of AMF were originally issued in September 1988 as Estimates Memorandum 1988/29. They have been slightly revised for clarification and are being reissued now in order to remind departments and agencies of the relevant requirements. Only those applications which conform with the attached pro-forma will be processed.

2. Application for funds from AMF must be made in advance of the requirement for those funds, and there should be no presumption on the part of departments and agencies that applications will be approved by the Minister for Finance's delegate. It is the responsibility of departments to ensure that expenditure does not exceed appropriation at any time. Finance Circular 1991/12 of 8 April 1991 also addresses this issue.

3. The delegate may request additional information in order to be satisfied that the requirements set out in the Appropriation Acts and the Guidelines have been met. This may cause delays in the processing of applications. To avoid this, departments should ensure that the Guidelines are strictly adhered to, and that adequate explanatory material is provided. Details of all issues from AMF are provided to the Parliament on a monthly basis, together with supporting applications. As a result of recent Senate Estimates Committee hearings, information relating to unsuccessful applications will, from 1 July 1991, also be collected on a trial basis for later provision to Parliament, if required.
I. McPhee
First Assistant Secretary
Financial Management Division
25 July 1991

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Government and the Minister. I draw attention to the fact that one of the key reasons that has been given for the issue of the memorandum, as contained in the document, is as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: Application for funds from AMF must be made in advance of the requirement for those funds, and there should be no presumption on the part of departments and agencies that applications will be approved by the Minister for Finance's delegate.

In other words, if those guidelines had applied before the example of the payment to Queensland that I mentioned, the Prime Minister would have been even more in breach of the proprieties of the Advance to the Minister for Finance than he was. I congratulate the Department of Finance on at least making this step, which should, hopefully, at least go some way to reducing the quite flagrant breaches of the use of the Advance to the Minister for Finance that have been occurring increasingly over the life of this Government.

On behalf of the Opposition, I can assure the Senate and the Government that we will be continuing to monitor this matter very closely indeed. It goes to the heart of the propriety of government in the use of public moneys. I welcome the guidelines and put the Government on notice that we are going to be very diligent indeed in ensuring that those guidelines are followed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I make two very brief points. Firstly, I commend Senator Short's remarks and say to the people of Australia that, if they get worried about the fact that sometimes the bureaucratic machine takes a long time to work for them, they should just note that it took the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) three months to get his will eventually implemented. He wrote on 13 March, promising the money to Mr Goss, apparently, and Mr Goss did not get it until after 7 June, despite `Dear Paul' letters and all the other paraphernalia. Maybe a lot of us should not feel too bad. I wonder what the relationship was between the Prime Minister and Mr Keating at that stage. I notice that the letter from the Prime Minister, dated 8 May, was not acted on by the Treasurer until 29 May. That seems quite a long time for the Treasurer to act in response to a `Dear Paul' request from the Prime Minister.
—Lightning fast, I would have said.

—The Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support, who no doubt has many relations of perhaps a less than satisfactory nature with the former Treasurer, says that, relatively, that is lightning fast. That may be so. However, it obviously did not satisfy the Prime Minister, who was massively underwhelmed by the fact that after two months nothing had happened about his request. It took another three weeks for the former Treasurer to do anything about it. The day after he did something about it, he took action against the Prime Minister. Maybe this was the straw that broke his back.

SPEECH.PARA: What I wanted to say is that I have a solution to our transport problems in view of the present industrial situation. Some people in Canberra-Senator McMullan, for example-have cars and can drive themselves to the Parliament. Obviously, all that needs to happen is that a car pool system be introduced. The reason I suggest that is that, if such a pool were introduced, no doubt Senator Richardson would give us a $20,000 government grant to assist us in that venture.

In the period when Senator Richardson was Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories he said in response to a question from Senator Walsh that he provided to the Flinders University conservation group a $20,000 grant to establish a viable car pooling system which, apart from educating the public in the importance of reducing the use of motor vehicles, was a step towards minimising the emission of greenhouse gases. All I can suggest is that we could do our bit to reduce greenhouse gases. All we need is a $20,000 grant from the Government. We could solve all the problems of the blockades here. No doubt Senator McMullan and I could spend the money quite well.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, upon notice, on 7 May 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Department considered the effectiveness of direct marketing? If so, please provide details of: (a) the areas in which the Department believes direct marketing will be of most use to it; (b) the results it would hope to achieve from direct marketing; and (c) the types of direct marketing methods considered most relevant and effective for the Department's purposes, for example, direct mail, telephone canvassing or other forms of direct marketing.

(2) Has the Department separated direct marketing as a budget item in Budget expenditure terms? If so, please provide details of the level of funds spent since 1 July 1990, the anticipated level to 30 June 1991 and the purposes for which the direct marketing will be used. If not, does the Department anticipate separating direct marketing as a budget item in its expenditure details? If not, why not?
(3) Does the Department have, or is it in the process of developing, a database from which it can operate its own direct mailing or telephone canvassing projects? If so, please provide details.
(4) Has the Department undertaken any direct mailing activities for this financial year? If so, please include details of the subject of the project, timing and to whom it was directed.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Most program areas of the Department engage in some form of direct marketing - by targeting specific industry groups to receive relevant information specially tailored to that group. This saves on the cost of dissemination of information and enables the Department to best design its information to achieve maximum effect with the specific target audience.

My Department also engages in direct marketing in its broad sense through a flagship magazine, Ascent Technology Magazine, and through various specialist publications targeted to specific audiences. A number of areas in the Department use mailing lists of clients, such as industry associations, companies, educational institutions, trade unions, scientific and research organisations.

In April the Department surveyed readers of Ascent Technology Magazine to find out needs for information on its programs. To date, more than 1,000 responses, expressing predominantly positive views, have been received. Media releases are also targeted to specific media and specialist writers to achieve maximum impact.

(2) The Department does not separately identify direct marketing as a budget item within its program allocations. Annual expenditure on Ascent Technology Magazine and other such publications is not sufficient to warrant the creation of a separate item within the Department's appropriation.
(3) The Corporate Communications Branch uses a database of 16 000 entries for mailing the bi- monthly Ascent Technology Magazine to industry organisations and individuals.

(4) In accordance with its mission of developing and supporting sustainable international competitiveness throughout the manufacturing and service sectors, the Department continuously disseminates information through the mail about its activities. Apart from the above-mentioned activities, the Department mailed the March Industry Statement, `Building a Competitive Australia', to 10,000 entries from its mailing list including industry associations, trade union companies, educational institutions and individuals.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Environmental Contamination of US Military Sites

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 7 June 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does Australia have specific and formal written assurances that no environmental contamination has been left at any US military site, former or current, in Australia, and that any such environmental problems have been addressed at least in accordance with prevailing US federal standards; if not, why not.
(2) Has the Minister secured a copy of the US Department of Defense compliance notice to the US Congress on these matters; if not, why not.
(3) Are there any problem sites, past or present, in Australia; if so, what are the sites, what dates were they contaminated, what were the contaminants, and what clean-up methods were used.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) While there may well be US legislation applicable to US military activities in the United States and overseas, so far as the Australian Government is concerned the relevant environmental standards governing the activities of US military personnel in Australia are defined in Australian legislation. This is provided for in a Status of Forces Agreement between the Australian and United States Governments (Australian Treaty Series 1963 No. 10). Article 13 provides that the United States Government shall conform to relevant Commonwealth and State laws and regulations, and that United States personnel shall observe those laws and regulations. These include environmental laws and regulations. Our agreements with the United States regarding the operation of the Joint Defence Facilities make provision for this situation to apply also at the Joint Defence Facilities.

(2) No. The obligations of the US Government under the Status of Forces Agreement and arrangements governing the Joint Defence Facilities remain undiminished by any domestic United States procedural obligation on the US Department of Defense to make available compliance notices to Congress.

(3) There are no US military sites currently in Australia and there have not been any for very many years. In view of the costs and other resources involved in researching any records that might still be available on any historical sites, such as those used by United States forces in the defence of Australia in the Second World War, I am not prepared to authorise the work necessary to provide a detailed response.

The Government acknowledges, however, that numerous areas throughout Australia are or may be affected by unexploded ordnance as a result of wartime training and testing activities by both Australian and allied military forces. The Department of Defence has for some years been working to identify these areas and the nature and extent of the unexploded ordnance problem there.

The Department of Defence and the Australian Defence Force are responsible for the disposal or rendering safe of any explosives or ammunition of military origin. This is provided for in a national policy for the management of land affected by unexploded ordnance as a result of military activities. The policy also imposes on Defence certain responsibilities for the management of land affected by unexploded ordnance. These responsibilities are primarily aimed at protecting members of the public from the hazards associated with such ordnance.

In November 1990, the Prime Minister wrote to the State Premiers and Territory Chief Ministers to inform them of the Government's policy and to affirm the Commonwealth's long standing commitment to make specialist Defence personnel available on request to render safe any items of unexploded ordnance which might be discovered.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 18 June 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is it a fact that, according to a September 1990 paper produced for the Uranium Institute by a departmental officer, Mr R.G. Crick, under current policy guidelines, Australia's annual uranium production capacity could be increased to 10 000t/y subject to market availability, that is, 6000t/y at Ranger and 4000t/y at Olympic Dam, without opening any more mines.
(2) Does the Minister concede that precisely the same thing has been argued by environment groups such as Friends of the Earth, even though they favour a complete phase-out of mining.

(3) Does the Minister accept the view that, if Australia cannot even get a guaranteed market for its current output of uranium, and that further mining in the Kakadu region would have a negative environmental impact, then there is no argument for opening more uranium mines.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. The paper presented by Mr Crick to the Fifteenth Annual Symposium of the Uranium Institute was entitled `Australian Uranium and Nuclear Policy'. The paper included the assessment that, by the late 1990s, annual production capacity from existing Australian uranium mines could be increased to 10,000 tonnes U(3)O(8) within current policy guidelines, subject to market availability.
(2) Some environmental groups would seem to take the view that Australia's future market potential could be satisfied by expanding output from existing uranium mines rather than by opening new mines.

Such an approach, however, does not appreciate the way the uranium market operates or the extent of future market opportunities for uranium. In reality, market participants would not enter into contracts to a mine's maximum nominal capacity. Moreover, for reasons of energy security, major utilities seek diversity of supply, not only geographically, but among different projects within a country. They would be cautious about the extent to which they were committed to any one project.

(3) The world uranium market is currently adjusting to past oversupply and excess of available stocks. This has led to cutbacks in production around the world, including the closure overseas of some higher cost mines. Although Australian producers have also felt the effects of the depressed state of the market, Australia has retained a significant and assured market for its uranium.

In 1990 Australia produced 4,163 tonnes U(3)O(8) and exported 7,442 tonnes U(3)O(8). Exports comprised 2,900 tonnes from the sale of the Nabarlek stockpile and 4,542 tonnes from sales by the existing producers under long term contracts. As recently as over the past twelve months, Australian producers have signed new, long-term contracts with utilities in Asia, Europe and the United States. Market opportunities will expand over the coming years.

The government has in place comprehensive environmental requirements, regulations, and monitoring arrangements relating to uranium mining in the Kakadu region. In relation to the existing mine there, the Supervising Scientist has attested to the high level of environmental protection which has been achieved.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 18 June 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is it a fact that, according to a Department of Primary Industries and Energy officer, Mr R. G. Crick, in a September 1990 Uranium Institute paper, the Department estimates that WOCA nuclear capacity in the year 2000 will be 320Gwe, as compared to 323Gwe estimated by the Uranium Institute, 310.6Gwe by Dr Ciaran O'Faircheallaigh, and a tentative forecast of 302-304Gwe WOCA by Friends of the Earth (FOE).
(2) Does the Minister concede that these numbers fall within what might be called a reasonable range of uncertainty, given the planning and construction lead-times for nuclear plants.

(3) Is it a fact that the environment group, FOE, has claimed in a widely circulated submission made in 1990 to the International Atomic Energy Commission and the ALP Uranium Policy Review Committee that, if nuclear capacity estimates made by NUKEM of 326.6Gwe for the year 2000 are taken and all reactors not currently under construction are removed from this estimate, a reasonable step in view of construction lead-time, and post Chernobyl uncertainties, we will derive FOE's number of 302-304Gwe for nuclear capacity in the year 2000.

(4) Is it a fact that, by removing from our calculations the 50Gwe that NUKEM says is not yet under construction from the 348Gwe NUKEM says will be in operation by the year 2005, we obtain the even lower number of 298Gwe for nuclear capacity by that year.

(5) Are the numbers suggested by Mr Crick consistent with claims in the Minister's letter to the ALP's Uranium Policy Review Committee, to the effect that the nuclear power industry will undergo a rapid expansion post-1995.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The paper given by Mr Crick of the Department of Primary Industries and Energy to the Uranium Institute symposium in 1990 estimated that WOCA nuclear generating capacity in the year 2000 would be 320 GWe. This was contrasted with Greenpeace's estimate of 310 GWe and other estimates from industry ranging from 326 GWE to 330 GWe.

(2) Forecasts of western world nuclear generating capacity for the year 2000 are based, for the most part, on reactors that are operating, under construction, or firmly planned. Variations in estimates arise because of different judgments about rates of construction and, in some cases, about public acceptance and government approvals. Greenpeace and Friends of the Earth, not surprisingly, take a conservative approach to the rate of growth of the nuclear industry. The estimate of 320 GWe, contained in the paper referred to in the first part of the question, reflects a realistic appraisal of government and industry processes.

(3) and (4) The claims attributed to the FOE submissions, as indicated in the questions, are based on the assumption that no reactor, not currently under construction, will be completed before 2005. While it is reasonable to expect that there could be approval problems and construction delays in a number of cases, the fact that approval and construction processes, in some countries, are currently continuing suggests that the validity of the FOE assumption is questionable.

(5) The letter of the former Minister for Primary Industries and Energy to the ALP uranium policy review committee did not claim that the nuclear power industry will undergo a rapid expansion post 1995. It suggested that there would be a significant upturn in the world uranium market from about the middle of the 1990s. This view is based on an analysis of both reactor-related uranium demand and uranium production and other supply trends. (See also the answers to questions 930 and 932).

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 18 June 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Minister aware of a September 1990 paper by Mr G. Grandey of the Uranium Institute.
(2) Is it a fact that, according to this paper, estimates for WOCA nuclear capacity in the year 2000 were dropped by 15 Gwe, from 338 Gwe to 323 Gwe.

(3) Is it a fact that only 4.7 per cent of the nuclear plants included in the updated Uranium Institute forecast were operating, under construction, or firmly planned, leaving little room for a post-1995 take off in nuclear capacity.
(4) What are the implications of this situation for Australian uranium markets.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. Mr G. Grandey and Dr W. Gehrisch of the Uranium Institute were the authors of a paper, presented to the institute's 1990 symposium, entitled `Uranium Supply and Demand to 2005: an Update'.

(2) The paper forecast that WOCA nuclear generating capacity would increase from 277 GWe at the end of 1990 to 323 GWe at the end of 2000, compared with an earlier forecast by the Uranium Institute of 338 GWe for the year 2000.
(3) No. To the contrary, only 4.7 per cent of the nuclear power plants included in the updated forecast were not operating, under construction or firmly planned at the end of 1989.

(4) All uranium market analysts, including those opposed to uranium mining, agree that western world nuclear generating capacity will grow in the period between now and the year 2000. There is general agreement about growth rates to 1995, but there are more substantial variations in estimates of the pace of growth beyond that.

The basic fact is that nuclear generating capacity is expanding, not contracting. This growth, coupled with draw-down of excess inventories accumulated in the expectation of more rapid growth in the 1980s, signals a significant improvement in the market outlook for uranium in the second half of this decade.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel, upon notice, on 19 June 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What is the existing Department of Defence policy for disability insurance for regular members of the Defence Force serving in: (a) peacetime; (b) a peacekeeping role; or (c) a declared or undeclared war.

(2) What is the existing Department of Defence policy for disability insurance for Reserve members of the Defence Force serving in: (a) peacetime; (b) a peacekeeping role; or (c) a declared or undeclared war, in both a volunteer and a call out capacity.

(3) What is the proposed Department of Defence policy for disability insurance for Ready Reserve members of the Defence Force serving in: (a) peacetime; (b) a peacekeeping role; or (c) a declared or undeclared war.
(4) Is it correct that disability insurance arranged for reservists serving in the Gulf covered only loss of income and not business expenses.
(5) Is it correct that the disability insurance arranged for reservists serving in the Gulf was not received by them until they had left the Gulf; if so, what was the reason for the delay.
(6) Has the Government received notice from any reservist who served during the Gulf conflict who, as a result of their service in the Gulf, are now suffering financially.
(7) What steps has the Government taken to put in place appropriate disability insurance in relation to any future conflicts Australia may be involved in.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The Minister for Defence Science and Personnel has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Regular members are provided with disability/invalidity cover as shown in the following Table 1.

(2) Reserve members are provided with disability/invalidity cover as shown in the following Tables 2 and 3. Members called out under sections 50E and 5OF of the Defence Act are required to render continuous full time service and are thus provided with benefits listed in Table 3.

(3) In relation to the Ready Reserve disability provisions will be exactly the same as for normal reserve members. That is while on reserve service they attract the benefits at Table 2. When on continuous full time service they attract the benefits of Table 3.

(4) The Commonwealth does not provide disability insurance to cover the private business expenses of its employees. Some reserve members did attempt to obtain such cover privately prior to deployment to the Gulf. In the circumstances insurance companies were not prepared to underwrite new policies for such insurance, while some companies stated an intention to invoke a war clause to deny liability in the event of injury or death in the Gulf.

(5) The first contingent of reservists to serve on the USNS COMFORT deployed in September 1990. Following representations in early November concerning the perceived inadequacy of the level of disability cover (provided under the Veterans' Entitlements Act (VEA)) the Government agreed that as an Act of Grace, in the event of injury or death, reservists serving in the Gulf would be provided with invalidity and death cover as if they had been members of the Defence Force Retirement and Death Benefits (DFRDB) scheme. The benefit was non-contributory though the regular member is required to contribute to DFRDB to obtain the same benefits. In addition a new provision was introduced for the reimbursement to reservists of any excess premium payable on invalidity insurance policies by virtue of service in the Gulf. No such provision exists for regular members. Members were informed of these initiatives in December 1990 prior to the departure of the second deployment to USNS COMFORT. Given the range of policy considerations which had to be addressed I consider the delay in finalising these matters was reasonable.
(6) The Government has received submissions from reservists who claim they are suffering financially from their service in the Gulf.

(7) With the introduction of the Military Superannuation and Benefits Scheme (MSBS) in October 1991, reservists who serve in an operational area described in the VEA will be able to contribute to and obtain the invalidity benefits of that scheme. Normal VEA operational service provisions will of course apply.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Communications, upon notice, on 18 June 1991:

(2) Can a target date be set as to when these services are to be separated from the 0055 network under an opt-in system.

(3) Is the new Telephone Information Services Arbitrator to exercise any supervision over on-line computer services transmitting `adult' and x-rated material; if not, has the Minister raised with Austel how such material may be regulated should its content contravene State legislation.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bourne Sen V.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support, upon notice, on 18 June 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Civil Aviation Authority (CAA) currently in the process of selecting a tender for an upgraded integrated system for the air traffic control centres at Brisbane and Melbourne.
(2) Which companies have tendered proposals for this project.
(3) Of the companies which have tendered proposals, which ones are Australian firms.
(4) Were Australian firms discouraged or barred from the tendering process for this project by the CAA.
(5) Is the CAA normally in the practice of discouraging Australian firms from tendering for projects.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Civil Aviation Authority on 3 June 1991 invited registration of interest in a project to modernise the Australian air traffic system. The project, among other things, will consolidate the provision of air traffic services, to the greatest extent possible, into two new major Air Traffic Service Centres to be located in Brisbane and Melbourne. The modernisation program is known as the Australian Advanced Air Traffic System (TAAATS) and has a target date for commissioning of December 1995.
(2) Six companies have been invited to register interest:
NEC Information Systems Australia Pty Ltd
Thomson Radar Australia Corporation Pty Ltd
The response period for registrations of interest closes on Monday 22 July 1991 for technical descriptions and Monday 29 July 1991 for price information.

(3) No companies have yet registered an interest. IBM Australia, NEC Information Systems Australia and Thomson Radar Australia were invited to register an interest. However, no Australian parent company was invited to register an interest.

(4) The approach chosen by the CAA of restricting invitations to companies that have demonstrated success in the implementation and integration of complete air traffic systems does not preclude opportunities for Australian industry. The CAA considered that no Australian firm met their qualifications, but the prime contractor chosen will be obliged to comply with Australian Government policies regarding offsets and Australian and New Zealand industry preference. The CAA will also require that a support capability for the selected system is available or established in Australia.

The high cost and schedule risks associated with development and implementation of air traffic control technology are well known. Cost overruns of billions of dollars have occurred on major projects. Therefore, it is no surprise that the CAA has chosen to minimise its risks by adopting a 'turnkey' approach. By seeking proven systems and inviting interest only from organisations which have demonstrated success in the implementation, integration and commissioning of complete air traffic systems, the CAA has adopted a low risk approach significantly reducing the potential for large cost and schedule overruns.

The CAA made a presentation to a large group of representatives of Australian industry in Canberra on 5 June 1991. At the meeting, the CAA provided Australian industry representatives with copies of functional specifications distributed to potential prime contractors, thus enabling local industry to assess potential areas of future involvement in follow up discussions with potential prime contractors.
In this regard, a group of Australian companies has now registered an interest with certain of the overseas companies on the CAA's prime contractor list.

(5) The CAA does not discourage Australian firms from tendering for projects. However, the CAA is a government business enterprise seeking to operate more efficiently and reduce costs to the aviation industry, without compromising safety standards.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel, upon notice, on 20 June 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: Where Defence Force members, being home owners, let their homes to the Defence Housing Authority for sub-letting to other service personnel:
(1) Is it correct that the Defence Housing Authority will not accept a release clause in the contract to allow the member to repossess the home if reposted to the locality.
(2) Is it correct that such a member would not be entitled to a married quarter.
(3) Is it correct that such a member would not be entitled to temporary rental allowance.
(4) What action is intended to rectify this situation.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The Minister for Defence Science and Personnel has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. The Defence Housing Authority (DHA) believes that its first priority is to the Service families occupying the houses it provides. In order to avoid disruption to families, the DHA would, ideally, like to provide assured tenure for the term of a Service member's posting to a particular posting locality. Although this may not always be possible when the dwelling has been leased, a no release clause at least gives security for the period of the lease.

(4) There is not yet agreement between the Department of Defence and the DHA on this question. Currently Service members who wish to lease their homes to DHA may do so. However, both Defence and DHA ensure that members are informed of the implications of being posted back to the locality of their own home before the expiration of their leases.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel, upon notice, on 20 June 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many of the 33,000 Australian Defence Force members without families are receiving a living-out allowance.
(2) What is the rate of the allowance.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The Minister for Defence Science and Personnel has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Departmental records indicate there are 2,476 members without family currently in receipt of Living Out Allowance.

(2) Living Out Allowance is paid to meet a member's reasonable living costs in respect of accommodation, food, utilities and laundry when suitable Service quarters can not be provided. As these costs vary according to the posting locality the Allowance is not paid at a set rate. Payment is of reasonable costs up to a locally set ceiling. Evidence of the costs incurred is required prior to calculation of the amount of Living Out Allowance a member is to receive and this payment is regularly reviewed by the approving authority. Members in receipt of this allowance are required to contribute an amount for board and lodgings known as the rations and quarters charge as if they were living in service accommodation.

(2) Is the service staffed at weekends.
(3) On what days of the week are the greatest number of calls received, and at what time.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services, upon notice, on 24 June 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many marketing approvals granted by the Therapeutic Goods Administration Division in 1990-91 are for therapeutic substances for treatment of specific conditions in women.
(2) How many drugs awaiting marketing approval are for the treatment of specific conditions in women.
(3) How are draft advice, discussion papers or agendas for the purpose of prioritising marketing approval for therapeutic substances developed.

(4) In view of private legal action opposed to the Government's National Health Policy for Women, does the Minister have absolute confidence in the processes administered by the Therapeutic Goods Administration Division.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (3) The allocation of priority for evaluation of drug marketing applications and the granting of marketing approval following evaluation is on the basis of:
First Priority: New chemical entities and drugs identified by the Australian Drug Evaluation Committee (ADEC) or the Department as offering a significant therapeutic advantage.
Second Priority: Generic drug products which are nominated as being likely to contribute to the cost effective achievement of the objectives of the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme.
Other Products: In order of receipt.
The process for identifying first priority drugs involves:
Applications for marketing approval applying for priority consideration and making a case as to why priority should be awarded.
All new applications are put before ADEC (whether seeking priority or not) which advises on the priority to be adopted.
In special cases, where the potential advantages of a new drug are clear, the Department's Therapeutic Liaison Committee may proceed to priority evaluation prior to referral to ADEC.

Where a drug is not identified as first priority, the application automatically becomes third priority unless and until a decision is made by the Pharmaceutical Benefits Branch to recommend upgrading to second priority.
(4) I have seen no evidence whatever of any improper basis for establishing priorities for the evaluation of therapeutic goods.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, upon notice, on 24 June 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Could the Minister advise the whereabouts of Saddam Hussein of Iraq.
(2) What is the present policy regarding Saddam Hussein and is he still regarded as the leader of Iraq.
(3) Does the United Nations intend to take any action to bring Saddam Hussein to trial for war crimes or acts of war.
(4) Are there any sanctions in place against Iraq by the United Nations.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) He is presumed to be in Iraq because of media reports of his public appearances there. I do not know his precise whereabouts.

(2) Australia maintains diplomatic relations with Iraq, the head of state of which is President Saddam Hussein. The Government withdrew Australian staff from our Embassy in Bagdad in January 1991, before the outbreak of the Gulf war, and we currently have no plans to return staff to the Embassy. Iraq maintains an Embassy in Canberra headed by a Charge d'Affaires.

(3) The United Nations Secretary General has said that the possibility of charging Saddam Hussein with war crimes `deserves much study and attention', and there have been statements from a number of governments calling for his prosecution.

In practice, however, there would be problems in bringing Saddam Hussein to trial. There is no existing international tribunal which could try him, and it is difficult to see how he could be brought before any tribunal that might be constituted for the purpose without substantial international intervention in Iraq to apprehend him. The US Government has said that it would not use force to arrest him. We understand that, in the circumstances, it is not the intention of the UN to initiate war crimes proceedings against him.

(4) UN Security Council Resolution 687 of 3 April 1991 affirmed the continuation of a broad range of sanctions against Iraq until Iraq complies fully with the terms of that resolution, which inter alia demands the destruction of Iraq's weapons of mass destruction. The sanctions restrict all forms of trade and commerce with Iraq except for dealings in foodstuffs, medicines and materials for essential civilian needs. In addition, Security Council Resolution 700 of 17 June 1991 reinforces the provisions of SCR 687 relating to the prohibition on the sale or supply of arms and defence- related supplies to Iraq.

TALK.START.PARA: —-On 21 June 1991 (Hansard, page 5327), Senator Watson asked me a question without notice concerning the eligibility of students at private tertiary education institutions to receive Austudy. The Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The tertiary courses approved for AUSTUDY are the bulk of courses at TAFE colleges and higher education institutions. Up to the end of 1990 it was a requirement for AUSTUDY approval that courses be government funded. The only private tertiary education institutions with courses approved for AUSTUDY in 1990 were private business colleges which had received a States Grants fees subsidy (phased out in 1989); Avondale, Signadou and Macauley Colleges which received States Grants funding in respect of teacher education courses; and Marcus Oldham Farm Management College which received States Grants funding in respect of a Diploma of Farm Management.

In the 1990 Budget the Government decided to extend AUSTUDY to other private business colleges in 1991. The further courses which have been approved for AUSTUDY this year are secretarial courses accredited by a reputable accrediting authority. The courses are similar in nature to those which were approved for AUSTUDY in 1990.

In the 1991 Budget the Government will be considering the possibility of further extension of AUSTUDY for privately provided courses. A requirement for approval would be accreditation by the relevant State or Territory accrediting authority.
